PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 10 citizens), Senator Calvert (from 445 citizens), Senator Parer (from 273 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 2,609 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

All Australians believe that the Keating Government should get on with the job of governing and direct its attention towards real issues such as the parlous state of the economy, the appalling level of unemployment, and our lack of international competitiveness.
The Australian national flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Quarrying at Exit Cave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee concludes that `even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values', respectfully call upon the Federal Government to take all necessary measures to prevent further quarrying at Exit Cave.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
Tamworth Legacy Widows' Social Club would like to protest most strongly at any change to our national flag.

Our husbands not only fought, but died under this flag. Since the Boer War our men have rallied under this banner. In every conflict since. Firstly for our British heritage then national pride in our own country, Australia.
Not under any circumstances whatsoever should our wonderful flag be changed in any way.
A referendum should be held Australia wide before anything is done.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that the new rates for registered articles under Australia's Post's Print Post arrangements are unfair and discriminate against rural residents. The new arrangements will significantly increase the cost of magazines and newspapers for those who wish to receive them by mail and has the potential to threaten the viability of country newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Farm Machinery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Those provisions of the "Sales Tax Simplification Bills" as applying to the payment of wholesale sales tax on spare parts by farm machinery manufacturers and dealers and its subsequent recovery is unfair and unreasonable in that it will;
(1)prejudice the financial viability of farm machinery dealers and manufacturing businesses
(2)increase farm machinery prices and increase production costs that will further prejudice the viability and competitiveness of primary production.
(3)not give any net gain to Government revenue
We therefore call on the Government to withdraw the provisions involved.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Green Labelling Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To Senator Michael Tate, MP, Minister for Consumer Affairs and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth. There is an urgent need for a Government green labelling scheme in order that consumers can be encouraged to buy products that have the least effect on the environment. Until consumers can be confident with manufacturers environmental claims this will not be possible.
Therefore, your petitioners request that the Australian Government takes steps immediately to:-
(1)Introduce a national environmental product labelling scheme.
(2)Insist on compulsory ingredients listing on household products.
(3)Upgrade the Australian standard for biodegradability.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Act 1982.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The speech read as follows—

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) Act 1982. The amendments will give effect to the Government's decision to extend the life of ACIAR, to broaden its mandate, to change the constitution and membership of its governing bodies, and to address four administrative issues which will further increase its efficiency.

ACIAR is a small statutory authority which promotes and assists collaborative research between Australian and developing country institutions on problems of mutual concern. This collaborative research is aimed at development of sustainable agricultural systems and the design of appropriate natural resource management strategies. ACIAR's activities form part of Australia's aid program.

Australia is in a unique position to provide such assistance because of its environmental and agricultural diversity and the high level of expertise of our scientists. Australia is the only developed country located in the tropics and subtropics, and many of our scientists are working on problems very similar to those in much of the developing world. Because of these similarities, benefits from ACIAR's work flow to Australia as well as to developing countries.

Mr President, when ACIAR was established ten years ago there was some uncertainty over whether Australia's initiative to establish a special-purpose statutory authority which would mobilise Australian agricultural research expertise to help developing countries solve their own problems and improve their own research capacity should be an enduring feature of the aid program. As a result, the ACIAR Act 1982 contains sunset provisions which limit the life of the Centre to twelve years unless, following review, amending legislation is introduced by the Government. Earlier this year, following a Ministerial referral, a comprehensive inquiry was undertaken by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to examine ACIAR's effectiveness and the desirability of its continuation. This was followed by the sunset review, as required by the Act, which drew heavily on the findings of the Joint Committee's inquiry. The Government has considered the sunset review report, and arrangements have been made for that report and the Government Response to the Joint Committee Inquiry report to be tabled.

Agricultural development is a key element of economic and social growth in developing countries and ultimately serves Australia's own economic interests because that growth fuels demand for agricultural and other products from trading nations such as Australia. Improved farming technology is the basic engine of growth in low income, substantially rural, developing countries. Numerous studies have shown that investments in agricultural research generate very large returns, and these returns, coupled with the way the benefits flow to those in poverty, make investment in agricultural research extremely good aid indeed.

Using a broad definition of agriculture, ACIAR has developed comprehensive but low-cost programs in crop and animal sciences, forestry, postharvest technology, plant nutrition, soil and water management and land use, economics and farming systems, and fisheries. There have been some outstanding successes. Examples include the successful biological control of salvinia water weed in Sri Lanka. This project rid Sri Lankan reservoirs and water courses of a choking mat of salvinia water fern, the world's worst water weed, using insects that feed on it. It was built on earlier work by the CSIRO Division of Entomology which resulted in the spectacular clearing of the weed in Australia and Papua New Guinea. Beneficiaries are rice farmers and fishermen and their families, hydro-electricity authorities, and rural people generally because of reduced spread of disease by mosquitoes. Independent assessment indicated a likely economic benefit to Sri Lanka over 25 years of $25 million—a benefit to cost ratio of 32 to 1. ACIAR is enabling the CSIRO team to release the controlling agent, a beetle, in Malaysia, the Philippines, Fiji, Kenya and Zambia.

Ambitious projects to control Newcastle disease, the world's most important viral disease of chickens, in village chicken populations in southern Asia using a heat-resistant vaccine are currently being concluded. Poor rural villagers throughout the world keep chickens to provide much needed protein and cash but frequent epidemics of Newcastle disease cause heavy losses in village chicken populations. Although Newcastle disease is not present in Australia, a mild variant of the virus exists here. This V4 strain causes no disease symptoms but does provide immunity against Newcastle disease. Veterinary scientists at the University of Queensland working with colleagues in Malaysia developed the idea that a heat-resistant strain of V4 could be developed and used as a vaccine which would not need to be kept in refrigeration. A first project proved this idea, and resulted in a vaccine coated onto chicken feed that could be conveniently fed to village chickens. A second project involved controlling the disease across a whole state in Malaysia, and proving and adjusting the technology in five other South East Asian countries.

The most severe disease threat to Australia's livestock industries is foot-and-mouth disease. ACIAR has promoted research to develop and prove the effectiveness of tests that can rapidly diagnose the presence of the disease and identify the strain of the virus causing the outbreak. This research involved teams of veterinarians from the Australian Animal Health Laboratory and the Department of Livestock Development in Thailand. The disease is endemic to northern Thailand and studies with the live virus there made it possible to refine a test and prove it in the field with actual outbreaks. Having the test available allows Thai veterinarians to quickly diagnose foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks and correctly identify the virus strain causing them. Cattle and buffalo can then be vaccinated with the correct vaccine. Rapid confirmation of false alarms or, should the worst happen, of foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks in Australia, would save the Australian livestock industries millions of dollars. For example, the tests enabled Australian scientists to diagnose a false alarm in Queensland in only 17 hours when a disease outbreak was suspected in 1988.

The final example relates to an excellent project on culturing giant clams for farming and restocking denuded tropical reefs. Giant clams became threatened after heavy poaching of tropical reefs in the 1960s and 1970s. Their meat is much sought after and forms part of the traditional diet of many Pacific island peoples. Work by James Cook University of North Queensland staff and colleagues in the Queensland Department of Primary Industries, the Philippines, Fiji, the Cook Islands, Kiribati, Tonga and Tuvalu resulted in the development of low-technology, on-land hatching technologies for artificial rearing of all seven known species of giant clam. Ocean culture techniques by which the clams can be grown to a commercially valuable size have also been developed. Nationally operated clam hatcheries are now operating in Australia, Fiji, Tonga, the Philippines and the Cook Islands. Apart from the benefits to villagers farming giant clams for traditional use and cash, denuded reefs can now be restocked for conservation purposes with locally extinct species.

There is no doubt that ACIAR has been outstandingly successful. It is lean, professional and efficient and has an excellent approach to its task. It has adopted a unique strategy of identifying developing country research priorities, of assessing the mutual benefit of projects to Australia and the developing country, and of matching these with relevant Australian expertise in the formation of carefully tailored collaborative research partnerships. The need for such programs now is even more compelling than at the time of ACIAR's establishment. While the driving force of agricultural innovation to increase per-hectare yields to feed burgeoning populations remains, the call for increased productivity is being counterbalanced by a call for sustainability. This requires a research-based effort to ensure high yields but without depleting land, water and marine resources irrevocably. Australia faces similar challenges to the developing world in this regard and will benefit from the ACIAR partnership mode.

Mr President, with the overwhelming evidence of the worth of ACIAR's activities drawn out from its review and elsewhere, the Government has decided that ACIAR and its work should continue, and the primary purpose of this Bill is to secure the Centre's future beyond its initial twelve-year life. However, in considering that fundamental issue the Government has also examined and endorsed three other recommendations which will extend ACIAR's mandate.

No provision exists at present for ACIAR to engage in training activities, yet training is integral to the research projects ACIAR commissions, not only to enable their successful conduct, but at times there are also excellent opportunities for broader capacity-building training. Up until now, this deficiency has been overcome by AIDAB reserving a small part of its training resource for ACIAR. In the future, ACIAR will be able to conduct its own project-related training.

The second matter relates to the implementation of results flowing from research projects. While the primary responsibility for the provision of resources necessary to ensure the transfer of technologies from ACIAR research projects into development programs remains with AIDAB, and AIDAB and ACIAR do maintain a regular dialogue on these matters, it is clear that there are occasions where it would be more appropriate for ACIAR to assess and commission a development activity independently. Accordingly, the Government has decided that ACIAR's functions should allow ACIAR to fund development activities when necessary to try to ensure adoption of the results of the research it commissions.

The third matter relates to Australia's support for international agricultural research centres, primarily those of the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research, but also other related centres and activities. The research conducted by the centres has been a driving force in expanding food production in developing countries. Most of the high-yielding varieties of rice, wheat and maize which have enabled the spectacular increases in production, commonly termed the "green revolution", were derived from varieties developed by two centres, the International Rice Research Institute and the Centre for Wheat and Maize Improvement. Australia has also been a substantial beneficiary. For example, around three-quarters of Australian wheat sown today comprises varieties derived from international research. The value of increased wheat productivity since the varieties were introduced in 1974 is conservatively estimated at $2 billion. Australia contributes to the work of the international centres through the aid program administered by AIDAB. ACIAR has developed close linkages with the centres and increasingly has been called on to provide technical and policy advice to assist in determining relative funding priorities and making sound decisions. With ACIAR's future assured, the Government has decided that responsibility for this important part of the aid program should become one of ACIAR's functions.

Mr President, much of the success and relevance of ACIAR's activities can be attributed to the direction and influence of its two governing bodies, the Policy Advisory Council and Board of Management. The uniquely constituted council with its strong developing country representation has played a fundamental role in the evolution of the Centre's programs. Similarly, the Board of Management has provided strong strategic management direction to the Centre. Nevertheless, the Government considers that some changes to the composition and size of both bodies are warranted. The 19-member Council tends to be somewhat unwieldy in practice and hence it has been decided to reduce it in size to a maximum of 14 members. It has also been decided to allow more flexibility in its membership by removing the requirement for Australians to be in a majority, and to allow for senior, appropriately-qualified AIDAB officials to participate in the work of the Council, instead of necessarily the Director-General of AIDAB. Similarly, the Government considers that the Board of Management could be reduced to five members with the removal of the requirement for ex officio membership of the AIDAB Director-General. ACIAR maintains good informal links with AIDAB and consultations are held routinely on a variety of matters of mutual concern.
Mr President, the remaining provisions of the Bill address four administrative issues aimed at increasing the efficiency of ACIAR.

The first issue relates to the powers of delegation of the Director of the Centre. Section 41 of the ACIAR Act stipulates that the Centre shall not enter into any contract without the approval of the Minister. The Attorney-General's Department has interpreted the power of delegation to approve contracts as limited to a person in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, an inappropriate and impractical arrangement for a statutory authority which is independent of the Department. This limitation has been construed on the basis of comments in the second reading speech made by the Hon. Tony Street, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, in 1982.

The ACIAR Act also limits the delegation of powers to `a person'. This prevents the delegation of powers to the Board of Management. The amendment Bill enables the Minister to delegate his powers to the Board of Management of ACIAR or to the Director or staff of the Centre.

The third issue relates to the banking of trust moneys. All moneys appropriated to ACIAR are paid into the ACIAR Trust Fund. The ACIAR Act also stipulates that all other moneys received by the Centre, other than trust moneys, are to be paid into the Trust Fund. As a consequence, any trust moneys received by the Centre cannot be banked into the Trust Fund, but must be banked into a separate bank account. This Bill amends the ACIAR Act to enable the Centre to bank trust moneys into the ACIAR Trust Fund.

The fourth issue concerns the financial reporting arrangements for the Centre. The Centre satisfies the criteria by which an organisation is deemed to be a department, and consequently is subject to the Financial Statements Guidelines. The ACIAR Act stipulates, however, that the Board shall prepare financial statements in such form as the Minister for Finance approves. The approved form is that set out in the Entities Guidelines. As a result, ACIAR currently prepares two sets of financial statements. This Bill eliminates this anomaly.

The Bill does not imply additional outlays although the Government is keen to see an increase in funding for ACIAR and the international agricultural research centres as budget circumstances permit. The administrative amendments to improve the efficiency of the Centre will reduce administrative overheads.
The Bill will come into force on Royal Assent.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORFOLK ISLAND (ELECTORAL AND JUDICIAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, the principal purpose of this Bill is to provide Australian citizens living on Norfolk Island the opportunity to vote in Federal elections.

The proposal flows from the Government's response to a recommendation from the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee Inquiry into the Legal Regimes of the External Territories.
The Committee recommended that Australian citizens living on Norfolk Island be given the right of optional enrolment for the purposes of representation in the Australian Parliament.

Mr President, the decision to make the enrolment facility optional recognises that there are historical reasons which make Norfolk Island a unique case. It also recognises the basic democratic rights of those Australian citizens who do wish to vote, but are currently denied the opportunity of doing so.

As Honourable Senators would be aware, the Government's decision to adopt this recommendation and, in particular, the proposal to attach Norfolk Island to the Division of Canberra for electoral purposes, created some controversy.

Legal advice available to the Government was that the Constitution would not permit the residents of an external Territory to vote in other than an electoral division of a mainland Territory. It was on this basis, and the advice of the Australian Electoral Commission, that the decision was taken to attach Norfolk Island to the Division of Canberra.
However, the Norfolk Island Government is vigorously opposed to the attachment of the Island to any single mainland electorate as it is felt that this would lead to a loss of identity.
I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that the legal and constitutional issues involved in this proposal have now been resolved.
Following intensive negotiations, agreement has been reached with the Norfolk Island Government as to the basis upon which eligible Norfolk Island residents will vote in future Federal elections.

The arrangement is based on the existing itinerant voter provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The Bill provides that Norfolk Islanders who can establish a relevant connection with a State Subdivision can enrol in that Subdivision. Those who cannot establish such a connection may enrol in a particular Territory Division, currently the Division of Canberra.

The Bill will also amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984, consequential on the amendments to the Electoral Act, to allow those Norfolk Islanders who take up the option to enrol to participate in referendums as required by section 128 of the Constitution.

Mr President, I am pleased that this contentious issue has been resolved to the satisfaction of both Governments and that, in future, it will be possible for Australian citizens resident on Norfolk Island to exercise their full democratic rights, but in a manner which takes account of the unique historical circumstances of the Island.
The Bill also seeks to amend the Norfolk Island Act 1979 to change the reference to "travelling expenses", as used in section 56, to "travelling allowances".
Section 56 provides a mechanism for authorising the payment of travelling expenses to Judges of the Norfolk Island Supreme Court as may be approved by the Governor-General from time to time.

The expression "travelling expenses" is somewhat narrower than the usual provisions dealing with travel-related entitlements. It has therefore been decided to amend the section to bring it more into line with the wording of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, which refers to "travelling allowances".
The opportunity has also been taken to validate past payments of travelling expenses purportedly made under that section.

Prior to 25 July 1991, the Governor-General had not approved the rate at which such expenses were to be paid. The practice was to pay visiting Judges travel-related entitlements in accordance with the relevant Remuneration Tribunal Determination applying to them as Judges of the Federal Court.
However, Judges travel to Norfolk Island in their capacity as Judges of the Supreme Court, not of the Federal Court.
As these past payments were technically unauthorised, but were made and received in good faith, it is appropriate that they be validated by legislation.
Financial Impact

The Norfolk Island Government operates its own fiscus from which it meets the cost of travel-related entitlements for visiting Judges. The electoral provisions of the Bill will have a negligible effect on Commonwealth revenues and expenditure.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for examination and report by 4 November 1992: With reference to the Trade Practices Amendment Act 1992 ("An Act to amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 to provide for the compensation of persons who suffer loss caused by defective goods, and for related purposes") and having regard to the need to ensure that consumers have reasonable and cost effective access to compensation for injury or damage caused by defective goods, and that producers and suppliers of goods are treated fairly, whether the Trade Practices Act 1974 should be amended to:

TAB.TAB: (a)give to Part VA of the Act the same extra-territorial application as is currently given to Parts IV and V of the Act;
(b)delete or amend the provisions dealing with the statute of repose (sub-section 75AP(2)); and
(c)assist plaintiffs in the discharge of the burden of proof.

SPEECH.PARA: This is to do with a matter which arose in the last session concerning the way in which Australian society should move the cost of an injury occasioned by a defective product in our society. In other words, where, because a manufacturer has put into the marketplace a product which is defective and that defect causes some bodily injury or some damage to a person, the Senate has already agreed that there should be a new way in which liability can be ascertained and, therefore, a new way in which compensation can be obtained by the injured party from the manufacturer—a new way, that is, supplementing the traditional ways of seeking damages by way of the law of negligence or under contract law as modified by statute over the last century or so.

PARA.TAB: This product liability legislation was a controversial matter. Whilst the Bill itself as presented to the Senate received the assent, I think, largely of all those involved in the then proceedings, three matters were excluded from the Bill which had been in the Bill in some of the original drafts. I indicated that I believed that those matters could be well sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

I argued in relation to extraterritoriality, which is a means by which overseas consumers could sue Australian manufacturers over defective products; and the period of repose, which is a mechanism by which the provisions of the Bill would not attach to the consequences of a product causing damage where that product had been put in the marketplace more than 10 years before. Also, a provision dealing with the way in which a plaintiff might be assisted to bring the claim before the court and get a fair hearing—get the day in court in relation to a particular matter—with the burden of proof always remaining on the plaintiff, on the balance of probabilities, to demonstrate that the defect in the product did in fact cause the injury. Nevertheless, it was thought in some earlier drafts that there might be a way of assisting the plaintiff to have the benefit of inferences that might be drawn from circumstantial evidence and so on to enable the person—

TALK.START.PARA: —Res ipsa loquitur.

—I will come to that; good point. This would enable the person to be assisted in getting the matter truly before the court—that it is a live issue for the court's adjudication. These are fairly technical matters, but nevertheless they have very important consequences for the viability of the manufacturing sector in Australia. That has to be balanced with the rights of consumers to ensure that they are not injured by defective products and have no effective form of redress.

PARA.TAB: I shall elaborate a little on those three issues. As to extraterritoriality, I have to confess that, in a sense, it was simply because the product liability provisions were placed within the Trade Practices Act that the extraterritorial operation of that Act was attracted. Almost without a definite intention on the part of the Government, the particular operation of the Act brought about a situation where it would be open to a person in a foreign country who suffered injury as a result of a defective Australian export to seek to recover damages from the manufacturer of that product in an Australian court.

I think there are good arguments for that to be the case. We should not be in a situation in Australia where the dumping on overseas markets of products that otherwise would not be safely marketed in Australia is encouraged. Already the Trade Practices Act prohibits the exporting, without ministerial consent, of goods that have been banned under the Act. So already there is a policy stance sanctioned by this Parliament with which the provision I originally had in the Bill would harmonise. But I think it is a matter that requires further consideration in order to get the balance right, and that is a matter that could well be looked at by a Senate committee.

`Period of repose' is a technical and unusual term. Basically, it means that there is a protection for manufacturers built into what we might call the parent model of this legislation, the European directive. It will be recalled that the Government, in seeking to renew the law relating to product liability in this country, was not attracted to certain proposals put by the Australian Law Reform Commission; nor did it feel that it was simply a matter of hoping that the law of negligence might be better implemented and modified by judicial reflection on the way in which loss should be apportioned in our society where a person is injured by a defective product.

The European directive, which governs, obviously, European Community countries and which looks like being adopted in northern Asian countries such as Japan and Korea, provided a model. Within that it is provided that this particular imposition of liability regime would not apply to a good which was put into the marketplace more than 10 years before the cause of action arose. In some earlier drafts of the Bill I took the view that 10 years was probably too short a time. I did so because, when one looks at the product liability cases of some notoriety over the last several years—claims against manufacturers in relation to the Dalkon shield and the Copper 7 IUDs and the asbestosis and diazepan cases—they all involved chronic long term effects which were manifested more than 10 years after the product was put into the marketplace.

I thought, therefore, that 20 years was a reasonable period. I am not talking about statute of limitations but statute of repose; it is a slightly different concept. I believe that, under the proposal I put forward, it was reasonable to say that the fact that a good was, say, 11 or 14 years old when it caused the damage should not debar the plaintiff from seeking to take advantage of this new product liability regime.

There was considerable concern expressed in the manufacturing sector in Australia, and the pharmaceutical industry in particular, about this provision, for very obvious reasons. When I was in the United States I talked with industry about the product liability regime, if it can be called that, that operates in that country. It is in absolute chaos. I do not know why a manufacturer would want to establish a manufacturing plant in the United States and put products into the marketplace there. The court regime is run by trial lawyers and the product liability regime is absolutely hostile to manufacturers in its operation.

The fact is that the Bills that have been introduced into the House of Representatives and the Senate, largely as a result of lobbying of manufacturers, include a repose period of 25 years for capital goods only and have no repose period for those which cause toxic harm. So what I was proposing was in no way radical. I hope that the American experience might be of interest to the Committee and that it might have a look at the drafts when it considers the matter. In any case, as Senator Alston, Senator Hill and Senator Spindler would know—I am not sure about Senator Macdonald—there is no statute of repose in relation to contract or tort. We also need to take that into account.

The third matter relates to the question of the burden of proof. What I tried to do in some earlier drafts—and Senator Alston indicated this in an interjection a little earlier—was build into the provision in the Bill some indication to the Australian courts that in looking at this matter they should give more weight to, and be more robust in the application of, the res ipsa loquitur principle; that it should not really be a very anaemic shadow of the rule as it is applied in the English courts in relation to negligence where in fact the English judges apply the principle of res ipsa loquitur, which means that a thing speaks for itself. There are certain circumstances where the plaintiff can take advantage of the obvious inference that must be drawn from an accident having occurred and relate the accident, the injury or the incident to a defect in the product.

At least this is a starting point. Then we can have the toing and froing of the case being argued. In the end, the plaintiff must prove on the balance of probabilities that the injury was caused by the defect in the goods. But the point is that the res ipsa loquitur principle is not strongly weighted in the minds of Australian judicial benches and in that situation I was trying to assist them to give the weight that they ought to give. That did cause great controversy and it may well be that some of the drafts that I put forward were not as eloquently put together as they might have been. Therefore, once again, I thought that ought to be withdrawn from the Bill as presented to the Senate in the latter stages of last session. Nevertheless, this matter ought to be properly considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

I believe that those three matters ought to be sent to the Committee. I hope that its workload will allow it to consider these matters when it finally concludes its report on the cost of justice—a mammoth undertaking which has taken several years of work. I hope that it will have an opportunity to examine this product liability matter. I hope that the various arguments can be put—and I believe this to be crucially important—on the Hansard record in open discussion before the Senate Committee rather than by way of various lobby groups exercising hidden power in the corridors. When I was Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs I was accused by some of being beholden to certain consumer lobby groups. Of course, it is alleged that manufacturers put pressure on other relevant members of parliament. I prefer to see all this out in the open with the arguments being put fairly and squarely before a Senate committee which I believe will be able to reach a reasonable conclusion in relation to these three matters. That committee would then bring a report back to the Parliament and we would consider whether a legislative amendment is required.

I commend the motion to the Senate. In anticipation, I thank the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for taking on this very interesting, somewhat technical but, in the end, very important reference. It is important for the rights of those who are injured by defective products but also it is important for manufacturing industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will oppose the reference of these matters to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That is a somewhat unusual stance for us. Generally speaking, we would prefer matters, particularly matters of legal consequences such as this, to be referred when there are issues that might not be otherwise as well developed through the non-public mechanism of the Parliament. However, in this instance the issues have been debated in detail for a long time and, basically, a reasonable balance has been found to protect the interests of consumers in matters of product liability.

PARA.TAB: I think everyone in this place accepts that there has to be reasonable protection for consumers, and perhaps at times in the past those protections have been inadequate. But most people also accept that there has to be a reasonable balance between the interests of consumers and manufacturers in this area, or the result is simply that our manufacturers are unable to compete with others in industrialised countries that also have well protected systems of law and protection. As we follow that argument, it develops into a failure of business in this country and a failure of jobs.

This motion is only before the Senate today because Senator Tate lost the argument in his own Caucus. It is somewhat rare that the Labor Party Caucus demonstrates any element of commercial commonsense, but in this instance it recognised that Senator Tate was just going too far and answering to the consumer lobby in a way that was out of balance with what is necessary to enable manufacturing industry to proceed in this country, but, nevertheless, subject to reasonable protections for consumers.

Senator Tate decided as a one-off that he would continue to pursue his objective, and to do it by means of sending the matter to this Committee. We received a rather colourful press release from the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) advising us that he had vowed to continue his push. Despite the fact that Caucus had decided to remove these three provisions from the legislation that he was bringing to us towards the end of last session, he was going to continue with this mission and try the alternative mechanism of gaining parliamentary support for these three measures through a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I remind you that the legislation passed through the chamber towards the end of last session. It considerably enhanced the protections and strength of consumers in relation to product liability cases. The Minister now wants to weigh the balance further in favour of the consumer to an extent that we think is totally unnecessary and, apparently, to an extent that his own Labor Party Caucus also thinks is unnecessary.

First, the Minister wants provisions written into Australian law that specifically give extraterritoriality—that is, the right for overseas consumers to sue Australian manufacturers over defective products. We see that as unnecessary. I use this occasion to say that we had some debate in the chamber as to whether the amendments the Minister was introducing to the Trade Practices Amendment Bill would have extraterritorial effect inadvertently. We produced advice from Clayton Utz and its counsel, Mr R.J. Ellicott, QC, to suggest that they may have that effect.

In the other place, the now Minister for Consumer Affairs, Ms McHugh, read an opinion given by the Chief General Counsel, Mr Dennis Rose, which was basically in support of the argument put in this place by the Minister that they would not have that effect. Nevertheless, I draw Senator Tate's attention to what Mr Rose specifically said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is by no means entirely clear that section 75AD(c) would be limited to cases where the relevant injury was suffered in Australia.

Despite the Minister's undertakings—and I accept that they may well have some consequence in the interpretation of that legislation—there still seems to be an element of uncertainty on that matter. There is a good argument that the Government should have made clear, and still should make clear, in that legislation by amendment, the fact that it is not to have extraterritorial effect. That is by the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will go to the parliamentary committee, too.

—I suspect that the Australian Democrats will support the Minister in this reference to the Committee. The Democrats are not well known to take into account the commercial consequences of legislation and, therefore, the Committee may well look at that issue as well. We do not see the justification for giving this extraterritorial effect in relation to product liability and do not see any reason at all why it needs to be further debated within the committee system.

PARA.TAB: The second issue that Senator Tate is concerned with is the period of repose; that is, for how long can complainants bring action and make their complaint. Senator Tate believes that that should be for a period of up to 20 years. As I said, these matters are a question of balance and we think that on balance that is totally unreasonable. It simply does not take into account commercial reality. What has been put in the legislation is a period of 10 years, and that strikes us as a balance that is not unreasonable. In fact, one can imagine manufacturers even being concerned by that length of time, because they have to plan their business to take into account consequences that could flow.

Nevertheless, we obviously have a responsibility to consumers and 10 years is the figure that has been included; but to seek to extend it to 20 years is totally unrealistic and totally fails to appreciate and reflect any sort of reasonable business understanding. There is no reason, in our view, why that needs to be debated further within a parliamentary committee either.

The third area that Senator Tate is pursuing in one way or another is really an attempt to switch the onus of proof. I do not know whether he adopted this colourful expression of the `Aussie battler' provision, but he certainly utilises it within his press releases as demonstrating the spirit of what he is seeking. What we are supposed to interpret from that is that in some ways the Aussie battler is disadvantaged unless the onus of proof is on the manufacturer instead of on the claimant. Although the use of such an expression is now obviously designed to strike an emotive cord, it really amounts to a switch in the onus of proof.

We do not think that is justified also. The person who brings the claim must be prepared to make out that claim, and that protection is enshrined within common law to try to find a fair balance between those who bring actions and those who have to defend them. We do not really see any reason in that instance why the Committee's time should be taken up with an examination of Senator Tate's so-called `Aussie battler' provision.

In normal circumstances we are more than happy to support references to Senate committees where useful outcomes might result from their deliberations. However, in this instance we are simply left with a frolic of Senator Tate's which in some ways is a relic of his period as Minister for Consumer Affairs. I think he somewhat regrets that that responsibility has been taken from him. When one thumbs through the series of press releases that he put out during that period, one understands that he certainly saw himself in the role of a knight in shining armour going forward.

Whilst I in no way reflect upon Senator Tate's motives, I really think he lacks an element of commercial reality. I say that in a sense of goodwill. I understand what Senator Tate was seeking to do during his period as Minister, but even his own Party recognises that there has to be some commercial commonsense in these matters. For him to seek to take it further yet again, having lost the portfolio, through means of this Senate Committee, is in my view simply a waste of the time of the Committee, and in those circumstances we are not prepared to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats regret very much the necessity for this referral to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As has been expressed before by our then spokesperson, Senator Powell, the Democrats would have liked that Bill to remain intact under the onslaught of industry lobbyists and in light of the Government's somewhat weak-kneed reaction to that particular lobbying effort. The Bill could have remained intact because the numbers were there. Let us put that on the table. If the Government had wanted to pass the Bill with these provisions intact, it could have because the Democrats were perfectly willing to support it.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons we would have supported it is the obvious responsibility of Australian manufacturers to users and consumers of their products. The three areas taken by the Minister into the reference are essential elements of that particular orientation. Why should there not be extraterritorial application if a user buys an Australian product in good faith? Why should a manufacturer escape responsibility if the time period elongates because the effects of the product defect do not become readily clear or cannot be detected as in many of the cases we have been dealing with historically? For instance, in the case of asbestos and some of the medical products, the damage and effects were not known until decades after people used them. So why should a manufacturer escape liability?

The third item which causes us great concern is the fact that manufacturers could escape liability simply because ordinary people—yes, Aussie battlers, Senator Hill—simply lack the financial power, the wealth, that these days is necessary to get into court. In our court system at the moment the legal costs that are attendant upon retaining lawyers practising in our courts are such that only the very rich or the very poor, if they qualify for the ever diminishing criteria for legal aid, can afford to take legal action. So it is necessary to enable these people to take action. I speak on that particular topic with a degree of feeling because of the cost of justice evidence that is now before the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee to which this particular matter is being referred.

There is another matter that needs to be raised. Apart from the need to even the balance between the manufacturer and his or her battery of lawyers on the one hand and the consumer on the other, I believe the Bill has been painted wrongly as being anti-business. I believe that business that sent its lobbyists into action was mistaken. If we are to be competitive in world markets, if we are to build up a viable export industry, we need manufacturers and we need products which are produced to the highest quality standards. In fact, the reputation that we can build by doing that will be of benefit not only to the community, not only to the consumer, but also to the manufacturer because we will be able to establish a reputation for quality, for consistency and for taking responsibility if something does go wrong, which will mean that consumers here and in other countries will buy our products with confidence.

It is rather a pity that business has chosen to hide behind technical legal protection when it should be concerned about building up its capacity and reputation for responsibility in not only producing the highest quality products but also standing behind them readily and responsibly. From that point of view, I believe that the Bill, as it stood originally, was sound from both the consumer's point of view and the manufacturer's point of view.

I regret very much that the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, has apparently been rolled in Cabinet, as it has been so colourfully stated by Senator Hill. I believe that the Minister is to be commended for the way in which he is pursuing the substance of the Bill as it originally was. The Australian Democrats will certainly support the reference to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, although we regret that that reference is necessary. As I said, we would much rather have passed the Bill intact. It was very much a second best Bill that was passed by the Senate.

We certainly support this reference to the Committee. As a member of that Committee, I look forward to the investigation that it will undertake into this particular matter. Although I have made quite clear our value position on the objectives of the Bill, we will of course carefully examine the evidence that is presented to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I come late to this debate. I have only recently had the opportunity to recently peruse the press release of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). But, if his proposal is as I fear, it is appalling. I would be grateful if the Minister could tell me or indicate to me as I talk whether I am wrong. If his proposal is to remove the evidentiary burden of proof and replace it with a proposition that, as long as a consumer can demonstrate that his claim is reasonable in all the circumstances of the case, he ought to recover damages—
—No.
—Could the Minister very quickly tell me what the replacement proposition is for res ipsa?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—With respect, Senator, that would create a rearrangement of procedure. Would you like to proceed to tell the Senate and the Minister your difficulties? The Minister will perhaps be able to put you right at the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply indicate that, if the Minister sought leave to make a brief statement to that effect, it would save me a lot of time in talking about something that I might have got wrong.

—by leave—It is the intention of the Government that the burden of proof remain on the claimant in relation to all the elements of the product liability claim: that is, that the injury that was sustained was caused by a defect in the product. In other words, the ordinary civil burden of proof, the balance of probabilities, would be retained.
—Including proving the defect?

—Of course, proving the defect and that it caused the injury. But, as the honourable senator would know, under the res ipsa loquitur principle the claimant, as in a negligence case, can have the benefit of that principle in order to make a live issue of what it might be difficult to prove by step by step evidence. In other words, there is a certain amount of circumstantial evidence and inference that may properly be drawn from the circumstances relating to the incident of the injury. That is what I mean by res ipsa loquitur. It is only as an aid to help the claimant get the matter off the ground.

PARA.TAB: The difference between the approach of the Australian and English judges in negligence cases, as Senator Alston knows from practice, is that the English judges take a much more robust view and give greater weight to the res ipsa loquitur principle as assisting the plaintiff. But in the end the plaintiff bears the onus in the traditional way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including—
—Excuse me, Senator Bishop. For your benefit, I point out that if you were in your chair then your questions and interjections could be heard and could be recorded by Hansard.

—I did indicate that I tried some drafts of how that might be achieved. I admitted that they may have lacked something in final elegance. It is difficult for a parliament to instruct a judge as to how he deals with the ebb and flow of a case before him, which is what the res ipsa loquitur principle of course deals with. There are difficulties; I do not deny the difficulties. All I am saying is that, in answer to Senator Alston's primary concern, it is the intention of the Government that at the end of the day, as the trial comes to the conclusion, the judge has to ask the question: `Has the claimant proved all the elements on the balance of probabilities?'.

—by leave—As I understand it, what the Minister is saying is that he believes that the judges in this country are wimps and that the way in which we strengthen their resolve is to refer provisions to the Committee so that the Committee can find ways and means of beefing up the res ipsa loquitur principle. The Minister does not have an alternative proposal at this stage, and the best that we have on the record is this classic populist phrase: `It is designed to ensure that where in all the circumstances of the case a consumer's claim is reasonable then the consumer should be guaranteed his or her day in court'. That is an open door approach. Can I just say, for the benefit of Senator Spindler in particular, that one does not have to be extremely rich or extremely poor to run—
—Tell me.

—I am just about to. Be patient. What happens in practice in the real world of litigation is that firms such as Slater and Gordon and Holding Redlich run these things on spec. They act for unions en masse. They have enormous claims constantly going through the courts. If they lose, they do not pay. Either the union underwrites—
—What happens when you get rid of the unions?

—We are not getting rid of unions. Unionism will be voluntary. To the extent that people get their money's worth, they will belong to unions in droves. If unions are prepared to underwrite legal actions, I suppose they will have even more supporters than they do now.
—But that should not be necessary.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! Please address your remarks to the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment. Senator Spindler made the facile and fatuous statement that somehow you have to be rich or poor, and now he is saying, `Well, even if the others can get a deal, maybe that's not the best approach'. He cannot have it both ways. I am just telling him the facts of life—that there are legal firms that will undertake these sorts of actions.

PARA.TAB: The other real difficulty, which Senator Spindler seems to be unable or unwilling to comprehend, is when someone comes along 40 years after the event and says, `I once served my country on the Kokoda Trail. It was pretty rough going so I used to smoke a bit in those days. Here I am at the age of 78 and I have suddenly discovered that I have lung cancer and it is all the fault of the Australian Army'. It is very difficult in many circumstances to establish the link. The link is not established on some emotional basis that somehow the person is a patriot who deserves recompense. It is established through the social security system or various other mechanisms. Veterans affairs provisions provide compensation of various sorts. But the person does not come along to the courts, throw himself at the mercy of a jury and say, `I really have great difficulty in proving that what I am now complaining of relates back to those days on the Kokoda Trail, but I want to put to you the Senator Tate principle that in all the circumstances of the case it is reasonable that I ought to get a whacking great pay-out. Despite the fact that it may be a windfall gain to my relatives because I have not got long to go, I want you to give me a very substantial award of damages, whether it is punitive or whether it is merely to make up for all the pain and suffering that I have incurred over the period'. In other words, it may have nothing do with the causative link and the person may have no prospects at all of proving his case. That is what litigation is all about.

Senator Tate gets up here and rings his hands virtuously and says, `We don't want consumerism gone mad, as I saw on my last trip to the US'. But that is precisely what he is proposing to import into this country. If he had a skerrick of responsibility and concern for consumers—who of course ultimately pick up the tab for these things by way of higher cost of products—he ought to be interested in ensuring that we compensate people as a matter of course for silicosis or pneumoconiosis or whatever else it might be through the welfare system. But people do not go through a big legal charade which eventually comes down to saying, `Because my injury is serious, I ought to get compensation'. That is what the Minister is doing by trying to do away with this link.

Put aside the general proposition that every judge in Australia somehow lacks the intestinal fortitude to apply the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur. That principle has been around for very many years. Senator Tate well knows that it is open to every lawyer in the country to argue it as vigorously as possible and to persuade judges that they ought to follow their English brethren. If they do not, presumably there are good reasons why that is so. One can then appeal and argue that the High Court somehow is negligent in its duties if it does not properly apply the principle. That is not what I understand Senator Tate to be saying which is that, somehow, the end result in this country is not quite as good as it seems to be in the UK.

The solution to that may well lie in a number of areas, but it does not lie in artificially trying to change the onus of proof. In my experience, that doctrine has certainly served the process well because it does, to a considerable extent, ensure that one does not get swamped by those American approaches. If there is one thing we certainly do not want in this country, it is that form of litigation. The Minister says it is run by the trial lawyers; it is run by a legal system that has opened the door. Contingency fees and all the other rigmarole—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you opposed to contingency fees?

—I do not have a view on them, but I have never seen a particular need for them. If I were pressed on it, I would not be in favour of them for that very reason—that they are really an encouragement for people to go in there on spec. That is precisely what would happen with the Senator Tate approach and that would be an absolute disaster.

PARA.TAB: Medical negligence actions have nowhere near reached the stage that they are in America. The consequence is that we have premiums of $100,000, $200,000, $500,000 being paid by surgeons and that flows through directly to the cost of medicine. Then we will get the Senator Tates and the Brian Howes of this world getting up and saying, `Isn't it appalling. We certainly couldn't move to anything like the American system of health because it is far too expensive'. That is part of the reason why it is far too expensive—every man and his dog is terrified; when he sees an accident he crosses over to the other side of the road because he might not be insured and he might have applied the wrong bandaid. Some clown will be able to go to court and run a million dollar suit against him on the basis that he might be insured. That is precisely what would happen here.

Those opposite are throwing away legal principles if they think that somehow one can go into court and say, `Despite the fact that I have not proved my case; despite the fact that, in theory, the onus of proof is on me; I am saying to the jury, "Go through the motions. You have to find in that way, but the bottom line is, is it reasonable?"'. Those opposite know that that is tantamount to saying, `If the injury is sufficient, give me compensation', and that is not what the courts are for at all. The courts are there to apply principles. We set out the standards in legislation or in common law and if one does not jump over the hurdle, one does not get to the winning line.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally agree.

—I have done enough jury actions over the years to know that there is a very considerable temptation for juries to award damages to people just because they have serious injuries. I have the greatest sympathy. I have acted for plaintiffs and I have prospered under that system to a certain extent. One does get caught up in it all and one does feel that somehow it would be terribly unfair and unfortunate if one's seriously injured plaintiff did not get a whack of damages. But when one stands back from it all, the fact is that that is a corruption of the legal process.

PARA.TAB: I can remember situations where people involved in accidents were not wearing seat belts, and it was quite clear that that was the major reason why they had become paraplegics. One is meant to discount it for contributory negligence. The real fault ought to lie almost entirely with the plaintiff for not having his seat belt done up. What would the jury do? It would award a huge amount of damages and knock off 10 per cent—the classic compromise.

That is an abdication of responsibility on the part of a jury, but we cannot blame them. They are representatives of the community. They are not even told about concepts such as insurance. They are just asked in effect to do the right thing. That would be the Senator Tate approach. What is the right thing? `The right thing is not to see the poor unfortunate wheeled out on a stretcher without an award of damages. The right thing, so-called, is to ensure that we can safeguard the future of this particular individual who has been before us for the last week and who is obviously very deserving. We are not particularly concerned about the fact that it might add a cent or two to third party insurance premiums or the cost of products'. Of course, we fall for that every time. That is precisely what Senator Tate is doing here. I think it is regrettable that he continues to cave in to the consumer lobby, irrespective of the practical consequences.

I am delighted that Caucus has said that enough is enough. Unfortunately, it would seem that if this reference goes off to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs we will get the same abdication of parliamentary responsibility that we have seen evidenced in the chamber today. I implore Senator Spindler—if the matter is to go off to the Committee—to think seriously about the ultimate burden on consumers because they are the ones who pick up the tab. If he wants to have a system of universal compensation because he has suffered serious injuries, let us talk about extending the welfare system, but do not let us talk about these sorts of charades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support this reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. To put it in context, as I said at the time of the passage of this legislation, it should not be necessary. Senator Spindler has made some comments on that already. Like Senator Alston, I too have looked at the press releases of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). I rise today, in particular, to refer to the Minister's press release of 7 May when he foreshadowed pushing ahead with the legislation and also this reference which is before us today. In that press release Senator Tate said:

SPEECH.PARA: `. . . on the three issues opposed by business, I will have my day in court—or rather in committee—to argue for their inclusion'.

I am not a member of that committee at present, although I have been in the past. I am standing here to urge Senator Tate to do just that because he remains the vocal advocate on the Government side for the consumers in this matter and on this particular piece of legislation. The consumers of Australia are relying on Senator Tate to continue with his strong advocacy in this area. I look forward to reading the transcript of his evidence before this Committee. I encourage Senator Tate to follow that through and have his day in the Committee.

PARA.TAB: However, I have a concern about some of the comments that the Minister made in the second reading speech when the Trade Practices Amendment Bill, now Act, was introduced. I am not questioning his motivation in sending these crucial issues off to the Committee. In fact, he is to be commended, as he has been already in this debate by Senator Spindler, for not dumping Australian consumers in the face of a heavy business and industry lobby and for conceiving this approach. He will have the numbers to achieve it.

I am concerned about the apparent implication that consumer groups and others with less power and force quite often in public debates are not treated equally unless they can get before a Senate committee. That is a matter of particular concern when we have an oppo-

SPEECH.PARA: sition here today determined to oppose, by its vote in this chamber, such a reference. One has to be extremely concerned about a political coalition in this context who may well be in government after the next election not being prepared to allow ordinary Australians, to allow those without the power of money behind them, to have their day in committee, let alone in court. I feel that is something that ought to be of concern in the political process.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly concerned about the suggestion coming from Minister Tate that before the Australian Labor Party was in government the situation, at least in this case, was that consumer groups and individuals in the community were not able to raise their voices sufficiently other than in this context. However, the reference will pass the Senate and go ahead and be in the hands of an extremely competent committee.

I want to make a comment or two on the Opposition's proposition that somehow or other to have strong consumer protection laws in this area—and as yet we do not, because the legislation that was passed was significantly defective—is to threaten the viability of Australian industry. The opposition to the extraterritorial claims, in particular, raises this question. Surely there ought not to be any suggestion at all that the viability of Australian industry should be dependent on the provision of anything less than full rights for consumers, wherever they live. Surely we do not want to build industry in this country that is dependent upon being able to fling its products out onto the world marketplace according to anything less than a regime in this country or anywhere else in the world that would protect the consumers of those products.

So much for the Opposition's much trumpeted pursuit of excellence in Australian industry. So much for its commitment to overseas competitiveness. What has happened to international best practice when it comes to consumer law? I do not see how the Opposition's position will in any way enhance the reputation of Australian industry—far from it. It is the case that around the world these sorts of laws are being passed and quite often they are strong laws.

It was a disappointment to me that, when the Bill was before us previously, the Minister took a different position on the question of the burden of proof from that perhaps previously canvassed by the Government and certainly by the Law Reform Commission and was forced to take the EC directive model. To my mind, that was a less protective approach, unless we take the approach which is taken by a number of EC countries, including the United Kingdom, Ireland, Germany, France and Italy, where claimants have other advantages, some of which the Minister has referred to already.

It is important for this Parliament that the issue of the burden of proof is very closely looked at, that we put the interests of consumers where they rightly ought to be—in perspective—and that we do not fall for the furphy about the viability of Australian industry. I do not think anybody really wants to fall for that one; our international reputation could only be damaged.

So while the Act as we now have it is, in my mind, considerably defective, as the Minister said at the time, Australian consumers had already waited five years or more for some additional protection. So we did need to pass that legislation. We do, however, need this reference. I hope that we do not have an election later this year because with the reporting date of 5 November, I think it is, and then time needed for legislation I would be extremely concerned if this issue were not dealt with in the life of this Government, given the incredible approach of the Opposition on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support Senator Hill's remarks in opposing the reference and to support the remarks made by my colleague Senator Alston, who dealt very effectively with the woolly thinking—which is the only way I can describe this press release—of Senator Tate. I think we need to look at this reference in the light of the history of this Bill. The first proposition that was brought to this Parliament was that we should have absolute strict liability. That is, if someone was injured by a good, then there was naturally assumed to be a defect in the good and the manufacturer was liable. There was no defence. The only thing you could plead was mitigation as to how much you paid.

PARA.TAB: The Government was forced ultimately to have an economic impact study as to the economic impact that the legislation would have upon Australian industry. When we finally observed the result of that, we saw that it would have been devastating. We looked at the situation in the United States where, not by legislation but by common law practice, a strict liability system had been introduced.

Senator Alston outlined the situation as it applies to medical practitioners. But, of course, there is the well known example of an entire industry that went out of business in the United States forever, and that was the industry that manufactured light aeroplanes. That industry went out of existence because of the strict liability principle: if an aeroplane flew into a mountain, there was a presumption of a defect in that aeroplane. Furthermore, under that principle the argument could be extended to say that some of the screws that held bits and pieces together were also defective. The whole industry collapsed. Other examples can be found—and I would suggest that Senator Powell take a look at them—as to the way in which the cost of the manufacture of goods and the cost to the consumer is increased by placing undue burdens on the manufacturing sector.

The Law Reform Commission report contained a statement that this was actually an ideological stance; that manufacturers who make things in order to be able to make profits ought to bear in the cost of that manufacture a payment to anybody who may suffer injury at some stage. In other words, it was a transfer on ideological grounds of the social welfare net onto the manufacturing sector. It was an absolute nonsense—and that is finally what the economic impact statement said.

Then we came to the watered-down provision. We took a look at the European directive or, more particularly, at the German-pushed European directive. When the United Kingdom introduced its version of product liability legislation pursuant to the European directive, it provided for a state-of-the-art defence. That simply says that a manufacturer has produced the goods to the absolute best state of the art in the world; that they are up to best practice in the world. But under Senator Tate's idea and Senator Powell's idea, the top standard of excellence is simply not enough; they impute that somebody was negligent or in error and that a fault existed whereas in fact it was the best state-of-the-art manufacture at the time.

The European Commission came back and said to the British Parliament, `Your legislation will not do; you are not following the directive and if you, the British Parliament, do not change your legislation'—and I think the period was three months—`then we will take you to the European Court of Justice'. So within the European Community we had two standards of the product liability standard to be followed. Germany followed the tougher standard, and when I had discussions with people in Germany about how they lived with it their answer was that they were a rich country and they could afford it. With the absorption of East Germany, they may have to reconsider that attitude.
Senator Tate's consumer's claim—and I did say it is woolly—states:

SPEECH.PARA: The so called "Aussie battler provision" designed to ensure that where, in all the circumstances of the case, a consumer's claim is reasonable, then the consumer should be guaranteed his or her day in court.

What Senator Tate is trying to achieve, on my reading of the rest of his press release as well, is a strict liability provision by legislation because, he says, our judges are wimps and do not use the res ipsa loquitur principle to the degree to which the British courts do. We can accept that or not.

PARA.TAB: Personally, I think there are judges here in Australia who are as good as the best that are going, and if Senator Tate thinks the real answer to his problem is for him to personally choose all the judges and say, `Before I approve your position on the court, you have to pass my test', that makes a joke out of our legal system. Very simply, Senator Tate cannot have it both ways. Either the burden of proof lies with the claimant or we do what the Law Reform Commission wanted to do in the first place and that is reverse the onus of proof so that the defendant has to prove it is not so.
