They were the stages we went through: stage 1, no defence at all; stage 2, the reversal of proof where it is up to the defendant to prove that there was no negligence, no fault; and now we are in stage 3 where we are saying again, and properly so, that it is up to the claimant to prove his or her case.

One is guaranteed one's day in court. The law societies and the provision of legal aid ensure that one gets one's day in court. Those are the decisions that have to be made. One does not disrupt, disturb and destroy the legal system to satisfy a personal fetish. It seems to me that the Government Caucus committee, for once, had some sensible things to say.

It looks like the motion before us will be passed. I will be very interested to see what sort of arguments will be put up and whether people will realise that what Senator Tate is really saying is that he wants a system of strict liability but he wants to call it something else.

I agree with the remarks that were made by Senator Alston and Senator Hill. The principle as laid down in Donoghue v. Stevenson, which is basically a question of who is your neighbour, is the one that is applied basically in questions of tort. There are some people who would like to get rid of tort and contract actions forever and replace them with a legislative codified system. Personally, I prefer the common law, which I think serves us well.

When this matter is discussed by the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee I will be most interested to see whether people are honest in saying what it is that they truly want to achieve. In Senator Tate's case, I believe it is strict liability.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—There has been a certain amount of hysteria on the other side. I certainly take offence at being charged by Senator Bishop with being involved in some gratification of a personal fetish in relation to this matter. The fact is that I am simply seeking to put before a Senate committee the sorts of matters that have been the subject of debate this morning. There is no reason why Opposition senators who are members of that committee cannot be persuaded or not persuaded by the sorts of arguments that have been put to us this morning from all sides of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important to state—although Senator Bishop seems to have missed this—that the Senate and, therefore, the Parliament, has already indicated that it believes that the laws of negligence, tort law, common law and contract law, are not adequate and need to be supplemented. The Senate and the Parliament have already agreed that there should be a supplementary product liability regime based on the European directive, which relates to the Italian compensation for injury caused by defective products. Obviously, this applies in the major trading areas of Europe. It seems that this will be applied in the northern Asian countries, which are very formidable trading entities. It will never be adopted in the United States because of the total chaos of that country's legal and political systems in dealing with this matter, to the great detriment of manufacturers and employment—the employment of all but lawyers.

The Government has no intention whatsoever of departing from the major principle of liability in this Bill, which is that the plaintiff should prove all the elements of the situation—the injury, the defect and the causal link—on the balance of probabilities. It is not a subterfuge or some sort of camouflage for a strict liability regime. It is absolutely apparent and utter nonsense to say that it is.

The European directive takes effect within the various European countries according to their own rules of procedure and evidence. In the United Kingdom it is most likely that when cases come to court the United Kingdom courts will apply the European directive, given their understanding of the rules of evidence, such as the res ipsa loquitur principle.

I was simply trying to indicate, not by way of a press release but in the various drafts that were produced early last year, how that principle might be put into statutory terms. In the end, that was deleted from the Bill that was presented to the chamber. I believe that there are some good working drafts that can be considered by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I look forward to the Committee's deliberations on this matter. I hope that they will be fruitful and that they will strike the right balance between the rights of consumers and the need to keep a vibrant manufacturing sector in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will support the passage of the Crimes (Ships and Fixed Platforms) Bill 1992, which will enable Australia to become a party to two international instruments relating to the prevention of maritime terrorism: the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against Maritime Navigation and the Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against Fixed Platforms Located on the Continental Shelf. The convention and the protocol, made in Rome in March 1988, came into force on 1 March this year. This Bill will make the changes to our domestic law necessary for Australia to become a party to them.

PARA.TAB: There is, of course, Commonwealth and State legislation in place relating to crimes at sea, which in effect means that the criminal law of a State will apply to an act committed at sea, provided that the offender, the ship or the territory in which the act was committed has some connection with the State. There is, however, no legislation specifically dealing with crimes on fixed platforms.

In essence, this Bill creates offences as required by the convention and the protocol in relation to acts likely to endanger the safe navigation of a ship or the safety of an ocean drilling platform. Division 1 of part 2 of the Bill creates offences relating to ships, as required by the convention. These offences include several for which the maximum penalty is life imprisonment, such as hijacking a private ship, destroying a ship, or causing damage to a ship or its cargo knowing that it is likely to endanger the safe navigation of a ship.

A number of other offences have a maximum penalty of 15 years imprisonment. Such offences include performing an act of violence against a person on board a private ship where the offender knows that the act is likely to endanger the safe navigation of the ship; placing destructive devices on a ship; destroying or damaging navigational facilities; and knowingly endangering the safe navigation of a ship by communicating false information. Causing death or injury to a person in connection with the commission of any of these offences is also an offence, as is threatening to endanger a ship.

Clause 18 of the Bill sets out the circumstances in which this Act will apply. It will not apply to purely domestic offences; there must be an international element. The basic rule is that proceedings must not be commenced unless the ship is on an international voyage or in the territorial sea of a foreign country at the time the alleged offence is committed.

The alleged offence must also have an Australian element or a convention state element. `Australian element' is defined in subclause 18(3) as being where the ship is Australian or the alleged offender is Australian. `Convention state element' is defined as being where the ship is flying the flag of the convention state or is in the territorial waters of a convention state; where the alleged offender is a national of a convention state or where a national of the convention state was seized, threatened, injured or killed during the commission of the alleged offence.

Division 2 of part 2 of the Bill sets out the powers of a ship's master. They include the power to arrest and hold in custody any person whom they reasonably believe to have committed an offence under division 1, and to deliver that person to the appropriate authorities of any convention state.

Part 3 of the Bill provides for a similar range of offences in relation to fixed platforms as required by the protocol. For the purposes of this Bill the fixed platform must be outside the Australian territorial sea and there must also be an Australian or a protocol state element. Such an element would be present if the platform is on the Australian continental shelf, or the offender is an Australian, or another state party to the protocol would have jurisdiction under the protocol. Pursuant to Clause 30 of the Bill, the written consent of the Attorney-General is required for the prosecution of an offence.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as I noted earlier, the coalition will support the passage of this Bill. In fact, there is only one specific matter that I want to draw to the Minister's attention. That concerns the drafting of clause 12 of the Bill which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: A person must not destroy or seriously damage maritime navigational facilities or seriously interfere with their operation if that act is likely to endanger the safe navigation of a private ship.

Other clauses which provide for offences, such as clause 9 which prohibits the performing of acts of violence against a person on board a private ship, and clause 10 which prohibits the causing of damage to a private ship or its cargo, require that the offender knows that it is likely to endanger the safe navigation of the ship. Therefore, it seems that there is some discrepancy between these provisions in terms of the knowledge requirement. The Minister might like to address that apparent inconsistency when he responds in this debate.

PARA.TAB: Apart from that minor point, I stress again the coalition's support for the Bill. We share the concerns expressed in the preamble to the convention about:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the world-wide escalation of acts of terrorism in all its forms, which endanger or take innocent human lives, jeopardize fundamental freedoms and seriously impair the dignity of human beings.

We support the convention and the protocol and, therefore, this Bill as a means of furthering international efforts to prevent terrorism and ensuring the prosecution and punishment of the perpetrators of terrorist acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Crimes (Ships and Fixed Platforms) Bill 1992. The purpose of this Bill is to introduce a number of offences in relation to ships and fixed platforms which will fill an important gap which now exists in the present international regime to prevent and suppress maritime terrorism. It provides legal redress to nations affected by incidents such as the October 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro, a matter to which I shall return shortly.

PARA.TAB: Given the international importance of this legislation, the Australian Democrats will support this Bill. The legislation will enable Australia to become a party to the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against Maritime Navigation and the Protocol for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against Fixed Platforms, both of which were drafted in Rome in March 1988. Both the convention and the protocol were drafted as a direct response to the hijacking incident which highlighted various uncertainties about the legal position of the parties involved.

Here there was a ship under an Italian flag, a hijacking which took place in Egyptian waters and the murdered victim was a United States citizen. In addition, there were several conventions dealing with specific acts of terrorism such as The Hague Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Seizure of Aircraft and the convention against the taking of hostages. However, there was no convention dealing with maritime terrorism.
The main provisions of the Bill—all of which carry the maximum penalty of life imprisonment—are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . without lawful excuse, take possession of, or take or exercise control over, a private ship. . . a fixed platform by the threat or use of force or any other kind of intimidation.
. . . without lawful excuse, destroy a private ship. . . cause damage to a private ship or its cargo knowing that it is likely to endanger the safe navigation of the ship.

I note the point that Senator Hill has raised and look forward to the Minister's comment on the discrepancy in the provisions relating to whether the act must be knowingly undertaken. The Bill goes on to refer to the placing of destructive devices on a ship or platform and, without lawful excuse, destroying a fixed platform or causing damage to a fixed platform knowing that it is likely to endanger its safety.

PARA.TAB: This Bill, unless the contrary intention appears, will have extraterritorial application to acts, matters and things outside Australia and to persons, whatever their nationality or citizenship. This will assist with extradition and prosecution of offences, and will overcome any legal hurdles such as the world was faced with in previous incidents.This Bill will not exclude or limit the operation of Commonwealth, State or territory laws except by the sections relating to aiding, abetting and attempting under the Commonwealth Crimes Act which will not apply to the provisions in this Bill relating to acts of blackmail.

I also welcome this Bill in my capacity as Democrat spokesperson on defence. The Bill is an example of international cooperation in the face of armed terrorism at a time when the world is striving towards an orderly and cooperative resolution of conflicts and, in particular, striving to stop aggression and wars where they occur through concerted international action rather than unilateral use of force. The Australian Democrats will support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Crimes (Ships and Fixed Platforms) Bill 1992 arises out of an incident which will be well known to honourable senators, the so-called Achille Lauro incident. The Senate will remember that in October 1985, Palestine Liberation Front terrorists took command of the Achille Lauro, an Italian cruise ship, 10 nautical miles from the coast of Egypt. They held the ship's crew and passengers hostage and threatened to kill the passengers unless Israel released 50 Palestinian prisoners.

PARA.TAB: On 8 October 1985, when their demands were not met, the hijackers shot and killed a person of United States nationality. On 9 October 1985, the Egyptian Government granted the hijackers safe passage in return for the surrender of the passengers. There is no evidence, of course, that the Egyptian Government knew of the killing at that time. Subsequently, the US intercepted the Egyptian plane carrying the hijackers and forced it to land at a NATO air base in Sicily. Italy prosecuted most of the hostage takers, but allowed the head of the hostage takers to depart to Yugoslavia and tried him in absentia. That outcome was in part due to uncertainties about the legal position of the parties involved.

The Achille Lauro was a ship under an Italian flag, the hijacking took place in Egyptian waters and the murdered victim was a United States citizen. There was a very murky problem so far as international law and dealing with this particular atrocious act of terrorism was concerned. The world community, therefore, decided to promulgate a convention and a protocol dealing with the suppression of such unlawful acts of violence against shipping and certain fixed platforms, and the Bill before the Senate incorporates those particular principles into Australian law.

I believe that the Senate—including both the Opposition and the Democrats—has indicated its support for the Bill. Of course, one would expect that view because of its concern to suppress, and deal with if suppression does not occur, acts of terrorism, particularly those which might occur in the sorts of circumstances which I have outlined. Even less dramatic incidents have to be guarded against, of course, and if they occur there has to be a legal regime which allows for the trial, conviction and imprisonment of those who have offended. This Bill provides for that.

Senator Hill and Senator Spindler raised a particular matter which, on the face of it, does require some explanation. It appears that in division 1 of part 2 of the Crimes (Ships and Fixed Platforms) Bill before us, in relation to acts of violence or the offence dealing with destroying or damaging a ship, the offence requires not only that an act be undertaken which is an act of violence against a person on board a private ship, for example, but also that it has to be undertaken in the knowledge that the act is likely to endanger the safe navigation of the ship.

That extra element is obviously put in so that this particular Act is not used to deal with what might be called simple assault in a dispute in the dining room or over cards on board the cruise liners. It has to be an act of violence which has that extra element that it is undertaken with the knowledge that it is likely to endanger the safe navigation of the ship. The same applies to causing damage to a private ship or its cargo.

In relation to destroying or damaging navigation facilities, it could be argued that simply to damage a maritime navigation facility or seriously to interfere with its operation carries the necessary inference that it will indeed endanger the safe navigation of a private ship, and the need to show an extra element of knowledge in the person accused is not required in that it is obviously a serious offence in itself to destroy or seriously damage maritime navigation facilities or seriously interfere with their operation.

The court has to ask itself whether indeed that activity would be likely to endanger the safe navigation of a private ship and the prosecution would have to indicate that that would be the case. But it is not thought by the drafters, apparently, that it is necessary for the prosecution to prove that extra element of knowledge in the accused. Nevertheless, I take the point raised by honourable senators, and, looking at the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Against the Safety of Maritime Navigation in schedule 1 to the Bill, I note that article 3 on page 13 of the Bill is headed:
Any person commits an offence if that person unlawfully and intentionally:—

SPEECH.PARA: amongst other things—

PARA.TAB: (d) destroys or seriously damages maritime navigational facilities or seriously interferes with their operation, if any such act is likely to endanger the safe navigation of a ship;

SPEECH.PARA: Whether that just means obviously acting with mens rea and in full possession of one's faculties or whether it requires a demonstration of that extra knowledge that is a feature of the elements of the offences in clauses 9 and 10 is a matter for further reflection. I suggest to the Senate it would be appropriate—and I am certainly proposing this—that the Bill be passed in its present form. If, on reflection on the matters raised by Senator Hill and Senator Spindler after the passage of this matter through the Senate and before it is considered in the House of Representatives, a further amendment is required, then I obviously give an undertaking that that will be done.

PARA.TAB: I have asked the adviser whether in fact there is any comment by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on this particular matter. I am advised that there is no comment that we are aware of. That is where this sort of thing is normally picked up if there is thought to be a problem, but it does not mean it is the only way in which it is picked up. Individual senators, of course, are right to raise a matter relating to knowledge in relation to the elements of an offence. Therefore, I give an undertaking that it will be looked at between this place and the other place and, if needs be, it will be dealt with there. But I commend this most important Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill 1992 facilitates the increase of the research and development levy from 10c to 15c maximum a tonne. The sugarcane levy was introduced in 1987 and has in the past been poorly supported, with growers providing only 6c a tonne, or about 0.17 per cent of annual gross value of production. We can compare this figure with that paid by other primary producers, such as meat and wool producers and wheat and oilseed growers, all of whom contribute 0.5 per cent. Cane growers have recognised that they want to increase the amount they pay by 8c a tonne to 14c a tonne.

PARA.TAB: The Government also provides primary industries with a dollar for dollar research and development grant up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. The purpose of the levy is to provide a matching grant with the industry dollar for dollar, which the Government has also subsidised. Currently the maximum rate is 10c per tonne of cane, and this piece of legislation will increase the maximum rate to 15c per tonne.

The request for this amendment has come from the Australian Cane Growers Council, the Australian Cane Farmers Association and the Australian Sugar Milling Council. The funds raised through this levy support the activities of the Sugar Research and Development Corporation. The Commonwealth is committed to matching the Sugar Research and Development Corporation expenditure dollar for dollar, up to a limit of 0.5 per cent of gross value of production of sugarcane. The current 15c per tonne represents 0.29 per cent of the gross value of production, which is less than the 0.5 per cent limit which the Government will match. The Government estimates that its contribution for 1992-93 will be $3.15m.

The importance of research and development cannot be overstated. Australian farmers are recognised throughout the world as leaders in efficiency and productivity. I have no doubt that there are lessons the sugar farmers could teach the manufacturing sector. The major productivity gains have been achieved through the purchase of modern machinery and improved agricultural techniques. Approximately 95 per cent of total Australian sugar production is based in Queensland. A further 5 per cent is produced in northern New South Wales.

As a result of widespread drought, the Australian cane harvest in 1991-92 was 23.1 million tonnes, the lowest harvest since 1979-80 and a fall of 15 per cent on the 1990-91 harvest. Sugar production fell by 400,000 tonnes from the 1991 harvest to 3.1 million tonnes. The value of sugar sales from the 1991-92 Australian crop declined by $255m to $949m. These figures reflect the severe plight of many sugarcane farmers right across the entire industry in Australia.

The cane harvesting process has evolved from the days of cutting cane by hand to the mechanically driven machines operating today. To a certain extent, productivity gains in these areas have come as far as they are likely to in the near future. However, the Australian cane industry must not stop research to improve its product. Australia must maintain the competitive edge that distinguishes our product from the products of other countries. The way in which we achieve this competitive edge is through research and development.

Much of this progress lies in genetic engineering, improved plant varieties, better sugar content, resistance to disease, resistance to drought and more efficient utilisation of water and soil nutrition, all of which add to greater efficiency gain. The coalition supports this Bill and commends the industry for taking measures to increase its contribution to the research of sugar.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this particular move, and agreeing with most of the remarks of Senator Tambling on the Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill 1992, I would like to say that it is quite all right to raise the maximum level of the levy that is collectable by growers from themselves, in essence.

PARA.TAB: The industry has been described as being fully supportive of this move.I think I was rightly sceptical of this Government's claim, following some recent experiences we have had in this Parliament with such things as the proposed deer levy and the proposal for a cattle transaction levy. At the time, both levies were described as having full industry support and we were assured that they were proposed with full industry support. But in those cases, as most honourable senators would know, we were later able to see that there was some doubt about the degree to which those who purported to represent the industry actually represented the industry. Although the levies proceeded, they have proceeded with not a little dissension from within the industries.

In this case, however, I am convinced that the industry's representative bodies do, in fact, accurately represent the industry viewpoint. Only a few minutes ago, I received further confirmation of that directly from one of the representative bodies. What I am not convinced about—and interested participants in the rural debate will share my scepticism—is this Government's commitment to maintaining the dollar for dollar support of research and development.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot be blamed for that.

—I agree with Senator Boswell that I can hardly be blamed for having such a scepticism, because the recent rumours about possible changes to this ratio were alarming. Thankfully, the ratio for Commonwealth support was not changed, but the alarm bells have been rung and I maintain a scepticism as to how long that will last.

PARA.TAB: I also believe that more Federal Government support could be forthcoming for those developments which arise from research projects. Senator Tambling quite rightly listed the sorts of developments and the sorts of initiatives that bring a competitive edge to much of Australian agriculture as a result of research. But it is not just a matter of developing a particular variety, or a particular harvesting technique, or a particular farming practice, or even a particular manufacturing process and then just leaving it at that, having developed it.

It is crucial that government support be given so that those developments can actually be implemented. That is the secret as to whether we become a more efficient industry and a more efficient and effective country. The research projects may well identify certain techniques but it is the implementation of those techniques which makes us competitive.

I wish to take a couple of minutes to speak about improving the environmental sustainability of the sugar industry. Many recent initiatives are worthy of direct financial support by the community through its government. We know of wonderful advances that have been made in a range of potential uses for bagasse, including its further development. For many years it has been used in various ways as a building material. There have been developments in its usage as a building material, as fuel, as an insulation material, and as fibre for paper. The Democrats believe that any step taken by processors to take advantage of these new uses should be encouraged and rewarded by government instead of the processors being left to speak for themselves.

Similarly—and this is a matter I have taken up since I came to this place—we should consider the use of alcohol as an alternative fuel for vehicles. Queensland canegrowers and the RACT have done a great amount of work over many years to demonstrate that it is technically and physically possible to do this. Many months ago I was fortunate enough to be a guest at a demonstration by the RACT and the Queensland canegrowers of the technical feasibility of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many times are we going to hear about this?

—If honourable senators will be patient, I might conclude my pontification on this, if it can be described as that; it is a favourite topic of mine. Recently I was fortunate enough to be a member of a parliamentary delegation to Brazil, where the many advantages of using alcohol as an alternative fuel for vehicles were demonstrated. They are obvious to anybody who travels to that place. Those advantages include reduced pollution, mechanical advantages, internal employment prospects, reduced reliance on overseas suppliers of petroleum, and the obvious foreign exchange benefits.

PARA.TAB: In the intangible region, the area where it is not directly calculable but is immediately apparent to anyone who watches, having established the industry, the country as a whole and the industry in particular benefit from the increased flexibility of market opportunities, so that some of the worst excesses of the single-selling opportunity are reduced. Even further, farmers have benefited from further technological advantages. A good example of that was seen outside a research station near Brasilia. I saw a small, low cost, low scale, self-contained distillation plant which was able to use 11 hectares of sugarcane to provide all the fuel needs of an extensive mixed cropping and grazing property.

We cannot get to that stage in Australia, even though we know it is technically feasible, because of the lack of government support, whether it be on the excise side or on the strictly legal side—whether one can have a still on one's own property. With those limitations, we have not been able to take advantage of the considerable advantages to both marketing and technology that derive from using alcohol as an alternative fuel.

For the benefit of those who are becoming a little impatient with my going on about that subject, I conclude with the observation that the simple and, in my opinion, misguided calculation of whether a fuel alcohol industry will be profitable, based on a simplistic comparison of the cost of oil-based fuels with the cost of production of fuel alcohol, is inadequate to provide our sugar industry with this other option. The significant community benefits must be recognised by the Government to justify government support for this initiative that the industry has been able to identify through research and should be empowered to initiate through further government support. That to me is justification for making my earlier claim that it is just not a case of encouraging the industry to levy itself to pay for further research. Rather, we are in need of a demonstration by government that support will be given for developments that are identified by that very research.

In supporting this levy, I do so with the knowledge that it is unlike a couple of past levies where it had been a bit iffy about whether they had their industries' support. On this occasion I am convinced that there is industry support. I am just a little sceptical of the Government's level of matching the self-raised funds. Again, we can only be confident about what we can see in writing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill 1992, which amends the Sugar Cane Levy Act by increasing the maximum of the levy paid by the sugarcane farmers and millers. I am very glad to see Senator Button here, because I believe that he needs all the help he can get on rural and primary industry matters. The increase in the levy was made at the request of the industry, which wished to see the maximum limit lifted to 15c a tonne so that a contribution of 5 per cent of the gross product value could be reached. This levy funds the activities of the new Sugar Research and Development Corporation, which last year spent $3.6m on sugar research and development.

PARA.TAB: Research and development is not a recent arrival to the sugar industry. Investment in research and development has played a major role in making the Australian raw sugar industry one of the most efficient sugar industries in the world—world leaders in crop production, harvesting, transport and marketing—and a major contributor to Australia's export earnings, on average around $1 billion a year. The levy proposed by this Bill is part of the Commonwealth Government's program to fund the Sugar Research and Development Corporation on the basis of industry-government dollar for dollar funding up to the value of 5 per cent of the gross value of production.

In 1991-92, the maximum levy represented 29 per cent of the GDP. This year, the contribution will be $3.15m, equivalent to 12.6c a tonne. The new SRDC is funding invaluable research across the range of the industry: planting, harvesting, processing, handling, refining, farm extension work and pure scientific research. The sum of $3.6m was spent this year on research, despite funding of $8.6m being requested.

The importance of research and development is no new phenomenon to the sugar industry. The value of the industry investment in research and development has not been acknowledged all this decade. It is not widely understood in the community that the sugar industry spends in excess of $15m a year on research—about one per cent of the gross value of the industry output. On top of this expenditure, the milling companies also conduct their own research. This is done through three major research organisations and has been going on since 1900. The Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations was established by the industry in that year. It now has an annual budget exceeding $9m, being mainly funded by growers and millers, with the Queensland Government kicking in one-tenth of the total cost. This research body has played a major role in developing cane species, researching and controlling pests, disease and quarantine and developing efficiencies in cane production and sugar milling.

Further to this, the milling industry has its own milling research organisation which has been operating since 1949—the Sugar Research Institute, or, as it is locally called in Mackay, the SRI. Unfortunately, poor seasons and returns have resulted in staff cuts of around 20 per cent, with a loss of valuable and highly skilled scientists. The Sugar Research and Development Corporation is funded by the levy under this Bill.

These three research bodies not only advance the industry and increase the nation's export but also employ skilled scientists and researchers. So it was with absolute shock that I read in the Australian of the Government trying to do some penny pinching by reducing research and development funding to all primary industries by $24m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Senator, you should not engage in scuttlebutt.

—It is not scuttlebutt; it is straight from the horse's mouth. Fortunately, someone in the Government—I expect someone at a very high level—put that story out and caused such an outcry in the primary industries that Senator Button backed out very fast. I commend whoever did it. I have my suspicions about who did it, but I will not go into names. It was a great bit of political play and he ought to be commended.

PARA.TAB: This $24m which the Government wanted to pinch to make its figures look better would be best spent on industries that will lead to real future growth and development in the sugar industry. Senator Button is always telling us how we have to be clever and more competitive and get into high technology research. I do not know who in Cabinet was responsible for the $24m reduction but it was fought off, and for the time being we still have the $24m for research.

Despite drought, flood and low prices through a corrupted world price, the growers and millers have struggled to make, and even increase, their contribution. It is all part of their commitment to research and its benefit to the industry and the national economy. The Government, despite the rhetoric of a `clever country', was prepared to cut funding for all primary industries, our multi-billion dollar export primary industries, in our worst recession in 60 years and one of the worst rural recessions ever in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will finish up with a pimple on your tongue if you go on like this. You don't know; you are just guessing.
—There is one thing I do know—and that is the sugar industry. I live with it continually.
—You know only what you read in the newspapers.

—I would be grateful to hear Senator Button's contribution, but I would welcome his letting me get ahead with mine. Expert assessment shows that research in agricultural production repays dividends far greater than any other investment Australia has ever made. No-one could ever accuse the Australian scientific community of being pampered or featherbedded by this Government when continued funding cuts are being made each year to our research bodies and universities. The Government, in its ignorance, shows its absolute short-sightedness in even thinking about cutting the meagre funding it now provides to research and development in primary industry.

PARA.TAB: The sugar industry is to be applauded for its firm commitment to increase its own funding to research and its financial commitment to the industry in times of distressing hardship in rural Australia—all this at a time when incomes have been reduced by 20 per cent. However, now that the community outcry has forced the Government not to deny rural industries $24m for rural research and development, it does not mean that we can sit back in the traces and expect research never to be threatened again.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not have to remind you that the world sugar industry is the most corrupt of any agricultural industry. All major sugar producing countries provide price support for their producers, who all get some sort of guaranteed minimum price. All Australian producers are exposed to the world price, currently around 10c a pound. In the US the producer is guaranteed a market price of 26c a pound or $357 a tonne. In the European Community the guaranteed price is $551 a tonne and in Thailand it is around $447 a tonne.

By comparison, the Australian producer, exporting 80 per cent of his crop, received around $300 a tonne last year, which was well below the cost of production. The industry has also had to accept the imposition by the United States of quotas on sugar imports. Australian imports went from 800,000 tonnes before quotas were imposed in 1981 to 109,000 tonnes this year. Last year they were reduced further, resulting in a yearly loss of $18m, or $1,400 to $1,500 a tonne per farmer.

Queensland produces 95 per cent of the national output while New South Wales produces 5 per cent of the total crop and, in turn, supplies 20 per cent of the domestic market. In both States the industry has introduced many reforms and efficiencies. Efficiencies have been gained through mill mergers, an automatic expansion rate of 5 per cent, and the adoption of practices such as trash blanketing, green harvesting and minimum tillage. Marketing practices, which are also receiving much promotion, are of great sophistication.

Our high quality Australian product is in enormous demand from international customers. They will buy only at world prices. Yet the Industry Commission, in its wisdom, has recommended that the Australian industry be totally deregulated. It has recommended that sugar communities from Mossman in Queensland to Maclean in New South Wales become guineapigs in its experiment in economic theory. I say to Senator Button, `When something is going well, don't fix it if it ain't broken'.

According to the IC, untold expansion of the industry will occur and Australia will suddenly earn an extra $500 billion in sugar export earnings. I would like to meet the farmer who is going to go into the sugar industry and lose money just because he can get an assignment. Senator Macdonald will back me up in that statement. There are already 48,000 hectares of land out there on which sugarcane can be grown but no-one is silly enough to take it up. People know that, if they do, they will end up in very serious financial circumstances.

The IC even tells us that the environment will benefit. I do not know how it reaches that conclusion. The findings from the IC inquiry are that the main inefficiencies in the industry today are caused by production and marketing controls, yet past expansions in the industry have not been taken up. Presently, 48,000 hectares of cane assignment land are available for canegrowing, but who would sink money into buying, clearing and preparing the land, and paying outrageously high State water charges, to produce a crop that is sold at a price below the cost of production? Only the people in the IC down here in Canberra who have solved the economic problems of the world, the officers on $80,000 a year, would do that. If Senator Button has any say in it or can give directions to these people, I suggest that he gets them to spend two weeks on a sugarcane farm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you really ought to stop all this populist stuff and give us a bit of a think piece about the industry, instead of sloganeering.

—It might be comfortable for Senator Button to sit there and take cheap shots at me across the chamber, but let me assure him that there is great hardship out there in the sugar industry and one of the main reasons for it is that the world price has been depressed so much by overproduction caused by massive subsidies. World agricultural subsidies are $412 billion a year, and a large amount of that goes to the sugar industry. How can our farmers compete with the boost that overseas production receives?

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission recommends doing away with the acquisition and vesting in the Sugar Corporation—that is, getting rid of one-desk selling. I am very glad to say that it is the policy of the National Party and the Liberal Party on the wheat industry that we are going to stick like glue to the one-desk selling in that industry. While this is a State issue, I am sure that we will give the same support to one-desk selling in the sugar industry as we will in the wheat industry.

It also wants to get away with getting rid of the Sugar Corporation's acquisitional powers except where there are long term contracts, some of which will expire in 1997. Yet effectively every single country purchasing Australian sugar has a single-desk buyer. What would be gained by many Australian sellers being picked off by the might of the overseas single-desk buyers? Even Senator Walsh would support that argument, being a wheat grower. By his silence, I know he supports it.

The IC recommended a one-off payment of $47m to farmers and millers to get rid of any tariffs in 1992 provided the Queensland Government deregulates the rest of the industry, or alternatively, tariffs reducing each year to reach zero in 1998. The IC has a further recommendation to sell off the sugar terminals that have been paid for by the farmers through levies. These terminals have provided for the efficiency of bulk handling and have been paid for by the industry through reductions in sugar price returns year by year.

This pie in the sky stuff from the IC is not really in touch with the real world. The sugar industry suffers from high input costs; from fuel excise; from high labour on-costs such as superannuation and training levies; and from our shipping system, which excludes foreign flag ships at an annual cost to the average canegrower of $437 a tonne from extra freight costs. Any development of refined sugar exports would see massive costs from high containerisation and wharf costs. These are the inefficiencies borne by the industry which the IC, Senator Button and his Government should be looking at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, really!

—Really, the honourable senator has not looked at this labour reform. He has done everything else. He has certainly looked at it and said, `Hey, the ACTU won't like this. This is too tough. Shove this one in the too-hard basket. We are not going to go out and upset the non-parliamentary faction of the Labor Party'.

PARA.TAB: The IC should look at those inefficiencies, not practices that the industry itself has under control and is deregulating at a sensible pace. They should leave the marketing system alone because it works. The benefit to coastal Queensland and northern New South Wales—and, in fact, the entire nation—from the sugar industry is enormous. To go the way of the IC would be to destroy the very foundation of northern Australia.

I support this Bill, and I acknowledge that the levy is being raised at the industry's request. In doing so, I applaud the contribution that the sugar industry, since its inception, has made to the Australian economy. I also applaud the participants in the industry for their big-heartedness, foresight and vision in their continuing commitment to industry research and development. Without this commitment over this entire century the Australian sugar industry would not be the efficient, internationally competitive industry it is today. To remove research funding, as the Government seriously proposed, would be to send our primary industries back to the Dark Ages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are talking about sugar again, and for the first time in over two years we find the Government doing something that the sugar industry has asked it to do. I suppose that is a welcome relief, given the sorts of things that we have seen this Government doing to the sugar industry over the last two years. The wholesale attack that it has embarked on against the sugar industry is thoroughly reprehensible. Senator Button can sit over there and joke—
—They are a wake-up to you up there.

—We all know that Senator Button and Jeff Fenech are very similar in one respect—their size—but in every other respect Senator Button has caved in at every challenge. He has not gone in to fight for the sugar industry. He is supposed to be the Minister for Industry. Goodness gracious me!
—What better industry than the sugar industry?

—What better industry, indeed, but Senator Button does not seem to be terribly interested in the sugar industry. He caved in at every opportunity. It shows that Senator Button's interjections are interesting but they are not terribly pertinent.

PARA.TAB: The Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill 1992 is important because it will guarantee some substantial funding for the sugar industry—substantial funding, that is, provided, as my good colleague Senator Boswell has previously said, the Government does not decide to change the way in which it funds research in agricultural industries.

The mere suggestion that this Government might cut back the funding from 50 per cent to 40 per cent sent shock waves through all of Australian primary industry, and for good reason: the government funding of research in primary industry in this country is one of the few areas where the Government has given some support to the development of primary industry. In so many other areas—in the sugar industry and elsewhere—we have seen this Government, year after year, tirelessly attacking primary producers. The effects of the drought which is currently being experienced in Queensland and New South Wales were always going to be bad, but would never have been as bad as they are now, were it not for the fact that this Government destroyed the income equalisation deposit scheme, took drought relief off the natural disaster arrangements and has effectively hamstrung—

TALK.START.PARA: —People were rorting it.

—I welcome Senator Walsh's interjection! Perhaps he would kindly tell me how many people were prosecuted for rorting it. Silence. None. Senator Walsh should hang his head in shame for badmouthing the primary industries of this country. He ran around with his mates Mr Courtice and Mr Wright—Mr Wrong—and he badmouthed primary industry in this country. When he was asked to stump up and prosecute one single person, of course the silence was stunning. Now we see Senator Walsh where he ought to be, on the back bench, because his contribution to primary industry when he was in Cabinet was thoroughly pathetic.

PARA.TAB: We have seen this Government, time after time after time, attack primary industry in this nation. Is it any surprise that, when a drought does come along, we see the pathetic spectacle of proud people, proud farm families, having to struggle to survive because of the evil things that this Government has done to primary industry over the last nine years?

When we talk about drought, it is also a topic that is relevant to the sugar industry. Some people think that, because the sugar industry is on the coast, it does not get droughts. Nothing could be further from the truth. Canegrowers, particularly in the Mackay area, this season have suffered an incredible drought. Mills in areas closer to Cairns, for example, the Mossman central mill, started crushing this year later than they had ever done in their history. Rainfall was insufficient and the growers wanted to give the crop a chance to get a little bit further ahead before they actually had to cut it, because they were concerned about the tonnage and concerned about the CCS they were going to get.

We can do a lot of good work in research, in terms of trying to get a crop which, by virtue of the varieties grown or the practices used, is more resistant to dry weather. This is particularly relevant on the Atherton Tableland where you have the sugar industry—the Mosman Central Mill with the expansion of its mill area—going into old tobacco land, which is irrigated out of the Tinaroo Dam. There is a limit on how much land can be put under cane out of that irrigation area. One of the ways that we can improve the potential area for growing cane is by using, for example, trickle irrigation. This would reduce the amount of water that is necessary. It would also ensure that we can have more hectares and a guaranteed irrigation supply. Those are the sorts of things that we need to be working on. They are also the areas where, hopefully, we will see some improvement through research funding.

But let us make it perfectly clear: this Government cannot be allowed to welsh on funding of research in primary industry. Arguably, funding of research in primary industry, even at one per cent of the total value of an industry, is insufficient. For example, high technology private sector companies frequently put 5 per cent to 10 per cent of their turnover into research. Of course that is not possible now; the returns to farmers are bad enough as they are. Many of the returns are negative returns, as my colleague Senator Boswell knows full well. Any suggestion by the Commonwealth that they might wind back funding is just insufficient.

I also want to touch on the topics which Senator Boswell has touched on, but only very briefly. I, too, wholeheartedly reject—as the National Party wholeheartedly rejects—any suggestion that the tariff on the sugar industry should be abolished in 1993 for the pitiful so-called `compensation' of $46m or $47m.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that per farmer?

—I do not know what it is per farmer, but I do know what it is in comparison with the value of the existing tariff. The $46m or $47m is in fact less than the value of tariff protection at the current rate over a period of 12 months. Only a bureaucrat could suggest that we wipe out the tariff—
—Only someone from the IC.

—That is right, I should be fair. Only somebody from the Industry Commission could suggest that we could wipe out the tariff, which next year will be worth more than $46m or $47m and, instead, give the industry $46m or $47m cash in hand, saying, `Aren't we all good blokes?'. One of the incredible things is that this country, unfortunately, is too frequently run from Canberra. I would love to welcome the recommendations of the Industry Commission report, especially if the members of the Industry Commission were going to tie their incomes for the next 10 years to the income of a canegrower in Queensland or, worse still, to the income of a canegrower in New South Wales. It will not happen.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the people who make the decisions are not the people with a vested interest in the outcome of those decisions. This nation really needs a bit of vested interest. It really needs a bit of decision making, done in conjunction with the industry and with the people on the firing line, instead of the situation we have at the moment where the decisions are made by bureaucrats who have no vested interest and who can walk away after they have wreaked destruction on the industry in question. I am very pleased to say that the National Party in Queensland backs wholeheartedly the existing regulation of the sugar industry and backs wholeheartedly, as the Federal National Party does, the system of single desk selling. If we are to go down the road of abolishing the Sugar Corporation, of abolishing single desk selling on the export market, we will see a couple of thousand cane growing families being pitted against three, four or five bulk commodity trading houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Senator Walsh would not disagree with that.
—That is right.
—I was not paying attention again.

—Senator Walsh is reading the newspaper—the only problem is that it is usually last week's newspaper. There is only one group of people in this nation who posit the suggestion of deregulating single desk selling in the sugar industry and in the wheat industry. That group of people sit on the other side of this chamber. That is why I, like Senator Boswell, am pleased and proud to be a National Party Senator for Queensland. That is also why we will continue, as we have done in the past, to stand up for the sugar industry.

—The sugar industry is Australia's third most valuable export crop; 75 to 80 per cent of the total sugar crop is exported. Production in 1991-92 was 3.2 million tonnes of raw sugar, gained from a crop area of 21.3 million tonnes of sugar cane, with a gross value of production estimated at almost $600m. This Bill that we are discussing today proposes to increase the maximum rate of levy for sugarcane for research and development from its existing 10c per tonne of sugarcane to 15c per tonne of sugar cane. Of course, the Liberal and National parties support those proposals and support the requests from the sugar industry itself, from the canegrowers, from the Australian Cane Farmers Federation and from the millers, to increase that levy to add additional funding to research ways of improving the sugar industry.

PARA.TAB: The Government provides funding to match industry levies up to 0.5 per cent of the annual gross value of production, in line with established policy of encouraging increased rural productivity and profitability through research and the commercialisation of research findings. Although there is a cost to the Commonwealth in this, it is a cost which the Commonwealth can well afford. Over the years the sugar industry has been a major contributor to the wealth of this nation in very many ways, in the export earnings it has gained over very many years and, of course, in the sheer amount of income tax that growers have contributed to this nation over many decades.

There were periods, going back some time now, when the sugar industry was very buoyant, when there were enormous amounts of money even coming out of the community that I live in—the Ayr, Home Hill and lower Burdekin area of the State of Queensland—where arguably the best sugar production in Australia takes place. So whilst there is a cost to the Commonwealth, it is a cost which the industry has paid for many times over in the financial benefit that the sugar industry has brought to this nation over many years.

The sugar industry is committed to funded research and wishes to increase the commitment to the Commonwealth scheme through an increased levy in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position. The sugar industry is one that has a very long history of research and development, research and development that principally has been funded by the industry itself. I know that in the town I live in, in the lower Burdekin area, the Bureau of Sugar Experiments Stations has over many years done a lot of quite magnificent research into the sugar industry. That research, of course, has now put the sugar industry in the pre-eminent position that it is in as one of the most efficient, most technologically advanced industries, certainly in the sugar industry world, but in the area of rural crops altogether.

As well as the Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, which does a lot of good work in the many different sugar areas of Queensland, there is the Sugar Research Institute based in Mackay. It is another organisation which has done an enormous amount of very good, very technical, very beneficial research work over many years. This funding is going to the Sugar Research and Development Corporation. It will continue that sort of investment in research which will continue to keep the sugar industry in the position it is in.

Over the years the sugar industry has looked at new varieties of sugarcane, quite different varieties that suit different areas, that suit different growing seasons, that get different types of sugar for different types of purposes. The industry has generally researched different growing regimes, pest control, fertilising and harvesting techniques. All those sorts of things have benefited enormously from the research that has gone into the sugar industry in past years.

I was a little concerned when my colleague Senator Bell from the Australian Democrats started talking about the sugar industry. As we all know, the Democrats want to increase the cost of fuel to farmers. They have all sorts of weird and wonderful ideas about most things in life, and when he started talking about sugar I thought he was going to say that we should ban firing sugarcane paddocks because it interferes with the ozone layer. But he did not quite get on to that ridiculousness, although I have heard it before.

The Lower Burdekin is a little different in that we still have such heavy tonnages of cane and the harvesting machines are unable to cope with them without the cane being burnt. The cane paddocks are set alight in every crushing season, which is just about now, and for a very short period the trash is burnt away from the cane stills, making it much easier to harvest.

These ridiculous radical greenies have been running around saying, `That should not happen; it interferes with the ozone layer'. Of course, as I always say, more damage to the ozone layer would be done by a few of those potbellied stoves in the cold Tasmanian climate than would ever be done by what might happen from the sugarcane—

TALK.START.PARA: —Potbellied Greenies.

—Yes, indeed, Senator Button. Fortunately, that has not come into this debate at this stage, but it is, of course, something that, if it is ever raised, should be treated with the mirth that it deserves.

PARA.TAB: I have an optimism for the sugar industry. There is a lot of expansion going on in the Herbert River and Burdekin areas of Queensland. The Burdekin Dam—an initiative of previous Liberal governments—has eventually been constructed and opened, and it has now opened up vast areas of land for the economical production of sugarcane in the future. Whilst there has been, as Senator Boswell said, some recent hesitation in the acquisition for the production of sugar of those blocks of land that are watered by the Burdekin Dam network, I confidently believe that in the years ahead the Lower Burdekin area and, in particular, the Herbert River area based on Ingham will become increasingly important as major producers of this very great export commodity we have in sugarcane.

The other very important area, of course, in sugarcane growing at present is the Mackay region. That area is suffering enormously from drought, and there is need for a Burdekin Dam type proposal to quarantine the Mackay region against those sorts of droughts in the future.

The industry continues to look at ways of improving its product. There was recently a trial at the Kalamia Sugar mill in Ayr whereby raw sugar was refined at the end of the mill. It was a very new technique—one that is still shrouded in much secrecy, I must say. If it comes to fruition and sugar mills around the State can be used to produce refined sugar at the end of their production run, that will be an enormous breakthrough and step forward for the sugar industry in Queensland. It is something on which a lot of research is still being done, and will continue to be done, by the sugar mills involved.

There is also a lot of excitement in the sugar industry over the announcement by the Mackay Sugar Cooperative of a new refined sugar establishment in the Mackay area. Of course, we are expecting an announcement by CSR very shortly on the establishment of a major sugar refinery in the Townsville-Herbert River-Burdekin region of Queensland. That announcement, I understand, whether it is to be positive or negative, is due very shortly.

The proposals that the Liberal and National parties have in their Fightback package for the sugar industry, and for all industries in Australia, are enormous. The slashing of costs will be of major benefit to the sugar industry. The National Farmers Federation's assessment of the effect of Fightback on rural production generally is very positive, as it must be when all of those costs that governments presently impose upon our export industries are removed. Of course, there are assessments that are in the area of between $6,000 and $9,000 of savings—

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the clear indications last night by the Treasurer that, in addition to the increased taxes that he announced for 1992-93, further tax increases are in the pipeline in a couple of years time. Can the Minister advise the Senate which existing taxes will be increased, whether new taxes will be introduced, and whether one of these taxes will include a broad-based consumption tax of the type proposed in 1985 by the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister?

—As Senator Short knows, most of that information is available in the Budget Papers. The Budget Papers say nothing about a broad-based consumption tax; nor do we. We are opposed to a broad-based consumption tax. Senator Short might have understood that if he had been listening to what had been taking place in the Senate over the last few months.

PARA.TAB: As the Treasurer has said, if the Budget deficit in 1995-96—and that is, of course, three Budgets out—looks likely to come in at around 1 1/4 per cent of GDP, if necessary the Government would take remedial action to ensure that the actual deficit is smaller than that. That action would not involve new taxes. We are very confident that change to existing taxes, if it became necessary—and we do not believe that it would be—would raise the requisite revenue. Some areas of existing taxes have been identified. Before any steps were taken, if indeed they were necessary—and we do not believe they would be—consultations would take place with relevant parties and design issues would have to be considered.

What we are talking about in terms of reaching that required deficit figure is a possibility of changes to existing taxes to rectify a possible increase in the deficit of about $2 billion. We are not talking about the $27 billion which the GST would impose on the Australian people in terms of increased prices for food and clothing and all of the other commodities which are essential to daily family life, particularly of the poorer families in the Australian community. We are not talking about that sort of figure. We are talking about a possible adjustment to some existing taxes. There will be no new taxes at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It appears from the Minister's quite lame attempt to address my question that he may not be aware, although he should be, of the significant decline in the share of indirect tax revenue to GDP in recent years and the expectation that this will continue in the future. I refer him to Budget Paper No. 1, page 4, point 40. In the light of this and his statement that the Government will not introduce a broad-based consumption tax, can he advise the Senate whether the inevitable increase in taxes will come from slugging business or slugging workers, or slugging both?

—First of all, I am aware of the decline that has taken place in indirect tax revenue over the years. I would have thought that it might be said to be a good thing that that has taken place, when one looks at the overall tax structure of the country. I have said nothing at all about particular changes to existing taxes that might be made if circumstances that we do not believe will arise do arise. If that occurs, there may be changes to existing taxes, which are dealt with in the Budget context. They are there for the honourable senator to see what the proposed changes might be. I have nothing further to add. We are certainly not slugging the workers.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Defence to a report in the last issue of the Sunday Telegraph headed `Gay Sex Quiz Sparks Navy Row', which contains criticism of the Department of Defence for its use of a personnel questionnaire in which recruits are asked to describe any involvement in sexual activity. I ask the Minister whether he can advise the Senate of the existence of such a questionnaire and whether it asks for explicit details such as the names of sexual partners. If so, what is the need for the gathering of such explicit information? Can the Minister guarantee that procedures will be put in place to protect the human rights and privacy of the individuals concerned?

—I am aware of press reports that have questioned the need for security vetting in terms of an aide-memoire once used by the Navy. That aide-memoire contained intrusive questions on sexual relations designed to elicit detailed information on private sexual matters and moral convictions.

PARA.TAB: In July this year—I point out that that was well before any press coverage—the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, wrote to the Chief of Naval Staff to register his strong concern about intrusive questions. Mr Bilney has since been advised by the Director of Defence Security that the aide-memoire is no longer in use. Mr Bilney has directed that appropriate steps be taken to ensure that individual vetting officers are no longer using the offending aide-memoire.

In February this year, Navy passed its security vetting function to the Defence security branch, which is now responsible for the centralised control of single service and civilian vetting. A new consolidated vetting unit was established at that time, and single service procedures were replaced by those already in place with the Defence security branch. The consolidated vetting unit applies a common policy for each of the services and for its civilian employees.

The procedures for all vetting interviews should now conform to the broad guidelines set out in the existing security manual. These guidelines reflect greater respect for individual privacy than suggested by the old aide-memoire. A new aide-memoire for the conduct of vetting interviews is now being prepared by the Defence security branch and will be issued only after consultation with the Privacy Commissioner. Defence will observe contemporary standards of privacy, discretion and sensitivity, at the same time meeting its obligation to check the security background of people entrusted with national secrets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The respected economic commentator Max Walsh has studied the Government's Budget and concluded:

QUESTION.PARA: The budget deficit is $20.9 billion, or 5.1% of GDP. This tops the 4.7% lunacy of 1975/76, before the defeat of the Whitlam Government.
With a Budget of such Whitlamesque proportions after 10 years in office, how can anyone take the Government or its Budget seriously?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad Senator Tierney has picked up the respected economic commentator Max Walsh. He had to stretch into the barrel to pick up Max Walsh, because Max Walsh and one other commentator sought to make this point. No other serious economic commentators have sought to make this point.
—Alan Kohler is pretty serious.
—He was the one to whom I was referring. I said, `No other serious economic commentators have sought to make this point'.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is getting a bit excited. It is into deficit fetishism at the present time. It is getting a bit excited about this issue. We inherited from the Opposition a Budget deficit to GDP of 4.1 per cent. In all its 27 years in government the Opposition made no structural changes to the Australian economy.
—Come on, Louie; try a bit harder.

—Elmer Fudd ought to get back to his think tank. This is a disgusting performance. He has come in here dressed in a red tie. His old man would turn in his grave, if he were dead, if he saw him in here wearing a red tie. It is a disgrace.

PARA.TAB: As I have said before in this chamber, the noise level rises according to the pain. The pain of the facts which I am putting to those opposite is so great that the noise level has risen. Every time unemployment goes up in this country, the Opposition gets excited. Those opposite are the only people in the country who do.

In 27 years in government the Opposition was incapable of producing a Budget surplus in any year. I say to Senator Tierney that in current circumstances an expansionary Budget of the kind we have embarked upon is totally legitimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We never had a deficit such as you have embarked upon.

—Senator Short seems to be so fussed about this issue, but he used to come in here peddling tired economic models from the United Kingdom and the United States. He did that for seven years in this place. Look at the deficit in the United States: it is 4.4 per cent of GDP. Look at the Thatcher inheritance in Great Britain. John Hewson is the Opposition's Mrs Thatcher. It is her model that the whole of the Fightback program is based on. The Thatcher inheritance in Great Britain is 4.2 per cent of GDP. In Canada it is 3.6 per cent. One can go through country after country and make these comparisons. This deficit fetishist Opposition comes in here and finds there is something extraordinarily bad in that in terms of the international economy in which this country now operates.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has said that the deficit should be $7 billion, but those opposite should go out on the stumps and tell people in Australia what the effects of a deficit of that size would be. I am not phased by Max Walsh's gloomy meanderings. He took the whole of yesterday in the think tank to work out what the size of the deficit was. He worked out that it was bigger than any other we have had for some time. That is an exceptional performance. Most economic commentators in this country see the size of the deficit as being reasonable and credible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If we can put aside Senator Button's red herrings for a minute and return to the central focus of this question, given the Government's poor record of predicting Budget deficits last year and the totally discredited and abandoned projections of the One Nation statement this year, why should the people of Australia believe the Government or what it is telling us this time?
—Why don't you retire now while you are still in government?
—I know that is something devoutly to be wished by Senator Macdonald, but I will make my own judgments about that.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—We had a question on forecasting yesterday. It is true that the credibility of forecasting—by governments, by the private sector and by business economists in Australia—has not been good. If Senator Tierney wants an understanding of that, the relative success of forecasting by private sector, government and OECD forecasters in the last few years is all contained in the Budget Papers. One of the reasons that has happened, of course—
—Where do you get your advice—the Geelong Football Club?

—The honourable senator should not get me onto my favourite topic. One of the reasons that has happened is that there has been financial deregulation around the world. The art of forecasting is not as simple as it was in the halcyon days of people like Harold Holt and Menzies when nothing ever happened in the Australian economy.
—They never had the level of unemployment that you have.

—Sure. But Senator Alston should not blow his bags too much about unemployment. He should look at his own forecast in Fightback before he blows his bags too much about unemployment. The honourable senator should not get too excited about that issue. The Opposition just sees the word `unemployment' and thinks, `That helps us to get into government. We ought to dig into that issue; it is very important to us'.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. What is the Government going to do about the practice whereby private patients are given preference over public patients in public hospitals?

—The fact is that under the restructuring of Medicare that was announced last night, a very vital modification and revitalisation of Medicare will take place to change it from being simply concerned with health financing to a truly comprehensive health care program for all Australians. It has been most important to emphasise the role of public hospitals and the capacity of those hospitals to treat public patients.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that some public hospitals have been tempted to take privately insured patients and we intend to create a situation where those who enter public hospitals do so based on absolute clinical need—on clinical assessment and clinical priorities—rather than on whether they happen to have private insurance. That is discriminatory against those ordinary public patients who have their Medicare cover but do not have private medical insurance. To give priority to those with such insurance must be regarded as discriminatory. It must be the case that the health care of Australians will be best advanced by saying that those who can occupy beds in public hospitals are those who have been clinically assessed as having a need to enter the hospital bed in that public hospital.

We will be providing a bonus of $1.23 billion over the next six years to those public hospitals which enter into these agreements—in a cooperative, collaborative agreement with the States and Territories, of course. In this way we will be able to ensure that public hospitals have the capacity to provide hospital treatment to those who are in need of it in the Australian community. This means that those who might be tempted to take out private hospital insurance because of a fear of not being able to get a bed in a public hospital will make the choice to do so as a true choice and not one based on fear of not being able to get a bed. They will be able to get a bed because of the incentives we will be offering to the public hospital system.

It is quite clear that this is a creative policy and one, as I say, which will revitalise the aims of Medicare to enable public hospitals to provide these services whereas, of course, the Opposition would decrease funding for public hospitals, transferring the funds across to subsidise private health insurance premiums. The Opposition recognises that there is a need to do that because the private health insurance premiums under its scheme will be set by the AMA and private hospital associations establishing the costs, and the private health insurance schemes will have to try to reach those excessive costs.

We do not believe in that system. We believe that the taxpayers' funds ought to be directed to the public hospital system, not to the private health insurance funds. I believe that with this emphasis on public hospitals being available for all Australians, not just in a situation where those with private insurance get priority, we will see a fairer system evolve, and that is exactly what all Australians require.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Will the Minister confirm that as many as 20,000 students will lose out as a result of the Government's Budget decision to increase the annual minimum Austudy allowance to $1,000? Secondly, will the Minister justify the rule change so that students will be eligible for the Austudy independent rate from the date they turn 24 instead of at the beginning of the year of turning 24, which discriminates against students born in the later part of the year, as the Minister, born in November, would appreciate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm that my star sign is Scorpio; that is true. Eight thousand tertiary students will cease to receive Austudy grants because of the increase in the minimum payment, and an additional 30,000 secondary students will also cease to receive the benefit. The minimum payment has been increased because, as concluded by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, small Austudy payments have little or no influence on individuals' decisions to participate in education and training, which is, after all, the purpose of Austudy.Tertiary students affected by this decision, along with others currently unable to receive Austudy because of parental incomes up to $50,000, will be eligible to receive a supplement of up to $2,000, repayable as per the other Austudy loan arrangements announced last night.

PARA.TAB: The age of independence has been reduced from the beginning of the year in which the student turns 25, at present, to the time at which the student turns 24 in 1993. This age progressively falls to 23 in 1994 and 22 in 1995. This puts the age of independence at one end of the scale on the same basis as the age of eligibility—16 years—at the other end. It represents a reduction for all. It is difficult to see how this can be portrayed, as it has in this question, as discrimination.

The other major improvements to Austudy announced in the Budget are: an increase in the personal income threshold from $5,000, at present, to $6,000 next year; further, legislative entrenchment of the CPI indexation for Austudy payments; and the loan supplement under which tertiary Austudy recipients can trade in up to $2,000 of their grant for a loan of double that amount at zero real interest rate, repayable after five years through the tax system once the student reaches average weekly earnings.

The total number—and I think this is the critical comment I can make in answer to this question—of Austudy beneficiaries is expected to increase by around 52,000 next year. Some 45,000 of this increase reflects the expansion in coverage of tertiary students resulting from the decisions that were announced in the Budget last night.
