TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for confirming that some 38,000 students will now no longer receive an Austudy benefit. Does the Minister agree that a student born in November would stand to lose $5,187 per annum, which represents approximately 85 per cent of the annual entitlement based on the average independent Austudy rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —So that my remarks are not misunderstood, the House of Representatives Committee concluded that the receipt of Austudy was not a matter that caused that group of students to want to go to university. That was the finding of the House of Representatives study.

PARA.TAB: Coming back to Senator Sowada's real supplementary question and not her observation, what she has to appreciate is that the total number of beneficiaries will increase and the age of independence will fall. The age of independence would have fallen further if we had chosen to operate it from the beginning of the school year and not from the day of the birthday. Nonetheless, all those people do get a benefit. Putting it in terms of loss, it is only a loss against the benchmark that would have been had we stuck to the beginning of the school year date. That is the theoretical proposition. To put it in real terms, it is an improvement for all those people.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Expansion of Labour Market and Training Programs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is it a fact that a fundamental element of yesterday's Budget is its expansion of labour market and training programs? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what impact these programs will have on prospects for improving the workplace skills of all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is that 800,000 new jobs will be created over four years as a consequence of this Budget. Unemployment will be around 10 per cent at the end of 1992-93, and at this time next year it will be below that figure. Spending of $1.2 billion on the employment package is a significant stimulus to job creation around Australia for meaningful work in jobs that will add to the value of assets in the community, particularly in regional Australia. This is, of course, on top of the moneys made available through the One Nation statement and the youth statement.

PARA.TAB: This is a Budget whose focus is jobs and more jobs. This is a Budget that achieves that objective by focusing on where unemployment is worst in Australia by region. It enables what local government has told this Government it is able to institute; that is, a program of capital works expansion in their regions, ready to go immediately. So the grants that come out to those regions will have a real and immediate effect of putting people into employment; they will add to the facilities and the community services within those regions; and they will stimulate in particular small business, which will be the major beneficiary of the contracts that will be let and of the employment generated in those areas too.

In addition, in this Budget we have targeted the long term unemployed. We in this chamber have debated often the issues of youth unemployment. In one of those debates I went on the record as saying that no-one wishes to diminish the problems of the young unemployed, but that the group in the community which is worst affected is the older long term unemployed. This Budget directs its attention at their real need and deals with that by improving their access to further training, making their skills relevant to modern needs, and to the provision of employment subsidies to encourage employers to pick up people at that rate.
In answer to Senator McKiernan, this is a Budget that does concentrate on job improvement and—

TALK.START.PARA: —A 10 per cent improvement at the end of it.

—I heard Senator Kemp interjecting when Senator Button was talking about the deficit. The Opposition's proposal on the deficit would mean that there would be less money available to stimulate employment. Therefore, what the Opposition's alternative proposal is all about is not stimulating employment. There would be much more unemployment under its alternative.

PARA.TAB: I conclude my answer by saying that we have a balanced attack on the problem of unemployment, which is one of the significant problems of this economy. We are doing it without raising taxes, we are doing it without introducing labour market programs that have the effect of lowering wages, and we are doing it without scrapping the initiatives on training, which is the significant big initiative that enables this economy to have a highly skilled work force and thus become a more sophisticated manufacturing and service-provider economy in this, the most spectacularly growing area of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Given the latest figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on manufactured exports from Australia, what is the impact of government industry policy on the growth in manufactured exports, particularly the increase in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures? What role will manufactured exports play if economic recovery gathers pace?
—The latest figures on manufacturing exports were published in the newspapers yesterday.

—Yesterday's figures are not published there. The figures which were published yesterday show a continuing strong growth in manufacturing exports. That has been happening for a number of years now through periods of high growth and low growth in the Australian economy. Members of the Opposition do not want to hear this; they want to hear about unemployment and things like that because it makes them feel good.

PARA.TAB: The latest figures from the ABS say that manufactured exports rose by 10 per cent in the year to June. The most significant part of that was the large contribution of elaborately transformed manufactures. As I recall, the figures are about $14.8 billion. About $9 1/2 billion of that was elaborately transformed manufactures. They are approximate figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —A low base.

—Of course it was a low base. The low base was the Opposition being in government for 27 years. That was a very low base indeed. For example, throughout the 1970s the then government managed to attain growth in manufacturing of one per cent a year.
—What did you do in the 1940s?

—Senator Crichton-Browne asked about the low base, and he is getting the answer—one per cent a year throughout the 1970s; 2.5 per cent a year from 1984 onwards and 2 1/2 times what those opposite achieved throughout the 1970s. So I would not interject about that too much if I were Senator Crichton-Browne, because those opposite were content with an economy which was structured on commodity exports and content with making no change to the economy throughout all those years.
—We did not have two million unemployed.

—Poor old Macdonald has wandered out of his pub again and says, `We did not have two million unemployed'. They did not have two million unemployed; that is true. That is very true. That is a good interjection—really telling. The fact of the matter is that, as the period of structural adjustment has taken place, the best reflection of that has been in the performance of manufacturing exports over the last few years, and that is continuing. The Budget Papers show that growth in manufactured exports has been around 15 per cent in the six years to 1991—well above other OECD countries and, indeed, competing with many countries in this region in terms of the growth factor.

PARA.TAB: Senator West asked questions particularly about whether Government policies had influenced the growth of manufactured exports. I think they have. The automotive industry, for example, which exported nothing a few years ago, had exports of about $1.2 billion last year—

TALK.START.PARA: —Including closing the Nissan factory.

—Of course. Nissan had been losing money for 16 years—eight of them under Liberal governments which had done nothing about it except prop Nissan up with subsidies and tariffs. They went on doing that. They did it for eight years. I do not feel any sense of regret about it. If the Opposition is into job creation of that kind, if that is the new Fightback proposal, where we subsidise companies that are losing money hand over fist—
—What about what you did with Kodak?
—Kodak was not losing money hand over fist. Kodak was contributing nearly $200m a year to the exports about which I am talking. That is the difference.
—Why did you subsidise them?

—Because Kodak would have closed its plant in Australia otherwise. You cannot have it all ways. I would not hesitate to support a proposal to support a manufacturing industry sector which was highly competitive or potentially highly competitive and which had strong growth possibilities—not at all. My objection to Senator Kemp's interjection is that those people opposite propped up a lot of companies that were not competitive. Those companies just had to trot up here to get a made-to-measure tariff from a Liberal government. That is all they had to do.

PARA.TAB: I note the point I was making about automotive industry exports. The same is true of shipbuilding, medical exports, pharmaceutical and scientific products—all high growth export areas where Government policies one way or another have had some influence on their growth.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I remind the Minister that in 1985, 18-, 19- and 20-year-old unemployed young Australians living with their parents received $88.20 a week in income support, an amount described by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his Priority One youth statement as `inadequate'. I ask: why is it that in 1992, seven years later, unemployed 18-, 19- and 20-year-olds living with their parents now receive just $77.10 a week in income support, a decrease in absolute terms of $11.10 but of one-third in real terms with regard to purchasing power? Can the Minister explain how making 18-, 19- and 20-year-old unemployed people live on 13 per cent of average weekly earnings, or some $12.20 below the very austere Henderson poverty line, advances social justice? And why was not something done to provide a living income for these young adults in last night's Federal Budget?
—I must say that, in contrast to the previous question, it is good to see that someone is getting onto the issues that are of concern to the Australian community.
—A bit of light relief, eh?
—Senator Alston refers to his colleague as a bit of light relief; I could not have put it better. It is good that we are on the bread and butter issues, the issues the community is concerned about.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Lees knows, the Government has had a very full commitment over recent months to the issue of youth unemployment and the issue of youth and their role in our community. Rather than give a simplistic response such as that which may come from the Opposition—which is, essentially, `We will charge them more for their basic necessities in life; we will charge them more for their travel expenses'—we have chosen to approach this particular issue in a comprehensive way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give them a job.
—In doing so, we have developed a very well balanced approach encompassing employment, education and training. I will tell you what: we will not be taxing their school books like those opposite.

PARA.TAB: As part of that commitment of this Government, I go back to the point that Senator Lees raised; that of course being support for children and—may I make it just a bit broader—support for families. It should be recognised by this place that this Government has had a long term commitment to the role of families in our community and support for such families. An important step towards fulfilling that commitment was the setting of benchmarks of adequacy, and they were set in 1989. When we introduced those benchmarks of adequacy for child payments, they increased family income support.

As a consequence, we have continued to maintain the benchmarks set at that time—benchmarks which, as I say, are there to provide adequate family support. This Budget reinforces our commitment to those benchmarks.
Senator Lees and everybody else in this place should remember—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very long answer.

—It may be a long answer but there is a very full commitment that needs to be explained, particularly to people like Senator Kemp. It should be remembered that only a few weeks ago, in response to and coming out of the youth summit that was organised by the Prime Minister and this Government, a large number of initiatives were taken up by the Government in respect of the role of youth in our community. Those initiatives go to employment, they go to education and training and they go very much to the heart of income support for young people in this community.

PARA.TAB: It should also be recognised that not only have those outcomes come out of that summit but also that the Government has achieved massive community support for those initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody believes you.

—Not only have we achieved that, Senator Macdonald, from community groups; we have also achieved it from youth themselves. This Budget builds on that. It builds on a commitment to youth and also to alleviating the position of the unemployed.

PARA.TAB: It should be recognised that this Budget allocates some $1.7 billion to creating jobs in our community over the next few years. Of course, that total builds on the $770m that was committed some few weeks ago to providing a program for young people in terms of education, training and employment.

So I say to Senator Lees that we have had a commitment to youth in our community. It is a commitment that has been met by the achievement of fulfilling the benchmarks of adequacy that were set some years ago. This has once again been achieved in this Budget. But I say to Senator Lees that this is not all of the Government's package. Our package has been developed over months. It is one that has the support of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. But, with due respect, I did not ask about those young people who are fortunate enough to gain employment or to be part of the new training options. I did not ask about those young people who are fortunate enough to gain places at university or TAFE. —I will tell Senator Macdonald something: the real perplexing issue facing the Australian community at the moment is that, whereas they do have some concern with us, they have absolutely no confidence in the Opposition. —Senator Bishop is only adding to the squalor of her escapade yesterday by embarking on a new—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Yesterday you caused the Minister to withdraw his slant on both me and the question I asked. It is obvious from his schoolboy humour that he regards this matter as being of no importance whatsoever. I ask you, Mr President, to treat this matter with the seriousness it deserves. We are talking about an ambassador who has represented this country overseas and a very serious complaint that has been made. We do not need schoolboy humour in this place.
—Order! I make the same comment that I made yesterday. I do not regard it as unparliamentary, but I do not think that it is helpful.

—The point about these matters involving personnel issues is that they are delicate, sensitive and complex. It is very difficult to make judgments about the facts of the matter on the basis of hearsay or second or third hand accounts. There are always two sides to these stories. There is a long and complex background to the people involved in this case. There was a question of disciplinary action arising in relation to the husband of the woman concerned. That is a matter in issue. It goes, however, not only to possible motives on the part of the alleged harasser but also, of course, to possible motives on the part of the complainant.

PARA.TAB: This is a very difficult issue to resolve in human terms. Questions of fundamental privacy and fundamental decency to the individuals concerned are involved here. Senator Bishop does not understand any of those fundamental questions of privacy and decency that are necessarily involved in questions of this kind. I find her behaviour in this matter, as indeed in so many other matters, nothing short of contemptible. I have no hesitation whatsoever in branding her in those terms. She is contemptible; she is a disgrace; she is a person who does not understand the fundamental decencies of public office in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. In this chamber we have some Standing Orders which require the Minister to behave. We are not in the Minister's office, where he throws ashtrays, telephones and scissors; we are in the chamber, Mr President, where he is required to abide by the Standing Orders. I ask you to ask him to withdraw those comments.
—Order! I ruled yesterday that it is not parliamentary for senators to call other senators a disgrace. I ask that that be withdrawn.
—I defer to you, Mr President, and withdraw that reference. May I deal with the substantive matters—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask for the term `contemptible' also to be withdrawn. The Minister is—
—Order! Senator Evans has withdrawn the unparliamentary remarks.
—No, he has not.
—I have asked him to, and I believe that he has withdrawn them.
—Now, Mr President, I would like to deal with the substantive questions about the process involved in this matter.
—Did the Minister withdraw all of the unparliamentary remarks?
—I withdrew whatever it was you asked me to withdraw, Mr President, and I do so again. Can I conclude my answer?
—You asked the Minister to withdraw the reference to `disgrace'. The reference that is being objected to is `contemptible'. Why can he not do that?
—Order! I am sure he will.

—If it is your judgment that that is unparliamentary, Mr President, of course I withdraw, and I now do so. May I deal with the questions of process that Senator Bishop raised yesterday. Senator Bishop made much, it will be recalled, of the fact that informal mechanisms, informal processes, were being applied by my Department to deal with this matter at this stage. Senator Bishop made much, she said, of the non-existence anywhere in guidelines that she could find of the availability of these particular informal processes.

PARA.TAB: May I draw to her attention that informal mechanisms for handling complaints of sexual harassment are provided for in part 4 of the personnel management guidelines on eliminating sexual harassment, issued by the Public Service Commission for use in the Australian Public Service. Part 3 of that document does refer to mechanisms for dealing with or resolving cases of sexual harassment. I think it was that to which Senator Bishop was referring yesterday. What she did not do was acknowledge the existence of part 4 of this document—the very next part—which is headed and is all about informal mechanisms, including the informal mechanism of conciliation.

The circumstances and the contents of this document make it perfectly clear that the processes that have been set in train by my Department are exactly appropriate and legitimate, and accepted and acknowledged as appropriate. In fact, 4.1 says that informal measures are the desirable way to resolve all but the more serious intransigent cases of sexual harassment, for a series of reasons which are then set out. Section 4.12 deals specifically with the question of an informal conciliation process and describes the way in which that operates. Might I draw to her attention and table the relevant extracts from those particular personnel management guidelines for Senator Bishop's edification. If she had any decency about her she would, of course, apologise for her assertions yesterday in the light of that documentation, but that is too much to ask, I acknowledge.

The other document I table is the extract from the departmental EEO program—a document no doubt hitherto unfamiliar to Senator Bishop. Certainly everything else about affirmative action and sexual equality in this country is. The relevant extracts from that I also now table. That deals with more specific mechanisms that are established within the Department, including the options of either going down the legal or criminal route, on the one hand, or the route of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Merit Protection and Review Agency on the other. There is also a middle stream procedure here set out and identified involving the contact of the workplace harassment contact officer for advice, and that was the course that was followed in this case. That is what is still being followed in this case.

May I repeat for the record and for Senator Bishop's edification that the complainant asked that the complaint be handled by these informal mechanisms. She has reconfirmed this preference in subsequent discussions. A deputy secretary of my Department, Mr Geoff Forrester, has been conducting an informal conciliation process, with the agreement of both the complainant and the other party. He has been assisted by two female members of the Department's workplace harassment contact group. This process has been conducted by the Department in strict observance of the principles of confidentiality set out in the Public Service Commission's guidelines in order to protect the privacy of both parties. I say again that it is a matter for concern that the details of this case found their way into the public arena and were exposed again yesterday by Senator Bishop's question.

That informal process has not concluded. I am advised that the stage this particular matter has reached is that the departmental conciliator, after conducting a consultative process, has advised the complainant that he cannot bridge the gap in the accounts or the approach to this issue of the two parties and that a decision as to whether to request a formal investigation now rests with the complainant.

It remains open to the complainant—she has been advised of this, as has always been the case, and she has been advised throughout—to lodge a formal grievance with the Secretary of the Department under the Public Service regulations, which is one option, or to go down the other routes I mentioned yesterday: the Merit Protection and Review Agency, a complaint to HREOC under the Sex Discrimination Act or, of course, the criminal process route. These matters are being handled by my Department in accordance with Public Service procedures. It would be quite inappropriate for me to intrude personally into that process other than to be kept informed from time to time as to its progress. That is exactly what happened.

Finally, I am aware of the further point that was made by Senator Bishop yesterday that, in the event that a complainant might withdraw an allegation of sexual harassment, there are still obligations upon the Department to follow through the matter in various ways. They are set out in part 3.6 of the Public Service Commission's guidelines. We are fully aware of these provisions. Mr Forrester has had them in his mind throughout his conduct of the conciliation process.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order—

—How this matter has developed over the last couple of days is to bring forward to the people of Australia through—

—If those standing orders were strictly enforced, we would not have a Question Time. Senator Bishop's supplementary question was too long. I think the Minister's answer was too long. Question Time is over and that was why I showed leniency.

—I do not propose to comment on any aspect of questions that arise as to personnel practice or actions that have been taken in respect of a particular officer who may be involved indirectly in this matter—at two removes from this particular matter. PARA.TAB: As to the first question about whether I misled the Senate in saying that informal processes were part of the proper response to allegations or claims, no, I did not mislead the Senate, for the reasons I have made absolutely clear today—that the guidelines for dealing with sexual harassment as set out under personnel management guidelines of the Public Service Commission in 1990, and still applicable today, make absolutely clear-cut provision for informal processes, for conciliation, of the kind that was engaged in here, of the kind that was specifically requested by the complainant in this particular case and, moreover, are, as I read out, not only available but also encouraged; and the guidelines say that the informal processes are a very desirable way to proceed in most such instances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want to ask your guidance on this matter.

—Mr President, standing order 73 does not relate in any way to this matter.

—I will pick No. 73, it is as good as any. Mr President, I seek your guidance on this matter because the Leader of the Government in the Senate has chosen to make this matter of this particular officer a matter of belittling and of no consequence.
—I think you ought to pull her up now.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, you can take your point of order when Senator Bishop has finished.

—I seek your guidance on how we deal with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, with his disparaging comments about this matter, where he clearly thinks that it is of no importance at all that an officer in the government department overseen by a Minister who has refused to take responsibility has, in fact, made a serious complaint. How do we deal with his unseemly interjections?
—Order! There is clearly no point of order. I cannot instruct the Minister how to answer the question that was asked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

ANSWER.PARA: In other words, it is not a substantive reference. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Boswell asked me a question concerning documentation of nursing home and hostel residents care and some unfortunate effects which he claimed it was having in relation to particular Queensland nursing homes. PARA.TAB: I would be very disturbed, as would the Minister, no doubt, if registered nurses have to work between one and two hours a day in unpaid overtime to answer such time-consuming documentation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to an investigation of allegations of sexual harassment by a staff member of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: It was quite important that during Question Time today for the first time Senator Evans had obviously come across the document called Eliminating Sexual Harassment. Yesterday, before I asked the question in this place, my office rang his Department and asked whether it would forward to my office a copy of the guidelines by which his Department was bound in the way it would act on these matters. His Department forwarded to me two pages only of a workplace harassment statement which comes from the book The EEO Program. The significant page that was missing was that which says that one such sexual harassment was physical contact such as a frequent brushing against a person, pinching or patting or putting an arm around someone.

PARA.TAB: The document I refer to now is a document that was not forwarded and which I had to get subsequently. The initial document that was sent across was the original document introduced by this Government in 1987, the provisions of which were virtually husbanded into this document. When we look at part 4, `Informal Mechanisms', we read the words Senator Evans used:

SPEECH.PARA: Informal measures are the desirable way to resolve all but the more serious intransigent cases of sexual harassments for the following reasons:
. they allow the case to be resolved without an individual necessarily being labelled as a sexual harasser . . .
. they focus on putting future working relationships onto a proper basis. . .
The mind boggles.
. management can institute awareness raising or preventative measures. . .
And on it goes. The most important thing it says, when it comes to conciliation and counselling, is that the principles of natural justice must be adhered to. It then specifically says:

The person conducting the session should in the first instance seek advice from the Merit Protection and Review Agency or the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and then consult with the sexual harassment contact officer on the complainant's preferred outcome. The complainant should be given the opportunity to be accompanied to any session by the sexual harassment contact officer.

I asked the Minister yesterday whether he would outline for us precisely what action he had taken to ensure that the guidelines were implemented. In other words, I asked the Minister which officer—and I can only believe that it has become the Deputy Secretary, Mr Forrester—is in charge of this matter; whether or not contacts have been made with those other agencies; what steps have been taken to attest to the truth of the allegations as made by the complainant; and whether there would be an investigation of the sending of the husband home, allegedly on the basis of unsatisfactory work.

PARA.TAB: The reason I am doubly concerned about this case is that we have had another instance, in this Parliament, where a woman was subject to similar procedures. She got no justice at all for more than three years. I do not think the principles of natural justice should allow this woman to be under a cloud for that period of time. I do not appreciate the sniggers, the schoolboy humour, the keyhole type language used by the man who passes for the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It is unbecoming of any member of this place to try to make this a snide, unpleasant affair. For the woman concerned, it obviously was unpleasant; otherwise she would not have made the complaint.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just wallowing in the sewer.

—Senator Schacht is part of it too. It is a snide and nasty affair. He is the man who goes around the world telling everybody else to behave, saying that everybody else's human rights have to be adhered to; but here, apparently, Australian people's human rights do not have to be observed.

PARA.TAB: I asked the Minister very specifically to outline for me the way in which this inquiry had been set up and whether or not the specific points in this booklet—which he has obviously for the first time clapped his eyes on—have been followed. I think the Senate is entitled to a full report. I ask that, unlike anything Senator Evans has done with regard to Burkegate or the Marshall Islands, he break with practice and come clean with the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop seems utterly unable to appreciate two things. One is a general matter of principle, and that is that one does not make assumptions about the validity of a complainant's complaint simply because a complaint has been laid. There are all sorts of circumstances in which complaints can be laid for all sorts of reasons, all sorts of motivations. Senator Bishop has leapt instantly to the conclusion that there did occur something to complain about. That is a matter ultimately for determination. If it cannot be resolved by some sort of informal process in which a person makes a complaint and the person the subject of the complaint acknowledges that there is some ground of legitimacy, then some other process has to be set in train if the matter is to be pursued.

PARA.TAB: But here we have a situation where the very existence of a ground for the complaint is vigorously denied by the person complained about. It is a matter of his human rights and a little bit of natural justice flowing in that direction for Senator Bishop, or anyone else minded to take up this or any related cause, not to leap to assumptions that something did happen which justified concern on the part of the individual. That may have occurred; it may not have occurred. It is totally inappropriate to make any other presumption than that of innocence about this, just as it is with any other matter of that particular kind. I cannot make that point too firmly, because it does create a situation of very real embarrassment, very real prejudice—

TALK.START.PARA: —To investigate it?

—No, no—when these matters are put into the public domain and when assumptions of guilt are made without any publicly available, publicly known foundation for those particular assumptions. That is the first point I make, and I make it very strongly.

PARA.TAB: The second point that I make is the one that Senator Bishop seems to have constantly forgotten, overlooked or ignored, and that is that this informal process was not one that has been thrust upon the complainant as part of one armoury of mechanisms that are available. This process was one that was sought by the complainant, as I am advised, in this particular case. It was sought to be resolved on an informal basis in the first instance by the complainant. It was made clear to her that she had many other forms of action or redress that she could take, including a formal inquiry established within the Department, as well as the Merit Protection and Review Agency, as well as HREOC, as well as the possible question of a formal legal process. That was made clear to her absolutely from the outset.

It has been made clear to her again, as I am advised, just in the last few days when the conciliator—the departmental person handling this—has formed the judgment that he is unable to bridge the gap that exists as to the matters of content and approach between the two parties. She has been advised that she may consider her position again as to which particular course she may go down. It is not helping her or anybody else to resolve this particular matter for this to be dragged into the public domain, with allegations being made wildly by Senator Bishop in this matter, by seeking to bring into it other issues which may or may not be totally peripheral to the resolution of this particular matter.

I have nothing further to add on this particular case. I do not propose to do so. I have explained the variety of mechanisms that are available. I am assured that Mr Forrester has acted completely in accordance with the guidelines. I do not know—I was not sitting there—how the matter was handled in practice. I can only rely on the assurances that I have been given. I believe that there is nothing that Senator Bishop has brought forward to suggest other than that those procedures have been followed with absolutely impeccable rectitude by Mr Forrester and by my Department. If Senator Bishop had any decency at all, she would let the matter rest and be resolved properly and privately within the processes which are so obviously amply available to deal with these sorts of matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to make it perfectly clear so that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) can understand—because he does have difficulty understanding—that I am not making assertions or conclusions about guilt or innocence. I am determined to ensure that there is a proper hearing. This is not a matter between two—
—You are a sewer rat; that is what you are. You are wallowing in it.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: that statement by Senator Schacht was absolutely disgraceful and unparliamentary and I ask you to ask him to withdraw it.
—I did not hear the remark because of other noise in the chamber, but obviously some remark was made. I ask you to withdraw it, Senator Schacht.
—I withdraw it, Mr Deputy President.

—To reiterate so that the Minister can understand, I am not making assertions about guilt or innocence. I am making assertions that the Minister does not take responsibility for what happens in his own Department. This is not a matter between two junior officers. This matter concerns a woman who is in a master-servant relationship with a head of mission. In other words, he had the power to send her husband back to Australia, to leave her there to fend for herself. He had the power to make life difficult for her.

PARA.TAB: I want to know that there is a proper inquiry, that all the mechanisms have been followed, as set out in the Government's own documentation, and that the rules of natural justice are followed. For the Minister to use terms like `decency' when he likes to sweep under the carpet his misdoings with regard to Burke, with regard to the Marshall Islands, the missing documents and the retractions he has had to make by saying, `I said this but I didn't mean that'—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Could you please rule on whether it is proper for a senator to accuse a Minister of misdoings in this place? I think it is unparliamentary and would ask you to ask the senator to withdraw it.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: it could not possibly be unparliamentary to make that suggestion unless it was totally unfounded. One is entitled to put the proposition, I would have thought. It depends entirely on the circumstances and you cannot make a blanket ruling on a matter such as that.
—Under the circumstances, I think the remark was in order.

—I am a bit surprised at Senator Crowley's attitude. Perhaps senators over there like to espouse things but never actually put them into practice. Here is a person who is in need of a bit of help. Those opposite are the people who basically always say that we have to give assistance to women who are in difficulties. I have not heard one word of support from that side of the chamber. Hypocrisy is the name of the game over there.

PARA.TAB: The point is that we are dealing with a complaint that has been made by a particular employee in the Minister's Department. The complaint is not made by someone who is anonymous—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not now she is not, thanks to you.

—Her name has never been mentioned and the Minister knows it. The reason that most people know about the case is that they read about it in the paper and they heard Ambassador Butler giving interviews on the radio. That is how it came to people's attention. He made some quite interesting comments on the radio.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Minister considers that the complaint that this woman has made is not worthy of his consideration. He has made that quite clear. This man would obviously think that Senator Evans has behaved well in Burkegate and in the Marshall Islands affair. The point is that this is a person who is in a master-servant relationship with a very senior public servant and who is appointed by the Executive Council. The Minister is now leaving us, I see. That is what he does with difficult things; he walks out on them, sweeps them under the carpet and hopes that they will go away. He hopes that the whole problem will go away. Indeed, one could be forgiven for thinking that he thinks the solution to his problem is that, if enough pressure is put on the woman concerned, she might abandon the claim.

The reason that I came back into this chamber is that there are many people who are concerned about this case who have been in contact with me since I raised it in the chamber yesterday. I understand that Senator Button, who is a tired and retiring politician, is no longer interested in perhaps representing his constituents. To the contrary, I am. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation. As I understand it, in the House of Representatives today, Dr Blewett took the opportunity to selectively and very misleadingly quote a remark attributed to me in the Australian Financial Review some months ago.

—Perhaps the Minister would just listen. Why does he think I am on my feet?

TALK.START.PARA: —What a sad, long bow.
—This is not a long bow at all.

Nonetheless, those who are sufficiently desperate, on the other side and in the State of South Australia generally, include Mr Bannon. What Mr Bannon did—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Alston claimed to have been misrepresented. To the extent that there is any misrepresentation, he has covered that. I do not know how, going into Mr Bannon, South Australia and whatever else he wants to do, he in any way affects whether he was or was not misrepresented. —It has, Mr Deputy President. Senator Bolkus has just made the very point I am seeking to make. He says that I am entitled to satisfy the Senate that I was misrepresented. He then says that I was misrepresented in the article. I was not misrepresented in the article. I was misrepresented by what Dr Blewett said today in the House of Representatives, which was to quote selectively one sentence from an article; in other words, to make no reference to real increases, which I would have thought was very significant, and also not to put the article in the context of the problems facing governments. TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Senator Alston may as well finish.
—I was proposing to proceed to what Mr Bannon had to say, because this is an even more egregious transgression.
—Senator Alston, you were debating the point then.
—In so far as you have been misrepresented, go ahead.
—I think Senator Button and I are in agreement. I am about to proceed to what Mr Bannon had to say. Mr Bannon wrote in these terms to a constituent:

SPEECH.PARA: Their Social Security spokesman, Senator Alston, said recently: `It would be very difficult for a coalition government to increase old-age pensions . . . Realistically, it's unlikely that they would go up much, if at all'. (Financial Review, 6th March 1992).
That is outrageous because that is not a direct quotation from what I have said—not at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate the whole article.
—I am happy to incorporate both the full letter and the article. There is no difficulty about doing that.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier of South Australia
9 April 1992
Mr K Bishop
28 Upper Sturt Road
BELAIR 5052
Dear Mr Bishop,
I refer to your letter of March 6th in which you ask why pensions are geared to the CPI. Although this is a matter for which the Federal Government is responsible, I provide the following comments.
Pensions are linked to the CPI so that pensioners' incomes do not fall behind increases in the cost of living. Wage and salary earners (including Members of Parliament) do not have this advantage.
When there is a positive CPI, as is almost always the case, pensions are increased accordingly. When there is a negative CPI, as occurred in June 1991, pensions are not, however, decreased.

Many wage and salary earners would very much like to be in your position and have their income automatically increased every six months, rather than have it eroded by inflation as has been the case in recent years of wage restraint. Although there are some salary earners, such as many business executives, who have had increases over and above the CPI, the vast majority have not even kept up with inflation as pensioners have.

The Federal Labour Government has not only linked pensions to the CPI, but it gave an additional increase in June 1990 to bring the pension to just over 25% of Average Weekly Earnings. In fact, the real value (that is, the value over and above indexation increases) of the pension has increased by 11.8% since the Labor Government came to office. This compares with a drop of 2.5% in the seven years of the previous Liberal/National Party Government.

The Labor Government intends to continue to index pensions to the CPI. There is no guarantee, however, that the Liberal Opposition would do the same if they came to power. Their Social Security spokesman, Senator Alston, said recently: "It would be very difficult for a coalition government to increase old-age pensions . . . Realistically, it's unlikely that they would go up much, if at all". (Financial Review, 6th March 1992).
Labor is also committed to removing all aged full and part pensioners from the tax system by 1995. The Liberal Opposition has not made this commitment.
Yours sincerely,
(J C BANNON)
cc Mr Stan Evans MP, Member for Davenport
NATIONAL AFFAIRS
Financial Review
Friday, March 6, 1992
Libs plan tax on transitional period super lump-sums
by Joseph Dowling

A coalition government would introduce a tax on lump-sum superannuation payments of more than $300,000 during a transitional period, the Opposition retirement incomes spokesman, Senator Richard Alston, said yesterday.
In the Fightback! package released by the Opposition in November, it was proposed that lump-sum payments would be capped at $300,000 and made tax-free.
The proposal had left confusion in the industry over the treatment of people who already had accumulated entitlements above the proposed $300,000 lump-sum limit.

However, in an interview with The Australian Financial Review yesterday, Senator Alston said the committee formed by the Opposition to examine aspects of the superannuation package was focusing on establishing an appropriate level of tax on lump sums above $300,000 until the coalition's regime was well and truly under way. He said the tax would be "something less than 15 per cent.
"At the moment, there are people with entitlements in excess of $300,000 and we don't want to retrospectively stop them from taking their accrued entitlements.

"But, because we're abolishing lump-sum taxes from day one, we don't want to give these blokes a windfall where they would otherwise be paying a 15 per cent tax. We'll therefore devise this low level flat rate tax during a transition period.
"After five years and once the new regime is well and truly under way, there won't be people with an excess of $300,000, because that is the cap, the limit," he said.
Amounts above $300,000 would have to be taken in the shape of annuities.

The senator also said the superannuation committee under Professor David Knox, would examine treatment of contributions tax for defined benefit schemes, some of which may be on contributions holidays.
As well, he indicated that it would be very difficult for a coalition government to increase old-age pensions.
"The fact that you've got a rising aged population makes it pretty likely that you can't just go on having real increases.
"The pressures will be it will be very difficult to increase the pension and people ought to realise that. Realistically, it's unlikely that they would go up much, if at all," he said.
In recognition of that, tax incentives to invest in superannuation would underpin the Opposition's non-compulsory superannuation arrangements, he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it plain that I find this an appalling misrepresentation of my position.
—You have been caught with your hands in their pockets and you don't like it.
—Order! I ask Senator Alston to disregard any interjections.

—Yes. It is virtually bordering on the pathetic, Mr Deputy President. What that letter by Mr Bannon did—and I presume it was on a considered basis; perhaps aided, abetted and encouraged by the likes of Senator Bolkus and Dr Blewett—was to say that I had said it would be very difficult for a coalition government to increase old age pensions, and to attribute that to an article in the Australian Financial Review. There is nothing in what I said that uses those words, so they are not in any shape or form a direct quotation from the article. If that is not a deliberate misrepresentation, I do not know what is. To put something in quotes and then to put in brackets `Financial Review 6 March' surely is saying to anyone who reads that that these words are directly taken from an article in the Australian Financial Review. And yet they are not. That is why I am more than happy for the record to speak for itself. I hope that even the likes of Senator Bolkus will be able to appreciate just how disgraceful that effort is.

PARA.TAB: I have written to Mr Bannon asking him for an apology and inviting him to say those things again. I regard that as not only the height of irresponsibility but a gross misrepresentation of my position. I have made it clear today that my position is that governments of any complexion will find increasing difficulty in meeting a wide range of claims on the public purse unless those reforms are undertaken. I would have thought that is self-evident. If the Government wants to put up taxes to do it, go on doing that and it will get its just reward. This ought to be self-evident.

Mr Deputy President, there is just one last thing that I want to refer to because I think it is also very significant. I want to quote from a document called Security and Retirement, which was tabled by Mr Dawkins on 30 June last. The document says:

SPEECH.PARA: To increase base pension levels significantly and to have the pension paid also increased with income as an alternative means of addressing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you are now debating the point.
—Mr Deputy President, I would like to finish the quotation because it is very relevant to—
—It is not relevant to your alleged misrepresentation.

—It is because it precedes what Dr Blewett had to say. Again, I think the facts will speak for themselves. If I can finish the quotation, I will be content to leave the matter there. The document says:

SPEECH.PARA: To increase base pension levels significantly and to have the pension paid also increased with income as an alternative means of addressing the market failure of inadequate savings for retirement would weaken further all the incentives that otherwise exist and which are now to be strengthened in their effect by the SGC for private self provision.
