TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 18 August 1992 of former Senator James Philip Toohey, AM, Senator for the State of South Australia from 1953 to 1971. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Tuesday 18 August 1992, of former Senator James Philip Toohey, a Senator for the State of South Australia from 1953 to 1971, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his wife and family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: James Philip Toohey was born on 11 July 1909 in Adelaide. He was educated at Cowandilla State school. His first jobs were as a motor builder at the Chrysler and GMH plants in South Australia. For several years he was an organiser and Assistant Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation. From 1947 to 1949 he was a councillor on the West Torrens District Council. He was State Secretary of the South Australian branch of the ALP from 1947 to 1955 and for a time he held the position of State party President.

PARA.TAB: His career as a parliamentarian in the Senate spanned 18 years, from 1953 to 1971. During this time, Jim Toohey worked on various Senate committees with diligence and distinction. As well, he was appointed to represent the Australian Parliament at the United Nations in New York. During those years, he was also the South Australian delegate to the Labor Party's Federal Executive. Upon his retirement from Federal Parliament he held the position of Senior Federal Vice President of the Labor Party.

Jim Toohey was well regarded by his peers and was a popular choice of the people in his home State of South Australia. He believed that as federal representative he should be able to give 100 per cent service to the community, and he did exactly that. His contributions were recognised in 1978 when he was appointed a member of the Order of Australia for his services to the trade union movement and to politics.

Jim Toohey was a very honest person who was noted for his conciliatory approach. Those who knew him say that he could always throw oil on troubled waters whenever situations seemed to be getting out of hand. In his maiden speech in the Senate he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We want people of understanding in our legislatures.
Jim Toohey was such a man and I think this sentiment would be shared by all those who knew him.

PARA.TAB: Personally, I had the privilege of knowing Jim Toohey. I always regarded him as a person of great honesty and integrity. He was also a person of wisdom and commonsense. I always very much respected his advice and the help that he was able to give me personally as well as others who were new to this business at the time. On behalf of the Government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his wife Margaret and to his close relatives in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on behalf of coalition senators, I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in expressing our regret at the death yesterday at the age of 83 of former Senator James Philip Toohey. I, of course, did not know former Senator Toohey. But from reading the record of his achievement, particularly his long period of distinguished service here for some 18 years, it is obvious that he made a major contribution not only to the Labor Party but to politics generally.

PARA.TAB: I noticed in the obituary in today's Adelaide Advertiser, headed `Historic role within ALP recorded' relating to Mr Toohey, that former Labor Minister Clyde Cameron was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Jim Toohey was easily the most greatly respected and admired member of the Labor Party I have ever known.
That is an endorsement that obviously indicates the standing in which he was held within the Labor movement.

PARA.TAB: James Toohey clearly rose from the bottom. He did not have a great deal of education. He progressed through his trade, worked within the party, became its General Secretary for six years and later became the President of the party. As I said, he spent 18 years in the Federal Parliament serving the State of South Australia and the ALP in this Senate. That is obviously a record of public contribution that we should recognise. I am pleased to be able to do so on behalf of coalition senators today. We join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate in extending our condolences and sincere sympathy to his widow and his family and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I too join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in the motion of condolence in relation to James Philip Toohey. I also did not know James Toohey during his time in the Senate but clearly he worked in a number of capacities and served the State of South Australia extremely well during his 18 years in this place.

PARA.TAB: I have here a copy of one of former Senator Toohey's speeches, which was given in relation to the Budget in 1953. It seems that the words are apposite to the circumstances of today, when we are also dealing with the present Budget. On that occasion, Senator Toohey said of the then Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: On that occasion he advocated—
that is the Prime Minister—
the entry of a greater number of businessmen into the political life of this nation. He said that because we were now dealing with budgets amounting to #1,000,000,000 —
a remarkable amount for the time—

it was essential that we should have in the legislative halls of this country, businessmen who could steer the various financial deals through to a proper conclusion. I certainly do not subscribe to the belief that there is any need for the intrusion of businessmen into the Commonwealth or State Parliaments.
He went on:

I do not say they should be excluded, but I believe that the business of the nation and the welfare of the people should never become inconsequential sidelines of somebody engaged actively in the pursuit of profits. The influx of great numbers of businessmen into our Parliaments would have exactly that result. The Parliaments of this country need men and women whose hearts and minds can be moved by suffering and who have a burning desire to correct injustices. Above all, we need men and women whose ears are so attuned that even above the roar of commerce and industry they can hear the cry for mercy of the underprivileged.
He went on:

We do not need businessmen to do that. When one looks through the legislation that has been placed on the statute-book in this and other countries, one finds that every measure that has for its aim the advancement of the human race was placed there by people of the homespun kind who know and understand the needs of the people and not by hard-boiled businessmen who are so concerned with chasing profits that the real problems of the people escape them.

As Senator Button said, we want people with understanding in our legislatures. I never knew Senator Toohey. However, it seems to me that, if that is an expression of his sentiments during his 18 years in Parliament, one can only say `Hear, hear!', and that they are as relevant today as they were in 1953 when he made them. We join with other senators in offering our condolence to his widow and the rest of his family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to associate my National Party colleagues with the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the remarks of the Leader of the coalition (Senator Hill). I never had the privilege of knowing Senator James Philip Toohey, and I do not suppose anyone in Parliament did, except with their associations with the ALP and their State organisations. No doubt we will hear from the Labor senators from South Australia who had the privilege of knowing this person.

PARA.TAB: One could say that former Senator Toohey gave a lifetime of service to his Party. Through his association from 1947, when he was a State ALP general secretary, until he retired from politics in 1971, he represented the ALP in both an organisational and parliamentary role. Former Senator Toohey lived for 83 years. During those 83 years, I believe that he gave great service to the people of South Australia. I extend the sympathy of the National Party to his family and friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also speak to the motion moved by Senator Button. I suppose that in politics one makes lots of contacts and from time to time makes friends. In the case of Jim Toohey, I saw him not only as a close, warm and personal friend but also very much as a confidant in both my personal and political life. Jim was very much a true believer all his life and applied his principles of honesty, sensitivity and equality to whatever role he played in his life. Irrespective of whether it was his interaction with individuals, communities or organisations within our community, Jim was not only a person who was liked and trusted but also someone on whom people could always rely for a calm head, a calm voice and a calm dose of advice.

PARA.TAB: As has been noted already, former Senator Toohey was born in 1909 very much in the heart of Adelaide. To assume the right label for the rest of his life, he very quickly supported and became involved in the West Adelaide Football Club, which was the right thing to do in that part of the city at that time. It was an interest he followed until his last days. He was lucky in 1983 to see his team win a grand final.

Jim maintained a concern for the working class in our community, who were the closest to him. As has also been evidenced in this discussion this afternoon, his concern went further than just one subgroup of the community. Whatever he did in life and no matter with whom he interacted, he applied a very healthy dose of intelligence and commonsense in a very sensitive way. As a consequence, he was widely respected as a gentle person and widely admired and listened to.

If one is to define how Jim approached life or how he was seen by others with whom he interacted, the best title for him is that he was very much an honest broker. His history of community involvement started with the trade union movement and the Vehicle Builders Union, whatever it was called in the days when he was a member—it did have a different name then—which was an organisation by whom he was widely respected.

Involvement with the Labor Party was a matter of course for Jim. His involvement was recognised not only in South Australia but nationally. As Senator Button mentioned, he also had an international presence. He was State Secretary of the Party from 1947-53, State President from 1954-55 and a senator representing the State of South Australia for 18 years from 1953-71.

Those raw figures do not adequately demonstrate the role that Jim played in community and political affairs. If one was to go to Jim's most important contribution in community and political life, though he would modestly deny it, others would recognise that Jim Toohey was very much the father of Labor in South Australia over the last four or five decades. He was the pivotal part of a troika consisting of himself, Clyde Cameron and Geoff Virgo—two rather headstrong and assertive characters—but Jim always had the capacity to bring them together and, in doing so, built a very solid basis from which the Labor movement in South Australia could operate.

Both the Dunstan Government and the John Bannon Government, which has been in government for a decade, owe their continuity and success to the stability in the Labor movement in South Australia, of which stability Jim Toohey was very much the father. Don Dunstan and John Bannon would both recognise the role played by Toohey in forming the basis of Labor politics in my State.

As an indication of his influence—I came into this place some 10 years after Jim left it—when I was first seeking preselection in the late 1970s for the Senate, the first bit of advice I got from anybody was to talk to Jim Toohey, in recognition of the fact that Toohey was respected and listened to. Though he probably did not carry one vote at that time in our conventions, his influence was much more persuasive than any figure on any card that was represented at that convention.

As I have just indicated, Jim's influence did not just prevail while he was in politics or in a formal position within the Party; he would listen to most people and talk to any person. As a consequence, his influences filtered through generations of Labor people after he formally retired from politics.

For instance, in 1974 in Adelaide—and I think my colleague Chris Schacht was one of those involved at the time—we started a lunch club in the Chinatown restaurant. We got this group together when Chris Schacht and I were both working for Senator Bishop. I suppose it was a Friday talkfest and Bishop and Toohey were two of the first people there. It was a talkfest in that it provided a good sounding-board for ideas for a lot of us who had been working in Canberra, but more importantly, it provided a good forum for interaction for younger people coming into and through the Party. That lunch club has continued and it was only a few weeks ago that Jim went to his last lunch at Chinatown.

He had a view of history. He had a lot to offer and, in fact, gave a lot—not just on the State level, but he was a reformer on a national level as well. His work in the Senate was evidence of this. It is interesting to note that this very meek and gentlemanly person was given the responsibility in 1957 by the National Conference of the Labor Party essentially to take over the New South Wales branch of the Party. At any time that would have been a daunting feat for any person, but Jim did it extremely well.

He was so widely respected by our branch in South Australia that at that crucial Hobart conference of the Party in 1955, at a time when the Labor movement was embarking upon a rather disastrous split, delegates from South Australia were told, in terms of what to do, to just follow Jim, because Jim would be the person who would take the right approach in terms of commonsense and for the good of the Labor movement.

He will be missed. I know I will miss him. Even until recently, Jim continued to provide me with advice in both my personal and political lives. He will be missed by his friends and particularly people like Reg Bishop, an ex-senator in this chamber; Clyde Cameron; Glen Broomhill and his family; and of course his wife, Margie. Margie will miss him, as will other members of his family. He will also be missed by the broader community to which he has made a very positive and valuable contribution for a good part of the 83 years of his life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my deepest sadness at the loss of Jim Toohey. He was a great South Australian Labor identity and a good friend of mine. Jim Toohey was a man who was slight in build and at a good age, but he cast a giant shadow over the Labor Party and the affairs of the State for many decades.

PARA.TAB: The South Australian branch of the Labor Party and, indeed, the Party nationally, owes much to Jim Toohey. His organisational ability revolutionised the operations of the South Australian ALP. While Jim was State Secretary he worked to ensure that the Party remained united. He recognised that there were many differences of opinion, but that these differences should not impede the effectiveness of the Party. Under the direction of Jim Toohey in South Australia, the ALP was able to prepare itself for the end of the electoral gerrymander, when Labor could take power.

It is interesting to note that Jim—as Senator Bolkus mentioned—was temporary State Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the ALP for a period. He was appointed to this position by the Federal Executive because of his impressive organisational skills and effective performance in South Australia. Further, it should be recognised that South Australia and New South Wales were the only States to avoid the destructive ALP splits of the 1950s. In fact, Jim is well remembered for his attempts to reduce factional conflict at the national level whilst he was Federal Senior Vice-President of the Party.

Like many of us, Jim Toohey became involved with the ALP through the union movement. I am very proud to say that Jim was a member of the same union that I was Secretary of prior to coming to this place. The Vehicle Builders Union was the second biggest ALP affiliated union in South Australia when Jim joined it and became involved. He worked originally at Chrysler and later at General Motors Holden as a car body builder, and for a time he also worked at the aircraft production workshops at Islington. In all of these jobs he took on the role of shop steward, which gave him much exposure within the union movement.

The union was to have the benefit of his tremendous organisational ability from 1944 to 1947 when he served as Assistant Secretary and Organiser for the VBU. During his service to the union many within the Labor movement noted his ability and commitment. Indeed, the Party made him State Secretary in 1947, a position he would hold until his election to the Senate in 1953.

The trade union movement has lost a great friend and supporter in Jim Toohey. His union career was always important to him and I remember that he would often talk about his involvement in the 10-day time-study strike. Jim was on the West Torrens District Council, as was mentioned earlier, and took those duties very seriously. He was an active person in the community throughout his life.The Party office in Adelaide became a very efficient and effective operation under Toohey's direction. Jim introduced elements of technology such as a Gestetner copying unit. Also, he was the first Party Secretary to use a car purchased by the ALP. He would travel all around the State drumming up support for the Party and establishing branches.

Politics in South Australia has always been a little different from the other States. Indeed, we tend to be less cutthroat and more conciliatory. This applies to the ALP itself. Organised factions are quite a new phenomena in South Australia and consensus decision-making still plays a pivotal role. Jim Toohey probably had as much to do with this as anyone. He was an exceptional political organiser who had the great ability to be able to negotiate and reach consensus without causing conflict. Along with a number of other ALP figures and union leaders, Toohey was able to ensure that potential conflict and divisions were ironed out before they could lead to problems for the Party. Jim was also an exceptional orator with the ability to sway the State convention or any other forum with relative ease. He was rational, reasoned and forceful with his arguments.

In 1953 Jim was elected to this place to serve the people of South Australia. During his 18 years here he proved his commitment by continually raising issues that were important to his constituents. His contributions to this place in the way of speeches and questions were a credit to his ability and integrity. On committees he was a lively participant and particularly enjoyed his involvement on the Australian Capital Territory Committee.

Jim served in this place with a fellow South Australian, Clem Ridley, who also came from the Vehicle Builders Union. They were great mates for many years. In fact, they first worked together selling rabbits as youths. Like all of us in the Labor Party, comradeship was important to Toohey. Unfortunately, Jim never experienced a Labor Government while he served in the Senate. Therefore, his time here did not have the highs I am sure he would have wished for. He did once represent Australia in the United Nations in 1968, which he counted as one of the most interesting aspects of his parliamentary life.

Jim Toohey was a man of very high principles and great moral fibre. He believed in and promoted consensus decision-making, while at the same time recognising the cut-and-thrust nature of the political system. In South Australia we often call this consensus approach to politics `Tooheyism'.

Jim enjoyed life and experienced many things. He played football for Parklands when he was young, his father was a builders' labourer and he went to Cowandilla State School, as was mentioned earlier. He was ordinary in origins, but a great man in stature. There is not one South Australian Labor MP, senator or legislative councillor who has not been influenced, inspired or touched by Jim Toohey. No other person in South Australia has been involved so much in the administration and direction of a political party. He attended Party functions until his death and his influence within the party was immense until the end.

My thoughts go out for Jim's wife, Margaret, his relatives and his friends who will be very sad at this time. James Philip Toohey was a born leader and caring individual. He was a true believer, who fought for a better deal for working people. He was an inspiration to our great Party. Your mates will miss you, Jim.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this condolence motion for a great friend, Jim Toohey. As a former State Secretary of the ALP in South Australia, I appreciate the service and the record of Jim Toohey as a previous State Secretary. Jim was State Secretary of the Party in South Australia from 1947 to 1953. When he became State Secretary, the Party organisation at a formal level was quite bereft of resources and of influence. It had been through a long period of turmoil during the 1930s when the Labor Party in South Australia split into three different parties. Jim took over in 1947 and very quickly brought together the remaining dissident groups within the Labor movement and combined them within the Labor Party so that they became a very effective political force.

PARA.TAB: In 1953 he sought election for the Senate. Typical of the Jim Toohey attitude, when he could have easily taken a very safe spot at No. 1 or No. 2 on the ticket, he chose to stand at what we call the marginal position, at No. 3 on the ticket, because he thought that was the right thing to do. It was a very good year for the Labor Party. He won a seat then and was re-elected a number of times until he retired in 1971.

When he retired from the Senate in 1971, there was much astonishment in South Australia because Jim was only in his early sixties. Under our then retirement age rule he was still eligible for at least another six years had he chosen to stand. When people asked him why he was standing down and not seeking re-election when everyone expected the Whitlam led Labor Party to win the 1972 election and when he clearly would have been a major contender to be a senior Minister in that government, he said, `It is better to retire from Parliament when people are asking you, "Why are you retiring?" than when they are saying to you, "Why are you staying?"'.

That was always his attitude to politics. He believed that it is always better to go out on a top note than to hang around until people get desperate to shift you on or you outstay your welcome. He always believed that about State secretaries. He said that six years as a State Secretary in South Australia was more than enough for anybody. It needed a turnover. It needed new people with new ideas to come into the position—new blood. He certainly impressed upon me and his other successors that the position of State Secretary should not be seen as a long term career position because the longer someone is there, the more ineffectual that person will become because of the nature of politics. That is very good, simple, commonsense advice that the Party in South Australia has now followed for over 40 years.

In the 1950s, Jim Toohey played a major role, as some of my colleagues have mentioned, in ensuring that the devastating split that destroyed the Labor Party in other States did not come to South Australia. I think his contribution to stopping the split in South Australia was greater than that of any other Labor figure. As senior national vice-president at that time, he played a role that was very difficult to carry out because of the split, because of the animosities and because of the personality differences that were alive in the Labor Party at the time.

Jim Toohey always believed that politics is a pretty simple art in a way. All one has to use is good commonsense in dealing with people and one cannot go far wrong or get into too many difficulties. That was something he expressed to many of us who succeeded him, to many of us who listened to his advice. He told us to treat people as we would expect to be treated, to be reasonable, to use commonsense and the Party would do well. He also told us never to get too far ahead of what the mainstream of our supporters want, to educate them but to understand that they have views that should be noted, and to always listen and take note of other people's views.

I believe that the success of the Labor Party in South Australia over nearly 50 years since the Second World War is overwhelmingly a tribute to the commonsense approach of Jim Toohey. He once talked to me and to others about the position of State Secretary and also, as an influential figure, about the use of power. He said that power is a commodity and that once you start using it it starts to diminish. He said that it has to be realised that no matter how good people may think they are power has to be used with great discretion and that even when people are using it well they are going to upset some people because at times they have to be honest with them and explain to them what they are about. He said that people should not run away from the fact that at times they have to use power creatively and constructively for the good of the Party and not just for the good of themselves or other individuals.

Jim Toohey will be remembered in the Labor Party in South Australia as one of the great figures in our 100-year history. Already there are many memorials to Jim and his contribution, memorials established before he unfortunately passed away last weekend. For example, the boardroom of the ALP head office in South Australia is called the Jim Toohey Executive Room in recognition of his contribution.

After Jim retired from Parliament in 1971, he continued to play a very active role within the Labor Party. For many years he came to State conventions and State Council as an ex officio delegate. Whenever he spoke, he invariably persuaded the convention or the Council to his point of view because of the sheer good commonsense of what he was expressing. Jim Toohey has held every position the State branch of the Labor Party in South Australia can give, and he held most of those without opposition. He also held most of the senior positions of the Party organisation at the national level.

I believe that the Party in South Australia and the community have lost a towering figure. I must say with great regret that it is highly unlikely that I will be able to attend Jim's funeral on Friday because I have to chair a select committee of the Senate. It is a matter of great personal regret that I will not be able to attend the funeral.

To Mag and the rest of Jim Toohey's family, I express my sincere and deepest condolences at the passing of a man who was not only a great Labor figure but also a great personal friend who, by his wise counsel, helped make my contribution to the Labor Party so much better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add a few brief comments to those of people who have spoken in this place to this condolence motion on the death of Jim Toohey. Senator Bolkus said that young people in the Labor Party who wanted to find out who was who and what was what in the South Australian branch were advised and urged to have a word with Jim Toohey. I got that message and I had the pleasure of talking with Jim on a number of occasions.

PARA.TAB: I am not quite sure that I was given the Jim Toohey imprimatur, but I regard it as a great privilege that I am the first woman the South Australian branch sent to Canberra. I am quite sure Jim Toohey was one of those people who were able to see the need for change and the need for increasing, as had been happening anyhow, the range of people who presented as candidates for the Labor Party, State and Federal, in South Australia.

I will not trawl over his great contribution. That has been mentioned often here. I can only second all of the comments that have been made. I simply want to put on the record my appreciation for not only Jim's support but, more particularly, his friendship. He and his wife, Meg, were delightful people. Jim's monument is in his dedication and commitment to all of those values and principles he held during his time of active involvement in the Labor Party, which continued for the 22 years after his retirement, almost up until a week or so ago.

He continued to contribute his own commonsense and friendly, generous calm in all sorts of forums, and his community involvement entailed attendance at any number of functions in support of the people whom he judged the Labor Party represented throughout his lifetime. I thank him for his support; I thank him for his friendship, and I thank his wife, Meg, for the same. They are people who I think stand as splendid monuments to just what it is to be a decent human. I do not suppose I can say it better than that for Jim Toohey today. I extend my sympathy to his wife Meg and to the rest of his family at this sad time.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Prior to giving notice of my motion, may I say how moving it was to hear some of the tributes that were paid to a former colleague in this chamber. The manner in which tributes are paid to deceased colleagues adds stature to this place.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Patterson proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Senate to condemn the government for:

INTERJECT.PARA: a)Failing to take the opportunity in the 1992/93 budget to reform the health care system presently in crisis
b)Raising personal income tax in the form of an increase in the Medicare Levy and perpetuating the myth that Medicare provides a universal health service for all Australians.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night we witnessed the Labor Party delve deeply into its barrel of tricks and treats. Unfortunately for Australians, the Labor Party pulled out a trick. For 10 years this Labor Government has neglected the health care system of this nation, after it introduced Medicare. Instead of moving over the years to correct the anomalies in the health system, the Labor Government has been transfixed by its ideology so as not to touch the system that it put in place in 1983.

PARA.TAB: Medicare was supposedly designed to provide an equitable, efficient and fair system of health for all Australians. After 10 years, we have finally reached the stage when the Government, in the depths of despair and facing electoral defeat at the next election, has been forced to acknowledge the problems inherent in its health system. However, the only action taken by this Government is to raise the Medicare levy and throw money at the symptoms without addressing the underlying problems.

This Government's record on health is an absolute disgrace and nothing in last night's Budget did anything to change that. Over the last 10 years, waiting lists have increased to between 70,000 and 100,000. Private hospitals are currently under-utilised with a 55 per cent to 60 per cent occupancy rate. Hospitals have been closed in rural areas and hospital costs have increased by 12 per cent per annum—163 per cent in the last 10 years. The cost of private health insurance has risen 130 per cent in the last five years. About 20 per cent of people who used to be covered by private health insurance have left the system. That is the state of Australia's health system as it stands today.

The criticism of the system has been deafening. The Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Hospital Association, in an unprecedented coming together in this report, Time to Act—Operation: Hospital Survival, `demanded a return to private health insurance for most of the population saying it is the only hope of survival for the nation's hospital system'. That is a direct quote from their media release when they got together just recently and issued this document to indicate that both the public and private hospital systems are in crisis. Their solution was to encourage people to go into private health insurance.

State Health Ministers have said similar things. Mr Wilson, a senior Minister in the Western Australian Labor Government, at a recent conference joined with his Liberal counterpart, Mr John Hannaford, in supporting the call to maintain a universal health insurance coverage for all pensioners, unemployed and low income earners but to ease the funding burden by encouraging other people to meet their health costs through private insurance.

What did Mr Wilson tell the rally that was held when he and Mr Hannaford got together on this issue? Mr Wilson told the rally that he had been put under pressure at a very high level not to make his speech. That is the sort of pressure that goes on in this Labor Party. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is, hospital Medicare is not the fair and just system it promised to be and has not been since its inception.

No wonder people did not want him to go and speak at that rally—because he was telling it as it is. He was telling the truth for a change—not a change for him but a change for the people on the other side of the chamber. That is what he was doing, and he was going to be gagged.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in one fell swoop we witnessed Labor's burning ambition to totally destroy the private health insurance system in Australia. The private health insurance system provides 11 per cent of funds to Australia's health system, which is more than the Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent provides. That levy currently provides only 8 per cent of the funds. I do not know what the Government will do when more people leave the private health insurance system.

Madam Acting Deputy President, because you are about the same age as I am, you will most probably remember those little clowns on a barrel. There were two sticks poking up and a bit of string around it. There was a little clown on it and when you pressed the bottom the little clown turned around. Somebody has been pressing on the bottom of the barrel and Mr Howe has been whizzing around and doing tailspins and somersaults on his policy. Last night when I listened to the Budget, I could see that little image—a little effigy of Mr Howe on a string whizzing around, revolving on his health policy. It has been like a revolving door—round and round and round.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before my time, Senator.

—If Senator Tate cannot imagine it, he might go to the Australian Museum in Victoria and have a look at the toy display. He will see some toys from our generation—and I include him and me in that—and he might see one of those little toys with a clown on it. In an amazing backflip, the Minister for Health, Brian Howe, has now decided that throwing money at the health system by way of an increased Medicare levy is effective.

PARA.TAB: On 29 August 1991, the Minister for Health said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that to produce the same fiscal result as our GP package (Medicare co-payment)—
All honourable senators have to do is just cast their minds back to the last Budget; we had a Medicare co-payment then—
would require a lift in the Medicare Levy from 1.25% of income to 1.53% and because this would not stem the growth in service use, further increases in the levy would be required in later years.
The fact is that it is neither equitable nor efficient to pump more money into a system which is oversupplied with practitioners and delivering unnecessary services.
It would be inequitable to increase the compulsory contribution of working people to finance unnecessary services and services of marginal clinical value brought about by too many doctors.

When was this? It was 29 August 1991. Almost a year ago to the week, Mr Howe, the little clown on the end of the piece of string, was telling us that if the Government were to increase the Medicare levy it would have to be increased to 1.53 per cent, to equal what the Medicare co-payment was going to bring in, and it would have to be increased in future years.

PARA.TAB: What did he do last night? He increased it, but not to 1.53 per cent. So how—and I believe `how' is the operative word—is he going to get the money? Will he increase it in later years? In August 1991 he said he would have to increase it. So if the Australian public is misled by anything that he has said in the Budget or anything that he says in the media today about it not increasing, then they are being fooled.

Why has the Minister changed his mind? Why did he spin around on the piece of string? When asked yesterday on ABC radio whether there would be any future increase after yesterday's rise to 1.4 per cent, the Minister was reluctant to comment, saying it would not be very useful to do so. No wonder it would not be useful to do so; he had said only a year ago that it would have to be increased. He said it would have to be 1.53 per cent at least, and after that it would increase in future years. No wonder he was reluctant to comment. I would bet that the Minister already had another rise in the Medicare levy in mind, because he said in 1991 that that is what he would have to do.

Last night we witnessed Labor's move to destroy the private system and remove the choice Australians have had until now of whether they are treated privately or publicly. The private health system will be destroyed by yesterday's measures. There is absolutely no incentive to take out private health insurance and take the responsibility of looking after one's own health. Labor has already sunk the boot into private health insurance, and last night's measures are designed to hit the rest of the private market on the head with a sledge-hammer. The injection of some funds into the public health system may have some minor effect on hospital waiting lists, but it does nothing to address the fundamental structural problems in our health system.

I ask honourable senators to cast their minds back to a document released just after the 1987 election in the 1987-88 Budget. What did the Government do? Labor was going to introduce a two-year hospital waiting list assistance program. It was going to provide $50m over two years to bring down hospital waiting lists. What did it do? Exactly the same solution—not `solution', thing—it is doing now to try to solve the problem. But the Government is directing money at the symptoms, not the underlying cause. Russell Schneider from the Australian Health Insurance Association put it very succinctly when he said that it is a mere drop in the bedpan. It does nothing to solve the hospital waiting lists—nothing at all.

The measures in last night's Budget will exacerbate the problem of declining levels of private health insurance. We have seen 20 per cent of people leave private health insurance. I think it was 63 per cent in 1983 in private health insurance, now it is down to around 42 per cent. What will people do now? They will most probably listen to the Government's furphy: `Here it is! Medicare—an equitable and fair system. You will now be able to get into a public hospital. Don't worry if you have a problem with your hip with arthritis. You'll get in. You won't have to wait 14 months. You won't have to wait to have your children's ears fixed when they need more surgery on them because they have glue ear. Don't worry about it'.

What incentive will there be for the 826,000 over 65-year-olds, many of them pensioners, who continue to struggle to pay their private health insurance when, in the next bed to them in a private hospital, they will see a public patient under this Government's scheme? There will be no incentive. Why would there be? Why would you struggle with no rebate and no credit for taking out private health insurance? Australia cannot afford to lose the enormous source of funding provided by the private sector, but this is what we are moving to.The measures announced yesterday will not work to fix the dramatic problems we currently see in our health system.

Firstly, the Medicare reforms rely on cooperation from the States. If we go by previous comments made by State health Ministers, I wonder—and I am sure my colleagues on this side wonder—what sort of cooperation the Government will get there. Secondly, the measures do nothing to address the imbalance between the public and private health systems. The hospital industry—as I said before, both public and private, coming together in an unprecedented way—has called on the Government to address the issue of encouraging people to go into private health insurance.

Doctors, the private health insurers and health experts have all been saying that what is required to restore the imbalance between the public and private sectors is a system of tax incentives to take out private health insurance. The press happened to pick up in a selective way—as some members of it do—on Mr Baulderstone from the Australian Hospitals Association, which represents 800 public hospitals, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the funding increase for public hospitals would greatly help to reduce waiting lists.
That was reported, but, wait, what else did he say? He said:
But it was only a short-term measure and the government had not attempted to deal with longer-term issues such as the future of the private hospital and private health insurance industries.
It is so easy to choose the first sentence and not go on and say that he added that it was a short term measure and, as we have seen, it most probably is not a measure that will have any effect.

PARA.TAB: If the Minister bothered to go to the electorate of Burke in Victoria—and they might invite him to go—and, as I did two weeks ago, visit the Melton Private Hospital, the Bacchus Marsh Public Hospital, the Daylesford Public Hospital and the Trentham Bush Nursing Hospital, what would they say, to a hospital? The four of them, representing private and public, say that we need to encourage people into the private health insurance system. That is what they are saying.

People told me at Bacchus Marsh that in 1983, 75 per cent of their patients were privately insured. What do they have today? Today, 25 per cent of their patients are privately insured. They cannot make their budget. They stopped operating towards the end of the financial year because they cannot give a service. They are not getting in the money from the private sector. They told me that what we need is a system that encourages people into private health insurance. That was repeated again and again at Daylesford, at Trentham and at Melton. If the Minister goes out and talks to the people, to the CEOs, to the chairmen of the boards running those hospitals, they will tell him what we need. They will tell him exactly what their peak body is saying: that what we need is encouragement for people to go into private health insurance.

No-one with any knowledge of our health system has suggested that an increase in the Medicare levy is the answer to our health woes. These loopy ideas have stemmed from one source in Western Australia. Up until now, we thought anyone with any commonsense would laugh at the idea of nationalising the health system in Australia, but from what we saw last night a nationalised health system is certainly on the Labor Government's agenda.

A number of surveys have been conducted recently showing support for tax incentives to take out private insurance. There have been calls by hospitals, both public and private, to encourage private health insurance. The Government has not heeded this advice. Last year the health Minister attempted to introduce a co-payment for general practitioner consultations. Mr Howe had to squirm his way out of that. Why did he have to squirm his way out of that? It was because the policy was changed so that Mr Keating could buy a few votes for his leadership last year.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you know exactly what I mean by that. Votes were bought and Mr Howe had to squirm his way out of it and change tack, scrapping the co-payment which was going to save Australia in the order of $1.64 billion over a period of four years: $164m in the first year; $306m in the second year; $480m in the third year; and $695m in the fourth year. It was also a price signal to operate as a way of reducing overservicing and undue demand on the health system. That is what it cost the Australian public for that vote. In contrast, the coalition has identified the problems and is not just going to tinker at the edges.

I nearly choked on my Weeties this morning when I was listening to AM. I heard the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—I am not allowed to use the word `lie'; I am not allowed to use the word `liar'; I can use the word `untruth'—blatantly mislead the Australian public on national radio, on the ABC, when he said that under us there would be no Medicare. Most probably all my colleagues heard him say that. What he said was totally untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said to my wife it was a damned lie.

—Senator Calvert might have said it was a lie, but I am not allowed to say that in here; so I say that what he said was untrue. He misled the Australian public. Every Australian should have choked on their Weeties or their Cornflakes or whatever they were eating because it was just the same furphy and the same untruth that the Prime Minister and his colleagues go around saying over and over and over. What he said is not true. We will retain Medicare and bulkbilling for pensioners and other beneficiaries. That is the truth. I ask the Prime Minister to tell the truth about our health policy. If he is going to talk about our health policy, he ought to read it in the first place and not go around telling untruths about it.

PARA.TAB: Only the coalition will address the fundamental problem of the structural imbalance in our system, that is, the imbalance between the private and the public system. We are going to reduce the burden on public hospitals and increase the utilisation of private hospitals. We will do this by encouraging people to take out private health insurance. Private health insurance tax credits will be directed at the aged and low and middle income earners. Senator Walters will be talking about that. High income earners, many of whom currently escape paying for their own health, will be required to take out private health insurance or they will be liable to pay a surcharge on their Medicare levy.

Last night we saw the Minister having to raise the Medicare levy because he was rolled on the Medicare co-payment. The savings in that co-payment would have provided more funds for use in the hospital system than the rise in the Medicare levy. What we got last night was Howe's second option because he lost on the first. Unlike the coalition's policy, which will restore the balance between the public and private system, the measures announced last night will do nothing to address the problems and will result only in more long term problems. On all counts, this Labor Government, through the Prime Minister's behaviour this morning on the radio in telling a furphy, an untruth, and through the policy announced last night, has failed Australians yet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the announcements made in the Budget last night, including the vitalising structural reform of the health care system which goes under the proud title of Medicare and which has been adopted by the Australian people as a health care system of which they can be extremely proud. The modifications which were announced last night will only enhance the affection with which the Medicare system is held in Australia, not only in an emotional sort of way but in actual delivery of better health care services for the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that we are not obsessed with Medicare as a health financing system. We want to see it evolve more clearly into a health care system with all components of the medical and hospital treatment systems being brought together in a way which serves Australians better. That is why we are not as obsessed as the Opposition clearly is with the question of private health insurance as a means of financing the health care system. We prefer, as I will elaborate later, a system of raising money for the health care system which is not so dependent on private health insurance premiums but is properly dependent on a fairer distribution of the costs, through the tax and Medicare levy system, amongst the Australian people. That can then provide a health care system which is open to all Australians.

It is in relation to access to public hospitals that most attention has been focused. There is certainly a need to ensure that the public hospital system in Australia is not allowed to run down, as it undoubtedly would under the Opposition's scheme, and is instead given the capacity, through funding and other arrangements, to provide for the health care needs of Australians. That has to be a provision of services, including hospital treatment and medical treatment in outpatients and so on—but hospital bed days are of particular importance. Access to beds must be based on clear, clinical assessment and needs and without any temptation for public hospitals in the allocation of beds to prefer in a discriminatory way those with private health insurance.

We will be providing a bonus of $1.23 billion over the next six years to those public hospitals which cooperate. Of course, this will be a cooperative and collaborative endeavour; it will not be imposed. It will be a cooperative endeavour with the States and Territories and their public hospital systems in order to ensure that all those who wish to avail themselves of public hospital treatment will be able to without having the fear that they will not be able to get a bed. I believe it is that fear that they may not be able to get a bed, which was alluded to by Senator Patterson, which drives many of them to take out private health insurance at a level at which they might otherwise not choose to do.

There is no argument that Australians should be free to take out private insurance if they wish to do so, but they should not be driven to it by fear that the public hospital system will not be able to provide them with the bed they require when they need hospital treatment. The fact is that by providing this extra funding to the public hospital system we will be able to provide that capacity, and therefore that fear will evaporate, whereas the Opposition will not provide the same level of funding for public hospitals. It will decrease funding to public hospitals because it needs to provide money for the subsidies it will pay to certain levels of income earners in Australia for their private insurance premiums. Those subsidies have to come from the taxpayers. If the subsidies are paid for in the scale of the hundreds of millions that will be required, then that is money that will not be made available directly to the public hospitals through the States grants system.

The Australian people are faced with a clear choice between the Government's proposal that the public hospital system be revitalised by direct injection of funds from the taxpayers or the coalition's proposal that taxpayers' funds go to subsidise private health insurance premiums. Private health insurance premiums will certainly need to be subsidised because we know that those private health insurance premiums will have to rise to meet the costs of the health care system. They will escalate because the Opposition, in its market driven ideology, will allow the AMA of course to set much higher rates than it mostly charges at the moment for general practitioner consultations and for other medical services. We could expect that private hospitals will also try to charge what the market might bear. Health insurance premiums will have to rise to try to alleviate some of the financial pain that will thereby be occasioned.

The honourable senator who wrote the letter to the President putting forward this matter of public importance spoke occasionally in terms of an ideological obsession by the Labor Party. I do not believe that is a fair characterisation at all of the position of the Labor Party. I find it very peculiar that a party which prides itself on freedom of choice as one of its ideological planks—I believe it is a good platform within the Australian community that people should be free to choose—has, for example, within its own health care provision proposals said to doctors that they will not be able to offer bulkbilling to Australians unless they are pensioners or cardholders. So a medical practitioner conducting a general practice in a suburb, city or rural area will not be able to make that choice as to how he or she wishes to fund the practice by bulkbilling. That is really quite an extraordinary denial of the freedom of choice of doctors within the system. I believe therefore that the ideological purity being claimed for the Opposition in these matters is very severely undermined.

It is very true that the problem of effective waiting list management and reduction is an absolutely key issue for many in the community. It is also the case that we do not have a clear picture of the situation, despite the figures that are sometimes bandied around by Senator Patterson. I believe that Victoria—Senator Patterson would be aware of this; it is to Victoria's credit—is the only State which has a very clear picture available of the waiting list situation. We need to provide funds to those areas—also those specialty areas, not only geographic areas—where waiting lists are particularly long. That means that we cannot have an Australia-wide approach; it will obviously have to be sensitively directed and differentially allocated to various areas.

Quite clearly, administrative procedures need to be enhanced so that there can be better administrative marshalling of the booking and management of waiting times. There will also have to be processes to enable the opening of theatres and surgical wards, the employing of additional support staff using spare capacity in private hospitals and the promoting of greater use of day surgery for some procedures and so on in a way which will help to reduce the waiting lists. For that reason, some $50m has been allocated in 1992-93 and almost $21m in the following year to allow hospitals to put better procedures in place to enable those waiting lists to be reduced. I believe that these key measures are absolutely essential and will be very welcomed.

The Government makes no apology for the decision announced in the Budget last night to impose an extra 0.14 per cent on the taxable income of persons above a certain threshold in order to raise the levy from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent of taxable income. The basic difference between the Government and the Opposition is that, in order to provide more funds for the health care system in Australia, the Opposition believes that the best way to do that is to work through the private health insurance funds—in other words, by way of the contribution of premiums from people, some of which will have to be subsidised, on their own admission in Fightback, to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars by the taxpayers. I am sure that Senator Herron would not deny that.

The Opposition sees the best way of providing more funds for the health care system is through the private health insurance system. We have a different view that Australians are prepared to accept. This will be done not through private health insurance which, by definition, means that the premium is paid regardless of the income status of the person and therefore subsidies might be needed for the very low income groups. We say that the contribution to the health care of fellow Australians and for oneself can be more equitably provided through raising the Medicare levy, which we provided for last night, and through the taxation system—in other words, through a progressive system which depends on capacity and ability to pay. I believe that that more egalitarian approach for those only who have the capacity to pay for their health care and those of their fellow Australians is a far fairer system than the private health insurance scheme that the Opposition proposes.

The Medicare levy that is proposed only has to be paid by individuals who earn over $11,887 and by married couples who have a combined income of $20,070, with provision for extra dependent children of $2,100 per dependent child. It means that a family of two adults and two children with an earning capacity of, say, $580 per week will pay an extra 87c per week. That is not an extravagant amount to enable the Government to put forward this very comprehensive package which will allow for the refurbishing and upgrading of the capacity of the public health system so that those who require hospital treatment in the public health system can have the confidence that a bed will be available. That increase in the Medicare levy will raise $300m in 1993-94 and will contribute to the expansion of the hospital and hospital related care system.

I believe that when one looks at those sorts of contributions that are asked for out of the persons who have the capacity to pay—as announced last night, an increase in the levy from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent—one can see that to pay 80c, 87c, 90c, 95c or even $1 per week extra is not a lot to ask from those who have that capacity in order to provide for the health care of Australians. The Opposition is not only proposing that the tax system will provide money for the health care system, and the Medicare levy will be retained on top of the tax system, but also requiring that private health insurance premiums be taken out at an extra expense to the individuals and households.

These points that I am making are part of a much wider restructuring of Australia's primary health care system. Over the past several months very significant discussions have already taken place between the Government and the Royal College of General Practitioners—I hope that the AMA has been involved also—to ensure that we do not have a system where money is thrown at an unstructured, oversupplied system of general practice. There has been general agreement that something had to be done about the number of doctors who were entering Australia from overseas and that there ought to be a rural incentive package, worth $8m in this financial year and $15m indexed a year thereafter, to improve access to GPs in rural areas. Most Australians would recognise that, whilst it is sometimes said that there is an oversupply of doctors, it is probably a maldistribution which is of more concern. In many areas, particularly in rural and provincial parts of Australia, the availability of general practitioners is not what it ought to be if one was simply dividing the number of general practitioners into the population and getting some per capita figure.

Therefore, the Government has been very keen to ensure that in this Budget and in succeeding Budgets provision is made for the incentives to encourage doctors to practise in country and rural areas of Australia or to reward those who have already made that decision and who are already involved in the provision of primary health care for so many Australians in those rural areas.

Quite clearly, the innovations in the area of general practice, which have been the subject of much discussion in the last year. Practice accreditation and the question of local networks or divisions of general practice are also under discussion. The strengthening of locational registration arrangements to further promote and reward high quality general practice is to go ahead and we will also be reducing our reliance on overseas trained doctors. All these matters point to a more comprehensive approach than would simply be the case if one was talking about changing the health financing system from taxation plus Medicare levy and some private health insurance to an emphasis on private health insurance, such as the Opposition would propose.

This is a much more comprehensive matter than simply financing; it is a question of health care for all Australians. In particular, stronger primary health care sector provision through general practitioners of a high quality is an obvious way in which we can make the necessary emphasis to improve health care for Australians.

I believe that what was proposed in the Budget last night will be acceptable to most Australians because most Australians want the public hospital system to continue. They want to see it strengthened. They do not like to see the public hospitals in their local cities or towns run down, lacking the capacity to undertake even capital works planning of a sophisticated kind, let alone the provision of such capital works to increase the physical provision of the public hospitals concerned. They certainly want to know that, if they have an accident or need to receive treatment within the public hospital system, a bed will be available.

The $1.23 billion to be provided over the next six years, combined with the attack on waiting lists, will, I think, alleviate much of the fear and misgiving which has perhaps got some hold in the public mind. I believe that what is being proposed will also be supported as a fair way to distribute the costs of enhancing the provision of health care for Australians. The levy system, based as it is on ability to pay—over a certain threshold you have to pay, but below that threshold you are not required to pay—I think is a fair system which appeals to the sense of fairness of Australians, as opposed to a system which depends so heavily, as the Opposition's package does, on private health insurance premiums which, of course, have to be paid by all, regardless of their income.

In relation to the low income earners, the Opposition will move hundreds of millions of dollars from taxpayers to the private health insurance funds by way of subsidies to those low income earners to take out insurance. We prefer to see the money moved from the taxpayers direct to the public hospitals, to the enhancement of the provision of primary health care by general practitioners and the provision of health care services particularly in rural areas, and in so many other ways restructure the health system in a way which will benefit all Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have before us today is the Opposition indulging in one of its regular Medicare bashes. What we really should be doing today is looking at the Budget's statements on health, looking for the holes—and yes, there are some—and looking for some positive initiatives. In particular, I commend the first national mental health policy, albeit many years too late. I also commend, in particular, in the area of general practice, the move to put some $8m into a rural incentives program, which has already been mentioned, to ensure that GPs in rural areas gain additional support.

PARA.TAB: Instead of looking constructively and sensibly at a health system that, despite its faults—and I certainly acknowledge that it has some—is one of the best and one of the most cost-effective systems in the world, the Opposition is once again putting on its ideological blinkers, ignoring the available evidence and data and trying to convince us of how wonderful the health care system will be when it finally succeeds in largely destroying Medicare as we know it.

It does not take much figuring out to realise that it really would not be that wonderful at all. It is pretty clear that just about everybody except the Opposition, the AMA and the private health insurance funds—we must acknowledge that there is some self-interest in there—sees that what the Opposition is proposing will result in spiralling costs and reduced services. As I have said before on this topic, I find it ironic that, at a time when many countries are looking to our system here, to a greater commitment to universal public health care to overcome the problems of their totally private systems, the Opposition in this country is determined to move in quite the opposite direction.

Indeed, the Opposition's health policies represent a giant leap backwards. If you want to see the future of health care under a Hewson Government, take a look at the United States and its appalling and very costly health system—a health system that has one of the highest rates of infant mortality anywhere in the Western World.

I acknowledge that the debate about the provision of health services is partly one of philosophical or ideological differences, but it is also a debate which needs to move beyond ideological posturing and blatant self-interest if we are to seriously address and remedy the problems in our health care system. The continuing calls for the abolition of Medicare, premised on vested interests, should not have a place in this debate. For example, I note the response of Bruce Shepherd of the AMA to the Budget measures. Dr Shepherd is being his usual constructive self, foreshadowing that doctors are going to battle with the Federal Government in what he persists in seeing as the Government trying to take control of the health system.

Looking through the Budget Papers, I do not see this as the Government's aim, although as I have said before, there are some compelling arguments in favour of Medicare becoming the national insurer. But even if we grant that there is a little too much influence on the part of the Government, Dr Shepherd obviously expects us to believe that putting himself and his colleagues in the private insurance industry in control of the health system would somehow give us a much better system and would be a good idea. That is what the Opposition agrees with. It has said to the AMA that it can fix its own fees and that that would be wonderful, and that somehow the all-curing free market will operate to make sure that those fees remain at a reasonable level. That is just nonsense.

Aside from the obvious and demonstrable fact that market signals are undermined by the distinctive nature of the health care system and simply do not work in this context, what is there to convince Australians that giving the medical profession and the private insurers even greater control of the health dollar than they already have would be a better idea than letting Dracula loose in the blood bank?

I remind honourable senators that, at the same time as the AMA was bleating about the costs of Medicare, it was running a case before the New South Wales Industrial Commission arguing for a pay rise in excess of 50 per cent for the 2,700 specialists who act as visiting medical officers in that State's public hospital system, thereby resulting in an additional $100m per year being paid from public funds into the pockets of specialists already earning between $127.50 and $135.50 an hour. So how committed are they really to the public health system, and to the public hospital system in particular? Australian health consumers would be perfectly entitled to ask whether these specialists were more concerned with the protection of their not inconsiderable incomes than with improving access to, and use of, the public health system.

I do not think anybody in this country begrudges doctors and specialists a very good income. I certainly do not. I do not think there are many people around who want to see the system nationalised in any sense. They do not want to see every doctor on a salary. What Australians do want is a responsible and comprehensive health care system. I believe that they will not continue to tolerate the sort of strident self-interest advocated by Dr Shepherd and a few others at the expense of the overall health system.

Medicare continues to be popular with the Australian public. It is very hard to think of another Government program or, indeed, a private program that is as popular, that enjoys such widespread support. As I have repeatedly said when talking about Medicare, it is not hard to see why it continues to be popular. On any objective analysis—one that is not blinkered by ideology or vested interests—Medicare has, despite its problems, provided Australians with equitable access to relatively cheap health care.

The provision of free services via Medicare has protected low income households from the costs of basic health care, that is, GP services, hospital care and prescriptions. The national health strategy paper Spending on Health concludes that free, or certainly low cost, basic health care protects low income persons with little capacity to pay even small out-of-pocket costs and high users. Those high users include some people with disabilities, the chronically ill and some members of our ageing community. These are people whose out-of-pocket expenses would mount up very quickly.

Australians understand, as previous speakers have mentioned, that they do not receive their health care for nothing; they know that it comes out via the levy. They are quite well aware that they pay for it through that and also through general taxation. The continuing support for Medicare by the Australian community does justify the moves that the Government has taken in this Budget in relation to the levy.

The Democrats welcome the Government's reaffirmation of its commitment to Medicare, although we do not think that the Government has been decisive or as forceful in many of these measures as it could have been. It is certainly very late in some measures, such as the final recognition that the State hospital system needed some extra support.

The Australian Democrats see the provision of basic health care as a desirable social and economic objective and, although we still see considerable room for improvement in the delivery of health services, we do not consider 8 per cent of gross domestic product to be a staggeringly high rate of expenditure to achieve this end. We believe that, if the Opposition and the private insurers have their way, the end result will be a much higher percentage of GDP moving towards America's 13 per cent; a much higher amount spent on health care with no corresponding improvement in any aspect of our health care system, except in the profits of private insurers.

The evidence from overseas clearly indicates that those countries where public health insurance plays a role have been the most successful in controlling their health expenditures. The Democrats do not think that it is in our interests to move away from that sort of system, and we do not believe that the Australian public wants to move away; the Australian public does not want to move away from Medicare. Within this year's Budget, the increase in the levy is something that the Democrats have wanted to see for some time. It represents an important signal to the community that the Government is clearly committed to Medicare rather than a private or even substantially private health care system.

I place on record our support for three other areas: firstly, the initiatives in the area of consumer and patient rights, the Medicare hospital patients' charter, complaints mechanisms, the enactment of legislation covering the principles of Medicare and the commitment to a national consumer advisory group for mental services; secondly, as I have already mentioned, the reforms relating to general practice and especially the rural incentives package and the funding for divisions of GPs; and, thirdly, the initiatives in the area of mental health, particularly the promotion of nationally agreed clinical standards and best practice initiatives.

Reform in this area is long overdue, and the Federal Government's reluctance to involve itself in this neglected area of health has done it absolutely no credit at all. I trust the not especially generous allocation in this Budget is a reflection of a genuine intent on the part of the Government to stop avoiding its responsibilities in this area and to play a leading role in mental health reform.

However, I move on to the negatives. I am disappointed that the Keating Government, having distanced itself from last year's co-payment debacle and supposedly committed itself to developing Medicare as a health care system rather than merely as a health financing system, has presented a health budget that does not seize the opportunity to come to grips with three areas that the Democrats have been concerned with for many years. They are dental health services, alternative therapies and preventive health programs.

In relation to dental health services, there is a small contribution, some $500,000, for the establishment of a research database to look at the supply of dental care. This is welcome and certainly long overdue, but it really is time that the issues of incorporating dental services within Medicare and the provision of extensive public dental services were seriously tackled by the Federal Government. Some State governments have been doing it. In particular, I acknowledge what the South Australian Government has achieved. The results that it has got from its schools dental program are certainly significant. But there is still a lot more to be done.

Something I would have liked to have spent more time on today is the issue of alternative therapies. That is certainly an area we need to look at. There is a range of options that need to be acknowledged. Their valuable roles should be acknowledged and they should be seen as playing a real and positive part in health treatment. Preventive health services is an area in which I worked for many years before moving into this place. If Medicare is to really become a comprehensive health system, then it must incorporate more than merely a token commitment to preventive health.

There are some very minimal bits and pieces in this Budget. There is some minimal recognition, but it is nowhere near enough. In particular, I am interested in seeing a concerted effort made to address health problems of young people—in particular, young people in our schools. It is well demonstrated that socio-economic factors are directly linked to quality of health, and this correlation receives very little, if any, recognition in the public health system. We should be looking at prevention in schools. We should be looking at projects in schools in those areas which are identified as having health problems linked with geographic, socio-economic factors. I am not talking about just more lectures, discussion and pictures on the walls. What I am talking about is daily physical education and nutritional food supplements.

In many schools in the north of Adelaide now, we have private agencies moving in and providing breakfast for young people who are going to school without anything to eat, who have nothing in their bags for lunch, and who cannot be expected to learn anything when they are hungry. So there is still a lot to be done in our basic health care system.

Having said that, I really do worry about the alternatives offered by the Liberal Party. As far as I can see—and I listened again today—they are a recipe for disaster, and I believe that the majority of Australians will reject them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word `placebo' is used in health care and its definition in the dictionary is `a medicine given to humour the patient'. I think that is a very apt description of the Budget paper brought down last night in relation to health care. Placebos are used also, to use medical terms, in double-blind trials: they are inert agents given which have no therapeutic effect but are a subterfuge to trial whether or not some mechanism is effective in producing a cure. I think that is a very apt description of the national health strategy that was established two years ago—because it has blinded everybody.

PARA.TAB: The Medicare levy's rise from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent is a 40 per cent increase since the introduction of Medicare itself. It has nothing at all to do with the funding of Medicare; it is a levy that goes to Consolidated Revenue—it goes straight into the tax bundle. It is a flat tax on taxable income. For example, a $30,000 income earner already pays income tax of $6,593.62. Previously, these people were paying another $375 tax into Consolidated Revenue. After the next election, I might say—because it does not come in until then—they will be paying an extra $420.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's if they get back.

—Yes, if they get back, because we make the promise that we will not increase that Medicare levy. At the same time that taxpayer is to pay that extra $420, supposedly, Australia spends an average of $1,796 per person on health care. So the Medicare levy does not come within a bull's roar of paying for health care. It goes straight into Consolidated Revenue and the rest comes from income taxes, State taxes and private funds. In fact, in the last eight years—and the Australian Democrats might like to take a note of this—the health funds raised $12.3 billion and the levy raised only $11.2 billion. Last year the levy raised $2 1/2 billion and the health funds raised $3.4 billion. Next year the health funds will again raise more money than the levy. Yet we have the illusion somehow that taxpayers have paid for their health care, and we have the Government and the Democrats denigrating the private health industry itself.

PARA.TAB: The private health industry is essential for the continuation of Australia's health care system. In fact, the Medicare levy was the source of only 8 per cent of health funding. Of other government funding—that is, tax revenue—35 per cent comes from Federal funding and 26 per cent comes from State and local funding: a total government funding of 69 per cent. Private health insurance funding is 11 per cent, and individuals out of their pockets pay 15 per cent. Total health expenditure last year was $30 billion—as I mentioned, $1,796 per person—and it has been on average 8 per cent of GDP over the last 16 years. It was more last year, in fact, as a percentage of GDP because of a real fall in gross domestic product as a result of the recession. Real health expenditure grew by only 3.1 per cent in 1990-91. It was lower than the average 4 per cent of the previous five years.
