The government funding of health care fell 3 per cent between February 1984 when Medicare was introduced and 1990-91 due to a fall in the Commonwealth contribution. State and local government and private expenditure increased.

Let us look at the average 8 per cent of GDP which the Government claims as a great success. That has not occurred in any other country in the OECD. The figure for OECD countries has risen over that period. We are now $740 a head below the average of the nine OECD nations—the United Kingdom, New Zealand, France, Germany, Canada, Japan, USA, Sweden and ourselves. We are $740 less per head. And we talk about a great health care system! We have not kept pace in any shape or form with our competitors.

Let us look at the $300m that is supposedly going to come with the increase in the levy. It will not even cover this year's increment in health expenditure. It would not have been necessary if Minister Howe had not been rolled last year on the introduction of co-payments in order to save Mr Keating's job.

As I previously mentioned, Federal Government expenditure has decreased. Since the introduction of Medicare in 1984, the real level of both Commonwealth hospital and general revenue grant funding has fallen by 18.7 per cent. In the same period, Australia's population has grown by 11.2 per cent. It is no wonder that the States are finding it impossible to continue underwriting the open-ended entitlements of hospital Medicare.

There are two major trends in our community. Public hospital expenditure as a proportion of total expenditure has declined substantially from 34.6 per cent in 1982-83 to 29.67 per cent in 1988-89 and even less today. That trend should dispel any preconceived notion that public hospital expenditure growth has been a major factor in increasing health costs. On the other hand, the States' share of public hospital expenditure has risen from approximately 43 per cent in 1982-83 to 48 per cent in 1989-90, and the indications are that this trend will be maintained.

While growth in public hospital costs has been significantly less than growth in other health costs, the States have not gained from this lower cost growth; the gain has gone to the Commonwealth. That has occurred because there has been a major shift of public hospital costs to the States. The result is that the States really are now the major funders of hospital Medicare. While the States have managed to date, it has been at considerable cost to other State government responsibilities. And I thought we were a States House.

However, States now face fiscal constraints which are so tight that they will be unable to top up public hospital costs due to the Medicare entitlement and decreasing use of public hospital facilities by private patients. The cost of such action in terms of other forgone State public service provisions would be too great.

My colleague Senator Patterson has already spoken about one of the most significant moves in the health sector in recent years—the Australian Private Hospitals Association and the Australian Hospitals Association banding together in an attempt to have the Federal Government rectify the serious flaws in hospital Medicare. The two organisations represent over 80 per cent of Australia's hospitals. They came together to implement what they called `Operation: Hospital Survival' to convince the Federal Government that major change is needed in Australia's hospital system.

In a joint statement, the two major hospital groups said that the last two years had seen a decline in Australia's hospital system which could no longer be tolerated. Public hospitals are being asked to provide more services with fewer resources. The demand for public hospital services is increasing dramatically because of the ageing population and the use and availability of high technology.

The private hospital system, now of the highest quality, is able to access only about one-third of the population. The situation is becoming worse by the day as Australians are forced to give up private health insurance or not to take it up, as the cost of private cover spirals in a time of economic recession. Despite that, 40 per cent of Australians are still insured and 42 per cent of Australians over 65 years of age have hospital insurance. The number of Australians now carrying private insurance has declined from 44.4 per cent only 12 months ago. It is interesting to note that more than two-thirds of them are insured with non-government health funds. This drop effectively means that another half million Australians have been forced to rely on the public hospital system in the last 12 months, adding another $128m to the States' hospital bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor compassion!

—The paradox, Senator Kemp, is that 600,000 people who are low income earners on less than $250 a week are still prepared to take out private hospital insurance while 110,000 high income earners on over $50,000 a year do not, thereby relying on the public health system.

PARA.TAB: There are three fundamental concerns which are shared by the Australian Hospitals Association and the Australian Private Hospitals Association. As I mentioned, the first is that public hospitals are under excessive pressure. Secondly, the private health funds are in a perilous financial position. Thirdly, the rising cost burden of private health insurance falls unfairly on pensioners and people on low incomes.

Both of those organisations believe that the Federal Government must radically alter the hospital financing system to ensure that pensioners and low income earners remain fully covered by Medicare whilst other Australians meet the full cost of hospital care through private insurance. What do we get from this Government? We get a placebo. We get a minuscule amount of money, no radical restructuring and no alteration of the system. We get more of the same. It is a case of `steady as she sinks'. Both the AHA and the APHA have urged the Federal Government to act quickly before the whole hospital system suffers irreparably.

Some of our public hospital buildings are a disgrace. The Royal Brisbane Hospital—the largest in Australia—conducted a survey to find out how much would need to be spent on the fabric of the place to bring it up to modern-day standards. The result was a bill of $200m. How much is being set aside in the Budget for capital expenditure? I will tell honourable senators—$30m, and $3m of that is for planning. They are going to plan what to do about it.

Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane obviously has a fatigued building syndrome problem with an uncoordinated lift system that would not be tolerated in a third world country. The Cairns Base Hospital has a greater patient throughput than the Royal Melbourne Hospital. How much is being spent on capital infrastructure there? The answer is nil.

In the past, Minister Howe has admitted that capital expenditure should be around 8 per cent of recurrent hospital expenditure. It is now around 3 per cent. This has meant an approximate $500m shortfall each year. The true cost of replacement of Australia's public hospital stock has been estimated at $700m annually. The paltry sum of $3m for planning in the 1992-93 Budget and the promise of $23.1m a year over the next five years is ludicrous.

The Budget document entitled Health Care for all Australians has been drawn up and produced by the bureaucracy in order to increase the number of bureaucrats. It is all about increasing control. I will give the Senate some examples. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: The levy measures to be pursued in developing effective waiting list management are clinical and administrative validation procedures.
It also states:
This will include steps to ensure that a patient's place in the queue is decided on the basis of clinical urgency not whether or not they are privately insured.

In other words, `The queues will be just as long or longer but we will change your position in the line because we will put in administrative arrangements to see that that occurs'. The Government spent $50m four years ago to do the same thing. What has happened in that four years? There have been longer queues and longer waiting lists. What has been the effect of $50m being thrown at the problem? There has been no effect.

PARA.TAB: The Medicare levy increase is a thimble and pea trick. At the same time as $300m more is being taken from taxpayers, they are being put another $13.4 billion into debt. Another way of putting it is that the average taxpayer will be paying $2 a week more in tax and will be borrowing another $32 a week for the pleasure of changing his or her place in the health queue. This is at a time when taxpayers are already paying the interest on a $19,000 per head overseas debt. I believe that the alternative proposed in the Budget last night is a steady-as-she-sinks Medicare system—another bandaid and transfusion into a moribund, disintegrating health care system which, though in intensive care, will be revived by the mouth to mouth resuscitation and external cardiac massage necessitated and delivered by the Fightback health policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance, the wording of which I will remind the Senate:

PARA.TAB: The need for the Senate to condemn the government for:
a)Failing to take the opportunity in the 1992/93 budget to reform the health care system presently in crisis.
b)Raising personal income tax in the form of an increase in the Medicare Levy and perpetuating the myth that Medicare provides a universal health service for all Australians.
c)Actively discouraging private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: These three allegations are based on a total misrepresentation of the position of Australia's health system in 1992 after almost a decade of Labor governments.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's policy in the Fightback program concentrates on a financing formula which seems to have very little to do with actual health care systems whereas the structural reforms which have been gradually designed over the last few years by Labor governments are developing and strengthening what is already a very fine public health system. Ours is a health policy, not a financing policy. Medicare gives rights and entitlements to all Australian citizens. Most Australians understand very well their entitlements in relation to their general practitioner care, because the vast majority periodically have need of that care.

There is uncertainty abroad about hospital Medicare. As has been raised in our Estimates committees—Senator Herron and Senator Walters will recall this—people on the whole do not understand the hospital system because few of them require to go to hospitals. In many cases, they go in as private patients when they have the option, if they wish, to go in as public patients. As has just been stated by Senator Herron, this confusion probably accounts for the vast majority of low income earners who take out private insurance in their confused state of mind about the availability of care. We are very conscious of the need to reassure these people and the rest of the community of their entitlements.

Several references have been made this afternoon to the development of a charter of rights for patients in our public hospital system. This is probably overdue and something which will be welcomed by very many people. A thorough examination of our health system has shown that over the last few years we have in many respects been able, in cooperation with the States, to design a new health system to overcome many of the difficulties of previous years. We can now look forward to restructured health systems which will, in the very near future, provide an even better and stronger health system for Australian people.

Medicare belongs to all, but everybody should know the rules. We believe that the charter of patient rights will make the position much plainer for the majority of Medicare patients. I have just referred to the fact that we have had splendid cooperation from the States in many respects in this restructuring process.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Western Australia?

—Even in Western Australia. Senator Walters needs to concentrate on more than the headlines if she wants to know what is going on in Western Australia. I have great pleasure in telling her that the State Government has been able to agree to many of the proposals put to it by the Federal Government. In fact, we are anticipating from all the States reciprocal legislation similar to that which has been achieved in the disability field that will enshrine the principles referred to already today, not only by the Government speakers.

PARA.TAB: People's access to hospital care and/or procedures should not be on the basis of their financial situation but on clinical criteria. Senator Herron seemed to think that this was a very strange way to go. I am afraid that I cannot agree with him. He seemed to insist that this would do nothing whatsoever to reduce waiting lists. Clinical criteria certainly identifies the patients who should have priority, but there are many other ways in which the assistance being provided by the Federal Government may make it easier for hospitals to reduce their waiting lists. It does not take a great deal of imagination to agree that, in many cases, maybe more staff or day surgery is required, the introduction of day surgery where none has been undertaken is necessary and that beds can be contracted out to the private system where we hear there are empty beds—though I understand that in many cases there are fewer than there have been in the past.

I draw the attention of the Senate to a number of extremely important elements in our restructuring of hospital care—hospital care being just one part of the health system. These matters have been raised in the Senate before, but perhaps a little reminder will not go astray. I make these comments in view of the fact that we know there will be an increase of 29 per cent in public hospital admissions in the next decade and that many health reforms we are introducing will be paid for by the increase in the levy. As has been pointed out by Senator Herron, the levy certainly does not pay for Medicare; the public pays for it. I do not think that will come as a surprise to most people.

Some reference has been made to waiting list management. In 1992-93, $50m will be available, and $20.9m available in the following year, to increase the number of patients treated and to achieve targeted reductions and better waiting list management procedures and performance monitoring. Public hospitals will not have to wait for another year for some assistance in moving towards the other innovations to which I have referred.

An amount of $3m will be allotted to help the States manage their capital stock better and to shift health services to where they are most needed. In many cases, it is a matter of maldistribution rather than a sheer lack of facilities. A further $116m will be allotted over the following five years. Not every case of maldistribution will need a vast amount of funding to fix it. In many cases, it will simply mean better design and better management. A substantial proportion of these funds will be allocated to capital works in the mental health sector. As was remarked upon earlier today, we have for the first time a national mental health policy in Australia. This will be implemented over the next six years. Once again, this could only come about because of the cooperation of the State governments.

In relation to the mental health program, there will be a considerable need for increased accommodation for mental health patients being moved out of institutions. This is where this plan melds very neatly with the availability of funding from the better cities program, to make sure that proper planning goes into the location of these patients in communities to the benefit of the individuals concerned and not to the detriment of the communities.

Area health management is a principle accepted by most of the State governments, including the Western Australian Government, which has a pilot project operating at the moment in three areas. There are three pilot projects which provide a range of options, one of which, or a variation of any one of the three, will be adopted by the Western Australian Government. Demonstration projects are being conducted all over the nation. These are also getting assistance in financial terms from the Federal Government.

Clinical budgeting will occur and again there will be demonstration projects showing how devolving budgets within hospitals to clinical units might lead to better health care decisions and more effective use of resources. This is what we have been talking about with the State governments for some years now. We have talked about the better use of resources and not just extra dollars. Many of the hospital administrators—even those who took part in the exercise to which Senator Herron referred—admit that it is not extra money they need. They need better management, the capacity to make a different range of decisions and assistance, sometimes financial, but not only financial.

As far as case mix development is concerned, I am sure you will remember, Madam Acting Deputy President, when we did a review of private nursing homes and private hospitals that we did a study on diagnostic related groups. Diagnostic related groups have grown up; they are now called case-mix development and the Government is providing funding over the next four years to extend the current work on case mix, leading to better decisions on the use of hospital funding and the promotion of best practice care.

I now turn to quality assurance which is probably the overriding principle that must be emphasised time and time again. We must develop practice guidelines for diagnosis, treatment and management, with a focus on the outcomes of care quality measurement. This will receive further funding over the next few years.

That is the hospital system, but, in addition, our restructuring and reform has included important measures, some of which have come out of this most recent Budget. The sum of $149m will be provided over the next four years, removing the freeze on benefits paid to State government nursing homes after appropriate offsets are provided by State governments. When I look around I discover that four members of that select committee are in this chamber and this is an issue that is very close to our hearts as well.

The Government will enable aged care assessment teams to purchase crucial care services for frail aged people as a key link between hospital and other services. This will ensure that there is that communication between the services, that services are used most appropriately, that elderly people are not forced to stay in hospital after recovering from acute episodes and they are able to find more appropriate supportive care where it is needed. Multipurpose services to deal with the needs of remote areas will be provided and general practice has also been referred to.

I would have to say that the only things we have been offered in the Opposition's policy simply do not add up to reforms. They do not add up to even a cursory approach to reforming the system. The Opposition gives a financing formula which will reduce our excellent system of health insurance to something resembling the inequitable United States system. By comparison with this Government's plans, the Opposition would deprive the public system of $8 billion over five years. According to its own Fightback program, $1.3 billion less per year would be spent on the public hospital system. Obviously, under that policy—if honourable senators opposite have the opportunity to implement it and I certainly hope that they never do—the public system would also be missing out on the $1.6 billion that this Government has guaranteed to the system over the next five years.

On the other hand, Commonwealth outlays on health would rise by an estimated $395m per annum on 1991-92 prices. That amount is just Commonwealth outlays and the total national expenditure on health would blow out at a great rate because of the enormously inflationary effects of giving carte blanche to dictate to doctors and private insurance companies. Fees could be dictated by doctors because their own recommended schedule would effectively be underwritten by private insurance and there would be no limit. There would be no cap and in fact the sky would be the limit as to what would be charged.

As an example, the schedule fee for a standard GP consultation would rise from $23.50 to at least $31. All those people who had been forced into the private system and persuaded to take out basic table insurance would find that it did not even cover their bed charge. At the moment the daily benefits available under the basic table average $185, yet bed, day and other charges in private hospitals average $335 a day. Even insured patients would have to find a considerable amount of money. They will continue to use public hospitals and the whole system will be in enormous disarray if ever the coalition plan is implemented. By no stretch of the imagination can this Opposition manifesto be anything more than a financing formula, and a bad formula at that.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the Senate today is the result of an acknowledgment by the Government that Medicare is just not working. All it is doing is adding a few more bandaids. Our particular concern is that while the Government has made that acknowledgment, it has failed to take advantage of this Budget to overcome the problems.

PARA.TAB: We all know that the hospital system is in crisis. All the people on the waiting lists realise that and the Government has failed once again. Every time the Government perceives a problem, the knee-jerk reaction is to throw more money at it. The Government does not step back and ask, `How will we overcome these problems? What causes the problems? How will we overcome it?' It is a matter of the Government upping the tax, charging an additional tax and throwing more money at it. Of course, the Government has a great problem with its ideology.
I will read from Budget Paper No. 8 just put out by the Government which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare was established so that all people, regardless of their location, age or health status could enter the health care system as equals.
That is fair enough. It goes on to say:
Since its introduction in 1984, Medicare has guaranteed access to public hospital services. . .

That is so untrue. The people of Australia know what the waiting lists are like and, for the Government to say in its Budget paper that since 1984 Medicare has guaranteed access, is just part and parcel of the Government's fabrication in this area.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley knows that. She was the chairman of a committee which heard evidence of the very large waiting lists, and yet in the Budget paper the Government says that it has guaranteed access to public hospitals for everyone in Australia. It goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: Medicare is based on five principles:
.universality
.access
.equity
.efficiency; and
.simplicity. . .
I agree with universality. I do not agree with access. No-one could claim it guarantees access. Indeed, the Government has acknowledged that it does not, because over the page it says:
In essence, we need an improved hospital system that increases public access. . .
It goes on to state:
The Budget package recognises. . . reforms which will enhance significantly access to services. . .

The Government knows that access was not part of Medicare. The next principle is equity. The Government also knows that equity is not part of Medicare. The Government has come out with the odd little phrase that that, too, will alter. There will be more equity in the revised Medicare.

PARA.TAB: Medicare is based on five principles and I will agree with the principle of universality. None of us agree with access or equity. Efficiency is another principle, but Senator Herron has spoken today of the inefficiencies presently in public hospitals and the lack of finance that creates those inefficiencies. The final principle is simplicity and I agree it is simple, all right. It is so simple that everybody pays. Forty per cent of the community pay twice and the people who really need it cannot get in. That particular quotation from the Budget is so inaccurate it really is appalling.

Let me deal first with access and then I will get on to our main priority, and that is equality. As I say, the Government has recognised the problem of access. For years it has acknowledged that. In his election speech in 1987, Mr Hawke, then Prime Minister, gave $25m to overcome the hospital queues. What happened in the 1988-89 Budget? The Government decided to give a bit more. I will read what was said:

SPEECH.PARA: The second major initiative is an expanded program of hospital funding involving expenditure of $3,000 million in 1988-89. . .
This will be devoted to providing more public hospital beds, shortening hospital queues.

What happened to the $25m that was to do away with hospital queues in 1987 that, in the next year's Budget of 1988-89, the Government felt it had to put another $3,000m into shortening hospital queues again? Is it not time that the Government learnt that it cannot keep throwing money at a failed system, and that it has to look at the reasons for its failure and overcome those reasons?

PARA.TAB: Since 1988-89, and since Mr Hawke's speech of 1987, what has happened? Hospitals have continued the go down the drain and have continued to close hospital beds, and the waiting lists have got longer. Between Bob Hawke's promise of that $25m, and the conclusion of that Budget year with the provision of the additional $3,000m—all to stop the waiting lists—those waiting lists in Western Australia grew by 47 per cent.

Before I look at New South Wales and the latest figures there, I come to Senator Crowley's Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. In 1991, that Committee was told there were 75,000 Australians at any one time on the waiting lists of public hospitals. Let us look at New South Wales. In New South Wales in 1990, 23,196 people were booked on the waiting list. A year later, there was a 4.3 per cent increase. As for the waiting times, there was a 10.5 per cent increase in the number of those who were waiting six months or more. Not only were the queues extended, but also the waiting times increased.

What is this Government's response to that? Throw more money in.One would think the Government would have learned in 1987; one would think it had learned in 1988-89; but again, in 1992-93, we get the same old response, `We'll throw more money in'. This time it is putting in, as Senator Herron said, $3m just to plan the deal. One would have thought the Government would have learnt. But, no. It has not learnt. It has allocated $3m just to plan how it is going to spend this extra money from the Medicare levy increase.

What is going to be the result of this increase? Right from the beginning we have had Dr Blewett saying that there would not be an increase. On 10 August this year he said there would not be an increase. Bob Hawke said, `It would only hurt the low income people'. But there we are, we still have the increase coming in.

We are really hitting the poor and the pensioners.I do not know whether Senator Crowley and Senator Giles realise that there are presently 316,000 people on an income of less than $160 a week—that is, less than $8,320 per year—subscribing to private health care schemes. There are 316,800 who, on an income of $8,000-odd, say, `Medicare is not good enough for me. I am terrified I will not be able to get into hospital when I want to', and 23 per cent of that group of people on that income privately insure. How they do it, I do not know. How do they struggle to pay their private health costs?

We have 28.6 per cent of people on an income of $12,428. That is not a big income; that is a very low income. They also struggle to pay their private health care costs. Indeed, there are 2,293,600 health card holders privately insured because, for them, Medicare is not good enough. They are terrified of being left out. It is appalling, and this Government says that it has compassion. Compassion? It would not know what it was about.

This Government has said, `We will agree with the ACTU that we will give an increase of $10 a week to low income earners'. Does anyone know what that does? That makes those low income earners eligible to pay the Medicare levy. A family presently on $24,270 and presently not paying any levy, given its generous $10 a week by the Government and the unions, will be paying $104 in Medicare levy per year. The people on $24,300 a year presently paying $6 a year levy will be paying $110 when they get their $10 a week increase. Not much left out of their increase, is there? Yet we had Senator Crowley publicly saying the other day that low income earners will not be affected by the increase. What hypocrisy. These low income earners who are being given the $10 a week will be put into the levy paying bracket and they will be paying this levy.

Why can the Government not see that it does not work? The aim, of course, is to get rid of the private system. We have had the Jenny Macklin report and it has been a concerted effort all the way down the line.

Under our policy, we will retain Medicare for all who want it. We will make sure that the low income earners if, and only if, they wish to insure, will be assisted. We will give all those single people over 65—this does not only cope with those who already believe Medicare does not deal with their circumstance and who struggle to privately insure—earning under $12,000 $400 dollars, and we will give $800 to those married people who earn under $14,500 to help them pay for their private insurance.

However, we do similar things for all low income earners, not only those aged over 65. Although I am running out of time, I would like to press home carefully the ideology of the Government. The Government says, `Give everyone equal hospital treatment'. But what it does is give that treatment to the wealthy. We will not encourage the wealthy to use Medicare. We will say to the wealthy, `If you do not privately insure, if you do not get out of the public hospital system'—and that applies to honourable senators opposite—`and allow for a pensioner, then you will be levied and you will have to pay dearly for it'. Those opposite who do not privately insure take from the pensioners and the low income groups so that they go to the bottom of the list. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot tell you, Madam Acting Deputy President, the delight I take in the Opposition serving me up an opportunity to have this debate. I believe that I could have had it late in the last session but, one way or another, I did not. Yet the Opposition has had the courage to come in here and say, `Listen, Government, tell us about your new Medicare policies'. We are proud and delighted to talk about Medicare anywhere, any time and any place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters closed her contribution by saying, `We will keep Medicare'. Does she think it will change once she owns it? I will tell the Senate why the Opposition is keeping Medicare. First, the Opposition wants the money; secondly, it wants to keep the name because it knows people like Medicare; and, thirdly, it will keep Medicare because it is universal and the Opposition will not have to deal with what it had to deal with under Mr Fraser—two million Australians uninsured and burdened with health costs. That is what the Opposition will do; that is why it will keep Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —You dreadful fibber!

—Senator Walters just told us the Opposition will keep Medicare. Madam Acting Deputy President, you can bet the Opposition will do that because it knows how good Medicare is, and that is what we will tell the people of Australia. The Opposition's policy is appalling. Medicare is great and the Opposition likes it so much that it will keep it. Senator Walters says the Opposition will keep Medicare. I thank her for telling us. That will make a good little flier. I will pop it around the place.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition also told us about waiting lists. This is a bit of a challenge. Senator Patterson is usually thoughtful and accurate. She says that 75,000 to 100,000 people are on the waiting list. I refer Senator Patterson to page 12 of the health supplements in her own document called Fightback! in which the Opposition actually assesses the waiting list at 60,000.

What has happened? Has the Labor Government been so good that it has reduced the waiting list from 100,000 to 60,000 in a mere two years? I do not know. Either Medicare is fantastic or the figures were dubious in the first place. Certainly Senator Patterson does not know her own book. The Opposition goes around saying that the waiting list is 75,000 to 100,000, but its own document says that it is 60,000.
I have often heard in this place, and I have certainly had it argued to me on radio, that there are no spare private beds out there—
Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! Opposition senators have previously had a chance to speak; I think they should let Senator Crowley say what she wants to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Patterson should know that she should not let me go last, especially not on Medicare. If I mention the word `Medicare' to people in this country, they know that this Labor Government introduced it and the people love it.

PARA.TAB: A very interesting point is raised in this very same Fightback! document. It is often argued that one will be able to do all the sorts of things the Opposition claims by moving private patients to private hospitals with private insurance because there are lots of private beds out there. However, some people have been arguing with me over the radio in recent times that there is not much spare capacity in private hospitals. Opposition senators had better make up their minds because, according to their document, private hospitals have an average occupancy rate of only 55 per cent to 60 per cent. The Opposition knows full well that the beds are out there. They are underutilised, not necessarily because people are moving away from private insurance but because under the previous Liberal Government there were too many beds built in the late 1970s and early 1980s when there was a quick dollar in private health and private hospitals. That is absolutely true because the figures from that same report Senator Walters quoted show that in private hospitals there has been more occupancy and more services under Medicare than before. That is pretty hard to deal with, Senator Patterson.

Senator Patterson got it wrong about Minister Brian Howe. He is quite right to say that there is no point in throwing money at things if one does not do the necessary structural adjustment. He has done that. That is why it is now reasonable to postulate raising the levy once those structural rearrangements, particularly the restructuring of general practice, were in place. Senator Patterson knows, as well as I do, that she was selectively quoting. I will not get too upset about that—it is par for the course in here—but some Opposition senators were getting upset about it earlier. So I am perfectly prepared to try to play that game too.

Senator Herron and Senator Patterson wanted to know what happened when we spent $50m on waiting lists. At least Senator Herron has the grace, I am sure, to know the answer—the numbers on the waiting lists dropped. The $50m made a significant difference to the waiting lists. The number of people waiting on those lists fell because that money could be targeted to buying the services of specialists, buying new operating theatres and buying specialists' staff. The only thing we did not need to provide were beds. We have too many beds in this country. Everybody who really knows about health care knows that. Senator Herron would certainly know it. We have far too many beds and most of them are in the private sector, where under the Fightback package there would be no restraint on how they were used or what their supply was.

The public hospital systems in our States, instead of being bagged and charged with `being in crisis stage' by the Opposition, should be acknowledged for the very great efficiencies that they have achieved. As Budget Paper No. 8, Health Care for all Australians: 1992-93 Reforms, states:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990-91—the last year for which utilisation data are available—public patient bed days were 61 per cent of total bed days.
Public patient admissions in 1990-91 totalled 2,075,349—an increase of 8.93 per cent over 1989-90.

There has been a dramatic increase in the number of services provided in both our public and private hospitals. Senator Herron has acknowledged that. This dramatic increase came from a system that some senators opposite want to call `crisis ridden'. It is not `crisis ridden'. It is very effective, but it is quite clear that the principles of Medicare that apply to general practice need to be extended further into our hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's just because the population has increased.
—I will quote to Senator Herron since he teases me:

SPEECH.PARA: `There has been a 16 per cent growth in population and a 30 per cent increase in hospital admissions over the last decade; bed days have remained relatively stable largely due to improvements in clinical techniques; and service organisations have seen patients being treated more efficiently'.

Yet so far nobody in here has acknowledged the benefits of same day surgery or the tremendous technological improvements or skills of our surgeons. That is one of the principal reasons why we have had more throughput in our hospitals. In fact, throughput is one way that we can measure efficiency but, at exactly the same time, that very throughput is causing an increase in demand. Until people understand the complexity of this and stop telling those dreadful stories about a public hospital system in crisis—which are not true—we will never have people in this country being able to properly debate Medicare.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken to very senior people in the New South Wales Public Health Department. They tell me that one could roughly say that about a million patients in a year attend the public hospital system in New South Wales. About 50 per cent of those come in as accidents and emergencies—in old-fashioned language, casualties. They are dealt with within 24 hours—in effect, straightaway. If one looks at the other 50 per cent one sees that about 49.7 or 49.8 per cent are treated within two weeks. About 25,000 patients throughout the whole of New South Wales—and Senator Walters confirms those figures—are on that waiting list. I concur that the concern is not the number of people on the waiting list but the time people have to wait. I agree that waiting for six months to a year, particularly when that is getting towards the year, for many procedures is not acceptable. That is why the Government is seriously addressing, yet again, the problem of trying to reduce waiting lists.

We have already seen in the Illawarra region of New South Wales a contracting of public patients to private beds with a special list that has seen a dramatic reduction in the waiting times for people—older folk in particular—with eye surgery requirements. Under Medicare contracts, that is exactly what happened. Medicare contracts solved that problem. Medicare contracts bought those beds, as they could under the previous system.

I say with some sadness that in my own State of South Australia we started to do that. I rang some private hospitals to confirm what I thought I knew. Four or five years ago in some private hospitals, particularly for ophthalmology, those eye lists were being contracted under Medicare agreements for public patients to be treated as public patients in private hospitals, and then it stopped. The private hospitals wanted to make good use of private beds, but the specialists refused to continue to cooperate. I think it is a great tragedy when this country's patients are held to ransom by the various specialists.

I cannot understand why doctor X can be paid to operate on Friday doing eye surgery in a public hospital and be able to work in a private hospital on Monday and Wednesday. I do not think he suffers indignity by dealing with some other public patients in a private hospital bed. If he is a good doctor, he is interested in doing good eye surgery, good eye care. I do not know that the insurance status of people should so determine a difference in the way they are treated. If that is the case, it has to go. Up until now we have seen a very unacceptable underbelly of some of this health debate. People like Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —People don't use it.

—That is an absolute outrage, a misrepresentation of the facts and not the truth for most people in this country. If it is true that people do not like our public hospital system, why is it that so many private patients, in Senator Patterson's own words, `are crowding to get in there'? They are either choosing it themselves or they are sent by their doctors. Neither of those factors will change under any system that the Opposition is proposing. Of course they will continue to go to public hospitals, because that is where state-of-the-art medical care is.

PARA.TAB: There are very few private hospitals that can get close to our public hospitals. Certainly there are one or two. People now rush at me and say, `You cannot say that any more. We have one or two private hospitals in this country that can compete with them'. We all know the quality of some of those top-of-the-range private hospitals. They have been offering a splendid service, but they are few. They do not in any way attempt to replace public hospitals but supplement them.

It is this invidious debate of public versus private that has to be laid to rest. Under the Medicare agreements, it is possible to make optimal use of beds in this country so that no patient has to wait unnecessarily. That is what the Government tried to do under the previous Medicare agreements, and then the specialists stopped.

TALK.START.PARA: —And never succeeded.

—I will just tell Senator Walters that in Illawarra it worked like a charm. The doctors, the public hospital system and the New South Wales State Government all sat down and worked it out. Of course it can happen. It requires political will, sufficient funding and intent. That is what people will get: a better cooperation between clear outlines. The principal concern that I and this Government have is for people in this country to get the health care they need as soon as possible. It is necessary to sometimes have a short wait. Senator Walters would know more than many that of course people properly have to wait for elective surgery.

PARA.TAB: The surgeons who came before the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, which Senator Walters mentioned, said that six weeks is a reasonable wait. If we had a million people in this country on the waiting lists, it would not matter if they had to wait only one, two or four weeks. It is the waiting time that matters, not the number of people waiting. Senator Walters and I know that the waiting list is in the same specialties now as it has been for 10, 20 or 30 years. One needs to have a very close look at why we still have so many people waiting for eye treatment, ear, nose and throat treatment and orthopaedic treatment. If it is necessary to look at ways of redistributing the specialists and the beds so that we get the optimal management, then let us do it. But let us not keep telling the furphies that the Opposition has been telling.

The Opposition's policies will slug people. Under the Fightback package, if a person is on $50,000 and does not buy private insurance, the Opposition will charge that person another $800 a year. The Opposition tells us about the offence of increasing the levy by $1 a week for a family on an income of $35,000, but the Opposition will increase it by $800a year. We have in this country a fantastic system called Medicare. It is all those things Senator Walters read out. It is hassle free health care, it is administratively efficient, it is clear and it is simple. At least 70 per cent of the Australian people know it and like it. To the extent that it needs to be, we are going to improve it.

I will take the fight about Medicare anywhere, any time to the people of this country and beat the Opposition on Fightback dead. Fightback is massively inflationary. It is going to increase the costs to every individual. It is going to increase the costs of health in this country. It is going the American way. It is no way to go at all, particularly as it is under the cover of Medicare, which the Opposition will keep. Those opposite either want to have Medicare or they do not. Do not come in here and tell me what is bad about Medicare when they will keep it. I know why they are going to keep it: because it is so good.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion has concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Walsh, I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Sales Tax Legislation on the Sales Tax Assessment Bill 1992 and five related bills, together with the submissions and transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

That Senator Lewis be discharged from further attendance on the Standing Committee of Privileges and that Senator Herron having been nominated in accordance with the provisions of standing order 18 be appointed to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 7 November 1991, on behalf of the President I table a document of the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super Charges: An Issues Paper on Fees, Commissions, Charges and Disclosures in the Superannuation Industry which was presented to the President on 31 July 1992. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the President has authorised the printing of the circulation of the document. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This issues paper concerns fees, commissions, charges and disclosure in the superannuation industry. It is therefore an important starting point in any examination of the matter of fees, charges and commissions. It is a synthesis of a substantial amount of evidence which has been placed, both orally and in writing, before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Whilst this paper has given rise to much media comment and speculation on the manner of disclosure by agents of their commission, it also gives the reader a better understanding of a number of other issues which are critical to the development of a sound, long term retirement incomes policy.

PARA.TAB: The first is that the level of fees, charges and commissions always has the potential to detract from final superannuation benefits. Along with the taxation of superannuation contributions, income and benefits, it can play, in some cases, a devastating role. Superannuation funds, in any economic environment, tread a fine line yielding positive returns on the one hand and not covering rates of inflation on the other. It is often the level of fees, charges, commissions and taxes, coupled with the less than spectacular funds management, which force a fund into a negative return.

Just how finely balanced superannuation investments can be was illustrated in Monday's Australian Financial Review, which ran a story on research carried out by Noble Lowndes, which revealed that the performance of major fund managers in pooled superannuation in the last five years ending July 1992 showed that earnings were running at 6.1 per cent each year against inflation of 5.4 per cent yielding a real rate of return of less than 1 per cent. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary of that research.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent ASFA Superfunds journal, which surveyed major superannuation funds, provides little more joy. This survey revealed that a 20-year rolling average of return of around 2.9 per cent was normal for funds under survey. The magnitude of imposts and charges on superannuation contributions can be gauged by looking at one of the critical elements of the industry: personal superannuation as sold by life agents. Statistics provided by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission indicate that in 1990 almost $1.3 billion in agency commissions was paid. That represented an average of about 20 per cent of funds deposited with the industry.

PARA.TAB: Having been briefed by representatives of both the Life Insurance Federation of Australia—LIFA—and the agents, I am prepared to state that the agents have a key role to play as financial advisers and that they are entitled to a reasonable payment for their services. But what concerns me is that in recent times early cancellations have been reported to be running at a rate of something like 24 per cent for those policyholders who have taken out a policy within the last two years. A figure of 78 per cent for cancellations in late 1991 has also been reported. Given that most personal superannuation policies have front-end loaded agency commissions, most of those who cancelled would not have been refunded anything like the value of their contributions.

This seems extraordinarily wasteful, given that no long term retirement funds have been accumulated and also that over $3 billion worth of tax concessions, some of which are allocated to personal superannuation, are given to promote a retirement incomes policy. Therefore, I am left to wonder what the rate of policy cancellations will be now that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has issued his fiat which has, with the exception of a $100 net incentive, abolished rebates for award-plus superannuation. My office has received a significant number of calls protesting against this retrospective tax measure. I trust that the Government will ultimately see the error of its ways and restore this tax incentive, at least allowing those polices in force to continue receiving favourable tax treatment.

Returning to the document before the Senate, I alert honourable senators to the sections which point to the need for greater consumer awareness of the various product types and the charges which relate to each. How many of us, if confronted by glossy, small print and very technical advertising and contractual information, could distinguish between the following features: establishment and investment management fees; asset fees and switching fees; renewal commissions and early termination charges? It is very difficult.

Too often the consumer, in sheer exasperation, signs a contract and suffers the consequences later. The report canvasses a number of options for reform which I hope are given due consideration by the industry, consumer groups and government agencies. The questions are: should agents have to disclose and what should they disclose? Should the Insurance and Superannuation Commission play a more pro-active consumer role or should self-regulation prevail? Should commissions be amortised or capped? What regulation of agents is needed to clean up sections of the industry which chase the fast dollar rather than sell products to consumers in a caring client oriented manner?

These are questions to which I seek real answers. I trust that in the coming months the Committee members, who are represented in the chamber at the moment, will come to a well considered common position on these matters and that future retirees will be better off as a consequence. I commend the paper to the Senate.

Before closing these remarks, I commend the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, Mr Beetham, on his decision to open offices in each of the State capitals. It has been a matter of some concern for those people in the outlying States who have to contact Melbourne, Sydney or even Canberra. Telephone access has been a problem for accountants and people with other interests in the superannuation industry. Therefore, I would like to take this opportunity of complimenting the Commissioner on this forward step.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words in the absence of the Chairman of the Select Committee on Superannuation, Senator Sherry. I have listened with interest to the remarks of my colleague Senator Watson. I think he has fairly extensively covered a number of the major issues in the paper. It ought to be clear—although one could be forgiven for believing otherwise from some of the press reports—that this is only an options paper and does not make recommendations. It urges all interested parties to contribute to a public debate which ought to take place over the coming months. It will be a very valuable exercise because, quite clearly, there are considerable levels of concern, as we know from the submissions received by the Committee and from talking to various people in the community, about whether products are value for money. It is fair to say that the industry itself recognises the need to ensure that public confidence is maintained. As a result, the decision by LIFA to opt for full disclosure of fees and charges is a very good step.

PARA.TAB: The vexed question is whether commissions ought to be disclosed. At this stage, I would take the view that as long as consumers are made aware in advance of signing up for the product of what the surrender value is at various stages, they are in a position to make an informed judgment. It is therefore not necessary for them to know precisely who is getting what any more than the average consumer who buys a motor vehicle knows what the agent's commission is. Often it is not only a well-kept secret but also it is one that is particularly sensitive in a commercial sense. I do not see the need for consumers to know that level of detail. They ought to know whether they are getting value for money. I think they can do that by and large by being made aware of surrender values.

I do not throw my hands up in the air in the same way as some people do to discover that there are high levels of commission up-front, although the amount of the commission up-front may well be an independent matter for concern. The mere fact that it may not be very good value if one surrenders a policy within a couple of years does not automatically prove that it is not good value because the whole purpose of the exercise ought to be that one is in it for the long term. There may be some circumstances in which one has to cash it in but one ought to do that in the knowledge that the benefit of compounding will be forfeited and one is not likely to get much back by cancelling prematurely. Therefore, these things have to be sensibly judged over the period.

Up-front commissions have fallen quite considerably in recent years. I think that is a result of a combination of factors—probably more competition in the industry and a realisation that the more one takes up-front, the less commitment there may well be down the track in terms of servicing the customer and also the more one deprives the capital sum of the opportunities for compounding. I would have thought it would probably be more sensible to spread that commission payment over a period in order to meet both of those concerns. I think there is certainly room for negotiation in this area.

At the end of the day there has been a very high level of multipartisanship on the Committee. I read an article today by Michael Rice of MJR Consultants in the latest edition of Personal Investment, saying how the Committee had gone about its work. Perhaps Senator Kernot should read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the look on your face I am a little worried.

—Senator Kernot gets a special mention. The article described her dissenting report as `rather trite'. I thought that was fairly harmless and almost verging on the charitable, given that she was pursuing her usual idiosyncratic line about investment controls, which no-one else, apart from the consumer lobby, seems to think is a very good idea.
—That is a recommendation in itself.

—At least Senator Kernot managed to achieve her objective of getting special treatment from this writer in any event. The basic proposition that he made was that in a number of areas the Committee, particularly in the safeguarding superannuation report, has come up with a number of very useful recommendations which are designed to ensure that not only does the industry retain its integrity but also that consumers are protected. This report similarly brings together a number of important concerns and addresses them in such a way that we are capable of achieving a fairly high level of consensus. No-one wants to put people out of business. I believe there is a very important role to be played by those in the middle—I nearly said `middle man', but I suppose I should not.

PARA.TAB: As long as we accept that there is a need to promote products, that these things do not sell themselves and certainly if one does not believe in compulsion, as we do not, it follows that one ought to be able to sell a product only if one can persuade the consumer that it is good value for money. In order to do that, one ought to be entitled to a commission if successful. A number of the suggestions in that report will prove very useful in moving towards that consensus which I hope emerges in the not too distant future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to be brief as well. We have seen yet another of what Senator Alston called a useful report from a very useful Committee—the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. This issues paper deals with one of the really important issues that came from many witnesses who appeared before us—that is, the issue of fees, commissions, charges and disclosure. I believe that the many case studies outlined in this report clearly indicate that consumers are confused, understandably so, about the whole issue of superannuation. Often they do not know what they have entered into until a dispute arises and they see the fine print or they have the explanation.

PARA.TAB: Our Committee has outlined a number of options for reform, including the capping of fee levels. We have had so much evidence about the erosion of the small nest egg by the size of the administration fee eating away year after year. This applies particularly to women in the work force who may leave and return to the work force from time to time to find in the meantime that the nest egg they have accumulated has been eroded.

Another option for reform includes the disclosure of agents' commissions. I fully endorse that recommendation. If it is to be enacted, it will lead the way for radical reform in this industry, which has virtually been left untouched. Now that it is a growth industry and now that it is of vital concern to the majority of Australians, it is very important that we have the opportunity to have a close look at the way it operates.

Something else we would like to see and which I endorse is simplified documentation so that no longer can the industry hide behind the jargon, or what I would call the obfuscation, of differing documentation so that consumers cannot make an across-the-board product comparison. I regard superannuation as similar to any other product. Consumers have a right to access basic understandable information so that they can make an informed choice. This has not been possible in the area of superannuation.

I do not support the view that people only need to know the aggregate. I believe they need to know the components of agents' fees and commissions so that they can see whether an agent who is tied to a particular financial institution, for example, may have a vested interest in promoting one product above another.

This report has brought together a number of issues and problems. It is for public and industry debate. When that debate occurs, I think it will greatly assist the Committee in its job of reaching its final recommendations by the end of this year. I look forward to our final report and to its contribution to this important debate in Australia. I commend this issues paper to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —This paper addresses two of the Committee's 17 terms of reference, namely, (g) and (h). The Committee agreed that, having regard to the sensitivity of the fees, charges and commissions subject, it was appropriate that a consolidation of the evidence received by the Committee should be carried out and that a series of options for reform should be identified to allow consumer groups, industry players and government agencies to further submit their views before the Committee decides on its final recommendation.

PARA.TAB: The paper is a landmark document in that it is the first attempt, in recent times at least, to bring together, in a comprehensive and detailed way, the various views on fees, charges and commissions relating to superannuation. The Committee envisages that during the next two months it will further consider the matter and make recommendations in its third and final report.

As can be gauged by reading the issues paper, the Committee has received substantial evidence on this aspect of its terms of reference. Unfortunately, however, the evidence has been significantly—at times extremely—polarised and the Committee is faced with the task of making very difficult decisions as a consequence.

Honourable senators will recall that during the autumn sittings the Committee presented an interim report on its work on these terms of reference and in so doing expressed a concern that the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, commonly known as LIFA, had not fully cooperated with the Committee in submitting company by company details of fees, charges and commissions. I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Committee has received this information for each of the LIFA board member companies and that this has been followed up with an intensive in camera hearing during which productive discussions occurred. These developments have greatly assisted the Committee's understanding of the complex issues which underpin fees, charges and commissions in superannuation.

Since the Committee's establishment, a number of other agencies have been conducting similar and/or parallel inquiries into the subject. To this end, the Trade Practices Commission, the National Community Affairs Advisory Council and the Australian Law Reform Commission have also been looking at aspects of fees, charges and commissions in the superannuation industry. The distinct difference between the Committee's inquiry and those I have just identified is that the Committee has terms of reference which are global in their orientation.

The Committee has already inquired into and reported on the supply side of the superannuation equation; that is, how a dynamic, competitive and thereby efficient environment can be created which will deliver value for money superannuation and roll-over products.

The paper contains a series of case studies from a consumer's or demand viewpoint which identify some of the weaknesses of current sales and marketing of superannuation. What is needed is greater consumer awareness, more easily understood product descriptions and changes to disclosure which ensure that all consumers know what they are committing themselves to when they agree to enter into a superannuation contract.

It is with these overarching principles in mind that the Committee has floated the following options for reform: capping fee levels, consumer education specific to superannuation; standardised documentation; standardised disclosure requirements and terminology; regulatory reform to give teeth to existing disclosure requirements and guidelines; longer cooling off periods; mandatory disclosure of agent commissions; amortising commissions; and rules which make agents disclose the companies and products they respectively represent and sell.

The document is aptly named for a number of reasons, one of which is the way in which it has generated a supercharged debate on whether there should be disaggregated disclosure of agent commissions. Life officers and agents alike oppose disclosure of commissions, whereas consumers believe that it is the right of consumers to know how much their agent is being paid for selling regular premium or roll-over superannuation. I should emphasise as Chairman of the Committee that I have not come to a final conclusion on that and will still determine my particular view based on the ongoing submissions and evidence that we are receiving.

There is an emerging concern that, unless there are considerable efficiencies achieved in the personal superannuation product domain, some consumers will not be able to accumulate levels of superannuation to ensure a secure retirement. If media coverage of this matter is any guide, it would appear that the community strongly believes that full disaggregated disclosure should occur. However, whilst this would normally be an extremely persuasive factor in taking a decision in this direction, the Committee will first need to canvass the full gamut of responses to the issues paper. For example, one argument against disclosure is that if laws are passed making it mandatory, unresolved questions remain. For example, should disclosure take account of agent bonuses, agent travel and expenses, and agent salaries? Unless such legislation is carefully worded, many loopholes would exist which would facilitate avoidance of disclosure provisions.

The life industry believes that a total up-front disclosure of total fees, charges, commissions, et cetera is all that is needed and, to its credit, that is a substantial movement and change in view of the last few years. Likewise, even this solution needs clarification. For example, would this total be expressed in present value terms or some meaningless future value which would not take into account the impact of inflation?

This week marks the conclusion of one year's operation of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. During this time the Committee has, in some form or other, reported its progress on six separate occasions. It has adopted this policy because it believes that, in the fast moving superannuation environment in which Australia finds itself, it is of critical importance that all senators as well as all persons in the community be as up to date as possible on the main game of superannuation as played by their Select Committee on Superannuation.

The idea that select committees should report frequently during an extended inquiry is, I believe, preferable to handing down a single holy grail document on the final day of the Committee's life. Often these documents have been overtaken by government and community initiatives and therefore, at best, give only a potted history of developments in the field of inquiry. Moreover, frequent and meaningful reporting of activities can serve as an ongoing measure of performance of a committee.

I commend the paper to fellow senators. There certainly has been significant community demand for copies of this paper. I believe that it is an interesting and informative document which will advance the development of a sound retirement incomes policy. I also place on record the Committee's appreciation of the work of the secretariat staff, particularly Alistair Sands, in assisting senators during this period of the inquiry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
