TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for the lunch adjournment I was simply indicating my support for the increased funding for research into sugar growing areas. I mentioned the long history of the sugar industry in research funding and the work that the industry itself has done. I also mentioned my optimism for the future of the sugar industry, particularly in the Mackay, Burdekin and Herbert River areas of Queensland. I indicated that part of my optimism related to the fact that there will be a new Government in power federally as soon as Mr Keating is game enough to call an election. I was indicating that under a new government canefarmers, particularly, as with all farmers and all rural people, would be substantially better off under the coalition's Fightback proposals.

PARA.TAB: I said, and I briefly elaborate upon the fact, that the National Farmers Federation has given the coalition's Fightback proposals a very big tick—a very big endorsement. The Farmers Federation has done the figures; it has calculated how it will affect four particular primary industry groups and, in all cases, those primary industry groups would have a much more profitable outcome than currently exists. In the case of the sugarcane farmers, figures have been used which suggest that—depending on their size, of course—they would be between $6,000 and $10,000 a year better off under the Fightback proposals than they are now.

As opposed to the Fightback proposals for the sugarcane farmers we have, on the one hand, the Democrats wanting to ban everything, increase the costs of fuel and make life really difficult for the sugar growers. On the other hand, we have the Labor Party which does absolutely nothing for the sugar growers except set up these high profile task forces to run around the sugar electorates in the months before the Federal election with the pretence that they are going to look at something. They never say what they are going to do, but Mr Courtice, the honourable member for Hinkler—

TALK.START.PARA: —Excellent member!

—The ex-member for Hinkler, so Senator Sherry says—and he is right, but just anticipating a little. Mr Courtice has to appeal to the sugar growers if he wants to have any chance of winning his seat. He has, of course, gone. The Liberal candidate, John Abbott, an exceptional candidate from Gladstone, will win that seat. But Mr Courtice, in a last gasp attempt to retain that electorate, somehow has talked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) into setting up some sort of group which Mr Courtice necessarily will chair. He will run around to every sugar town in Queensland saying, `We're concerned about you; we're very concerned about your plight; we're going to look into doing something for you'. But we can be assured that nothing will happen before the Federal election.
—That is what you told them.

—I know Senator Kernot is sitting there with Senator Sherry—and I know that this unholy alliance between the Labor Party and the Democrats continues all the time—and she is equally to blame for the plight that many of the sugar farmers are in.

PARA.TAB: What the Labor Party has done to the sugar industry is unilaterally break a firm and solemn promise that the sugar farmers relied upon. Not only did it deliberately break this promise, but it has not done anything else which would assist the sugar farmers in overcoming some of the difficulties that some of them face. As I have mentioned to Senator Kernot, who obviously was not listening, and I will repeat it, under the Fightback proposals, according to figures that have been produced, sugar growers, depending on their size, would be between $6,000 and $10,000 better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will not be any industry left because you voted for tariffs.

—What absolute stupidity we continue to get from the Democrats. As I have said, unlike these southern people who suddenly float up north and become experts on the sugar industry, I have lived with and in the industry all of my life. I know what it is like. I am optimistic about the industry. I know that the industry will not be, to quote Senator Kernot, `wiped off the map'. That simply will not happen.

PARA.TAB: The sugar industry is a vibrant, strong industry that will continue to win in the world against all competition, because it is efficient, because money has been put into it through a lot of research—the sort of research we are talking about funding today, and the research which the industry itself has done—and because of the efficiency of that industry. That industry will continue. I have optimism. I know the people involved in it. They are people who will make it work; they will continue to make it a very prosperous industry; and, unlike my colleagues in the Democrats and the Labor Party, I have a lot of confidence in the way that that industry will continue and continue to expand and prosper, particularly under a coalition government when the costs are removed from it.

Senator Kernot, would you believe the National Farmers Federation's figures? The National Farmers Federation has indicated that most primary producers will be better off, and sugar growers are included in that. So they will be substantially better off under Fightback. Senator Kernot, someone told me the other day—and I have always said that, being a Queenslander, when the time comes, you will do the right thing—that you are now a convert to the GST. Is that correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —What's that?
—You are a convert to the GST?
—No.
—Someone told me that. It appeared in an article in the paper, apparently. I am not surprised, Senator Kernot, because, unlike many of your colleagues, I do not write you off completely.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! Senator Macdonald, by and large, we have been going along agreeably, but perhaps we could try addressing remarks through the Chair, just for a novelty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is very difficult with the rabble behind me.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Yes, I appreciate that. Resist temptation, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just indicating that I have not given up entirely on Senator Kernot. She is a Queenslander, and that is one thing in her favour. I think that when the Democrats completely fade away, with a bit of re-education and a bit of reorientation she might understand where things go in this life.
—Nothing else to do in life.

—It has nothing to do with sex, absolutely nothing at all. I think Senator Kernot has a little ability, which many of her colleagues do not have. It should be pointed out—although I must say most sugar farmers do not need it to be pointed out—that there is a small section of the industry which is enthralled or captured by the statements that Mr Courtice makes before elections about how concerned he is for the sugar industry, but it is all a rort.

PARA.TAB: If Mr Courtice was at all concerned about the sugar industry, he would not have allowed his Government to break a solemn promise to the sugarcane farmers. What is more, he would introduce the sorts of reforms that need to be put in place now to remove the costs of sugar farmers in the way that Fightback proposes, and in the way that the National Farmers Federation has indicated that primary producers generally, throughout Australia, will benefit from the Fightback package.

Last night, Mr Ballantyne, the General Manager of the Queensland Canegrowers, was quoted as saying that the Budget, which was supposed to do something for rural people, was mere tokenism. Of course, he is right. The Budget generally was tokenism and lies to the ultimate degree. Certainly, it has done nothing for rural producers anywhere. It has certainly done nothing for sugar farmers or the sugar industry. After the election is held, Mr Courtice will be looking for another job. The canegrowers in his electorate will throw him out in favour of John Abbott.

I support the Bill. As previous speakers from this side have indicated, we support additional funding for the sugar industry. We wish the Bill a speedy passage. It has our support and the support of the industry as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have a brief opportunity also to speak in support of the Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill 1992. I was interested to hear my North Queensland colleague, Senator Macdonald, speak about the coalition's policies in relation to the sugar industry. But Senator Macdonald did not say what they are. The people of North Queensland in particular are still unaware of just what they are.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take the time of the Senate this evening to run through some of the examples of about face by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer, and the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, Dr Hewson, in relation to what those policies might be if in the unlikely event, as Senator Macdonald seems so sure will happen, the coalition is in a position to make these decisions.

On 7 May Canegrowers was told by the Leader of the Opposition that, if elected, the coalition's policy was that there would be no special arrangements for Australia's sugar industry and that tariffs would be reduced to zero by the year 2000. Speaking on ABC Radio that day, Ian Ballantyne, the General Manager of Canegrowers, said that Dr Hewson had confirmed that `he would not look at holding a tariff' and that `They would come off on a progressive basis to reach zero'. Dr Hewson's position clearly exposes his coalition partner, the National Party, whose representatives have claimed that the tariff will not be zero but would be `negligible' by the end of the decade.

I cannot understand why Senator Macdonald is leaving the chamber. Perhaps he is not doing so. I am glad that he is staying to hear why the people in sugar growing areas are so confused about the coalition's policies. On the same day—7 May—a media release stated that the National Party Leader, Tim Fischer, had apparently either deliberately attempted to mislead rural Australia in recent statements or the National Party's views seem to have been ignored or overridden by Dr Hewson. In an interview with John Laws, Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, by negligible—we say negligible protection—because protection comes from two sources really. It comes from the tariff, and it comes from the exchange rate. If the exchange rate depreciates, it increases the protection of an industry. . . So in a sense, we say negligible protection because you could have a movement of the exchange rate by as much as 5 per cent or so over that period. But the aim is to eliminate tariffs. But of course the exchange rate movement can still provide protection.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not know whether you know what all that means. This is certainly gobbledegook from Dr Hewson who, frankly, does not understand the sugar industry. This is quite clear from that convoluted statement. But the one clear message that comes through from the interview is—and I repeat it:
But the aim is to eliminate tariffs.

There was then a little bit of quiet for a couple of months. Ray Braithwaite had to resign his position because of total confusion and an inability to be able to focus on the coalition's policies in relation to the sugar industry.

PARA.TAB: On 17 July we had another statement—this time from Tim Fischer. What did Tim Fischer say this time? In an article in the Australian under the heading `Fischer Predicts Policy Shift', it is claimed that `according to. . . Mr Fischer', the Federal National Party Leader, Dr Hewson has been convinced by the coalition that the Fightback package needs `adjusting'. Further, the article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fischer indicated to the Women's section of the Queensland National Party Conference adjustments would also be made to the timing of tariff reductions in Fightback, which delegates took to mean a slowdown in the phasing out of tariffs.
He told the Australian yesterday a Coalition Government would not even begin to reduce tariffs until the rest of the Fightback package was in place, including the goods and services tax—
the canegrowers would love the thought of a goods and services tax—
industry relations reform and the abolition of payroll and sales taxes and fuel excise.
That was on 17 July from one of the coalition partners. The views of Dr Hewson were also sought in regard to this matter. The same article states:
A spokeswomen for Dr Hewson said yesterday she had no knowledge of any proposal to hold back tariff reductions until after all aspects of Fightback had been passed through Parliament.
So there is a clear contradiction between the coalition leaders.

PARA.TAB: On 23 July Mr Crean issued a press release which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Crean called on sugar growers to recall Dr Hewson's response to the CANEGROWERS chairman, Harry Bonnano, and general manager, Ian Ballantyne, when they put to him the growers concerns. . .
The press release continued:

Mr Ballantyne said. . . : `We spoke to Mr Fischer and Mr Hewson separately, but in general terms Mr Hewson. . . reconfirmed they would not look at holding a tariff, should they be elected to Government next year, they would not look at holding a tariff at present levels and by that time it would be $55, but they would progressively come off on a straight line basis so if the tariff was at that point at 20 per cent over the next six years or so they would come off on a progressive basis to reach zero. . . they would be adhering strictly to the Fightback package.'
The press release also contained the following quote:

`In spite of Dr Hewson's clearly stated position Mr Fischer told the Queensland National Party conference and the media that a Coalition Government would not even begin to reduce tariffs until the rest of the Fightback package was in place. . .

Clearly, all honourable senators would agree just from what has happened in the last few months in one industry—the sugar industry—that it is quite clear that the coalition does not understand the rural sector. It certainly does not understand the sugar industry.

PARA.TAB: While I acknowledge and applaud the coalition's support for this sugar levy amendment Bill, it is quite clear that there are continual contradictions in the ranks of the coalition. I am simply quoting directly from what has been said by Dr Hewson and Tim Fischer. It is quite clear that they do not understand the sugar industry. Coalition members like Senator Macdonald come into this place and pretend to anybody who cares to listen that the coalition has it all sewn up, that it is going to protect the sugar industry. Yet the evidence is in black and white in statements which have been documented. Clearly, the coalition has no inclination to protect the sugar industry. It has no particular policy, except to reduce tariffs to zero.

I am pleased to support the Bill. I am also pleased that the coalition is at least supporting the Bill. But heaven help the canegrowers of Queensland and elsewhere if the coalition were to get into government because obviously it would have absolutely no heart for the sugar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or requests.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every six months or so the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories labours and brings forth a gnat. Once again, we have before the Senate one of these ludicrous ragbags of legislation where the Government either fixes up stupid mistakes which have generally emerged from rushing legislation through at the end of a session, or includes in legislation matters of very little consequence. I simply wonder how much it really costs to put a Bill through this Parliament and why the Government wastes its time with this sort of nonsense rather than making it part of some matter of real substance. Anyway, here we have yet another set of amendments to legislation under the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

PARA.TAB: The Arts, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 seeks to amend five Acts. Three of them relate to the arts and heritage, and I will deal with them first. The first is the Australia Council Act 1975. The amendment that the Government is now proposing, if passed, would enable the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, rather than the Governor-General, to appoint and accept the resignation of the members of the Council. By the way, the Chairman would still be appointed by the Governor-General.

I stress that all appointments to bodies similar to the Australia Council are appointed by the Governor-General in Council. That means that the Government makes a recommendation to the Governor-General. People like Senator McMullan have to trot out to Government House and explain to the Governor-General why they want whoever it is appointed to whatever board it is. There are many such organisations, yet here we have suddenly brought into this place a Bill to amend the way we appoint people to just one of those many bodies.

Either the Government has taken a policy decision that it does not want the Governor-General to appoint people to this kind of board—and if it has taken such a decision, it should apply it to all such bodies—or it has not taken a decision, and is just having a one-off flight of fancy. It seems to me that the reality is that it is simply another example of this Government being a chaotic organiser. No doubt, in coming months we will find further examples of legislation that someone might decide needs to be changed this way, and the time of the Parliament will be wasted similarly. It just seems extraordinary to me.

I ask the Minister whether the Government favours appointments to this sort of body being made by the Governor-General. If it does not, why is it not changing the method of appointment to similar bodies such as the Australian Film Commission, the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian National Maritime Museum, the Museum of Australia, the Australian National Gallery, the Australian National Library and the Australian Film, Television and Radio School, which all have boards appointed by the Governor-General and which relate to this portfolio?

Rather than us having to change this legislation day after day, week after week, or every six months after six months, and having to put up with the same sort of nonsense, cannot the Government get its act together? If it wants to change the legislation with regard to one body, it should change it in relation to them all. Let us do it efficiently. Surely the Government has learned by now, after almost 10 years, that there are efficient ways of doing things and inefficient ways of doing things. Why it sticks to the inefficient way, I do not know.

In any event, this new section 31A will allow the Minister to delegate in writing to the Council the power to appoint members—but not the Chairman—of the various boards, such as the Aboriginal Arts Board, and to accept resignations. The Chairman, as a member of the Council, must be appointed by the Minister. I do not have any problems with that element of it—that is quite reasonable—but the Government should look at the question of the main board.

I will admit that, in reality, appointments are made by the Minister, but in most instances the Minister has to get approval from the Cabinet, particularly in situations involving the Chairman. The farce of who was going to be the Chairman of the Australia Council went on for months. In fact, it was not until two months after the previous Chairman had retired that the Government eventually got around to replacing him, having publicly hawked the appointment around for quite some time.

If it is sensible for the Minister to have the power to appoint and accept resignations to the Australia Council, it applies equally well to all those other bodies. The Minister's explanation for the need to make this change was that the amendments will streamline the appointment process. Presumably it would streamline the appointment process equally well in all those other organisations which are not being fixed up in this way.

As a result of an absence of any rational, coherent reason why it should be done like this, the Opposition opposes the amendment. It has no rational basis. If the Government can explain it to us, great. But it cannot, and it has not. It just says that it will streamline the process. Let us streamline the process for the lot or none, but do not take this seriatim, item by time, wasting the time of—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a rational basis for opposition.

—The Minister says that it is not rational. The Opposition is trying to enforce self-discipline on this Government—a bit of intellectual rigour which I know the Government does not accept and is not very good at. If the Minister is genuinely concerned about the way his Government makes a mess of legislation, he should see to it that departments get such changes together in one bit of legislation, and save the time of this Parliament and the money involved in having series of amendments come through like this without any kind of coherence or effectiveness. Our approach is to impose a bit of discipline on an undisciplined, incompetent government. The Minister should go away and think about it. If he wants to change them all, we will listen to his argument. But to knock each body off one by one like this is just ludicrous and incompetent.

PARA.TAB: The next matter is the Australian Heritage Commission Act. The Government is proposing to correct a drafting error and substitute `Remuneration Tribunal' for `Remuneration Tribunals'. Naturally, we will support that. All we wonder, is why this amendment could not have been part of some more substantive legislation than what we have here so we do not have to waste time on nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's only a short Bill.
—The nation would not fall apart if the proposed amendment to convert the term from `tribunals' to `tribunal' did not take place until there was some substantive change.
—Neither will it fall apart if it does.

—The point the Minister makes is that it will not fall apart if it is passed. If the Minister had been listening he would know that that is one of the reasons why we are supporting it. We are just chiding the Government for incompetence. We are supporting that amendment, but it seems to me to be ludicrous to suggest that there was any special need to hasten this sort of stuff before the Parliament, unless we are facing the usual situation where the Government is desperate to find some legislation to bring in early in the session because it has such a chaotic record of having nothing to come before this Parliament early in its sessions and ends up with a mountain of stuff at the end. The Government then rushes legislation through and makes this kind of silly mistake.

PARA.TAB: The next Act is the National Gallery Act 1975. The amendment seeks to change the name of the gallery from the Australian National Gallery to the National Gallery of Australia. No other alterations are to be made. Obviously, this is a matter of enormous substance to somebody. I have spoken to the Director of the National Gallery of Australia—as she would like it to be called—and I have a great regard for her. But this seems to me to be a monumental waste of time.

The argument put forward is that the new name will be more in keeping with other institutions in the Parliamentary Triangle, such as the National Library of Australia, the National Film and Sound Archive across the lake, the National Museum of Australia and the National Science and Technology Centre. If the view is that we should call these bodies the `National' whatever it is, then I wonder why so recently the Australian Government decided to call the national maritime museum the Australian National Maritime Museum.

This Government has no consistency and no rationality. If it is important not to call something Australian, why did it call the Australian National Maritime Museum the Australian National Maritime Museum? This strikes me as more examples of absolute nonsense coming before this Parliament.

There is also a problem relating to the National Gallery of Victoria. In future, if this legislation goes through, it is very likely that the National Gallery of Victoria will be confused with the National Gallery of Australia. Both are called the `National Gallery of. . . '. Surely the name `Australian National Gallery' is a far more distinctive and different name from the National Gallery of Victoria. If the Government is seeking to change the name of the Australian National Gallery because—and this is what was put to me—at present it is confused with the Victorian gallery because it is called the National Gallery of Victoria, then surely the Government will create even greater confusion by going down this track.

Certainly concern has been expressed to me by some people on the museum staff and people who are close to the gallery that it is presently known throughout the world by its present title. As well as causing changes in Australia, similar alterations would need to be made to reference and trade publications which relate to the Australian National Gallery. The question we should ask is: will the change make the gallery any more efficient or attract more visitors? It is the view of the Director that it will and that it is to its advantage. That is her view. I am afraid it is not mine. She is entitled to her view and the Government is entitled to go to the expense of changing the Act, bringing it through Parliament and changing the stationery, the signage and heaven knows what for some vague and, it seems to me, inconsequential end. I do not think it has any rational purpose and I would need to be persuaded that there is a net benefit in changing the name from the Australian National Gallery to the National Gallery of Australia. I understand that ultimately the purpose is to simply say, `It is the national gallery'.

TALK.START.PARA: —National Gallery of Australia sounds better.

—If it is to be known as the `National Gallery', that is great. It can be known as the `National Gallery' when it is called the Australian National Gallery just as well as if it is called the National Gallery of Australia. It is just so inconsequential and ridiculous that I wonder why our time is being wasted by it.

PARA.TAB: I have one other point. The word `Australian' seems to me to be an important word and I would like to see it up in front of the names of bodies like these. The word `Australian' seems to me to be a much more significant word to have up front than the word `national'. Other countries may take the view that they would like to have the word `national' up front. I want the word `Australian' up front. Unless there is a damn good reason for changing it, I cannot see why we should lose the word `Australian' at the front of the names of these bodies—just as the Australian National Maritime Museum, which is a recent creation by this Government, has it. In any event, I see no reason for supporting the change.

I would now like to deal with another couple of matters which my colleague Senator Macdonald related. One concerns the National Capital Planning Authority. Clause 5 of this Bill amends the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988, the National Land Ordinance 1989 and the Reserved Laws (Administration) Ordinance 1989 to enable the National Capital Planning Authority, with the approval of the Minister, to manage on behalf of the Commonwealth national land which is used or intended to be used for the special purposes of Canberra as the national capital.

This formalises an arrangement made on 1 July in a ministerial direction which handed over the management of national land from DASET to the NCPA. There are no financial obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by the Bill and we support this section of the legislation. We really do want to highlight our growing concern over the power entrusted to the Minister in light of a Labor Party proposal to nominate Canberra for World Heritage listing. That is the only concern we have.
As to the other matters in this ragbag, we have no basic objections, even though this kind of omnibus Bill to fix things up really

SPEECH.PARA: should be attached to something worthwhile. I will remind the Minister of the other element that I was prepared to let go. This one relates to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and it increases the value of contracts which the Director of Parks and Wildlife may enter into from $100,000 to $250,000. This is consistent with increases already approved for other statutory authorities in the DASET portfolio.

PARA.TAB: Here is another example of doing things in bits and pieces. The last time we had this sort of DASET amendment Bill we did this for all the other organisations. In fact, we took two bites to do it for the other organisations. Here we are now having another bite at it and we are doing it for the National Parks and Wildlife organisation. Cannot this Department get its act in order? Cannot this Minister, or whoever is in charge of it, get his act in order? We support that element of the Bill.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 12 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: What is the expected cost of: (a) airfares; (b) travel allowance; (c) accommodation; and (d) other associated expenses, incurred by the Minister, his/her personnel, department and security staff, in the course of travelling to and from, and attending, the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development in Rio de Janiero in June 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The amounts at (a) to (d) represent the estimated costs to be incurred by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, two ministerial staff members, security guard, and seven officers of the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

The amount at (d) includes $5,000 advanced from the Department of Administrative Services for functions hosted in Rio de Janeiro and for other hospitality expenses plus an estimated $7,200 expended on car hire. It does not include any of the estimated total of $88,150 to establish delegation offices a proportion of which will be charged to the Department by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
The figures are provided as estimates subject to acquittal in accordance with normal procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of a workshop organised by the Australian National University's Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research in early 1991 which evaluated the goals and progress of the Government's Aboriginal Employment Development Policy.

(2) Is the Minister aware that the workshop came to a consensus conclusion that the goals set for the year 2000 for Aboriginal employment and income equity, when measured statistically, are `hopelessly unrealistic'.
(3) Does the Government still adhere to such goals; if so, what alternative means of achieving them have been put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Aboriginal Employment Development Policy (AEDP) Task Force recommended that the Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research (CAEPR) be established in response to Recommendation 164 of the Report of the Committee of Review of Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs ("the Miller Report") and the Minister is aware of its activities including the publication of `Employment Equity by the Year 2000' which was the subject of discussion at the workshop.

(2) The targets set for the AEDP are both challenging and demanding. Given the extent of Aboriginal disadvantage, this is proper and appropriate. Whether those targets are met will depend on a range of factors including macro-economic conditions, program effectiveness at Local, State and Commonwealth levels, and progress toward the achievement of a reconciliation between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and other Australians.

(3) In order to strengthen and reinforce the AEDP the Government, as part of its response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, has committed an additional $250m in the next five years (1992-97). These funds will be allocated to areas such as Rural Resources, Community Economic Initiatives, Industry Development, the Community Development Employment Projects program, the Youth Development Employment program and the Young People's Development program all of which are specifically targeted at enhancing the economic circumstances of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. All existing AEDP programs are being systematically assessed and it is anticipated that following the release of 1991 Census data an assessment of progress to date and the prospects for achieving the equity targets will be made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism, upon notice, on 5 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were recent media reports which suggest that the Government is considering a request from major Japanese travel companies to grant 2000 temporary resident visas for up to two years for Japanese citizens to fill tour guide positions in Australia accurate.
(2) Does the Australian tourism industry suffer from the lack of qualified personnel to fill tour guide positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In June 1991, representatives of the Japanese Tour Wholesalers Committee of Australia and the Australian Tourism Industry Association met with Australian Government officials to discuss the future recruitment of Japanese tour guides to Australia. There was concern expressed about a perceived shortfall as a result of significant growth in tourism from Japan.

A proposal for the entry of up to 2000 Japanese tour guides, on a temporary basis over a number of years, was subsequently presented to the Government. The proposal is currently being considered by Government agencies and trade unions, in consultation with a wide range of community and industry representatives. No decision has yet been taken.

(2) A preliminary analysis of the labour market conducted by the Department of Employment, Education and Training suggests that there may be shortages of Japanese speaking tour guides in some specific Japanese tourist destinations.
In addition, the anticipated growth in visitor arrivals from Japan over the next few years is expected to generate further demand for Japanese-speaking tour guides.

To ensure that there is an appropriate training infrastructure to meet this demand, and that employment opportunities for Australians are maximised, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has established a committee to develop a national strategy for enabling Australians to train as tour guides.

Any decision to allow the entry of Japanese tour guides would be contingent on the development of such a strategy as part of a labour agreement, which would ensure that the entry of overseas skilled workers would not be at the expense of employment opportunities for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why has no ongoing administrative staff funding been given to the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress in Western Australia so that support for Aboriginal women can be maintained.
(2) Does the Minister agree that it is ludicrous for any organisation to be given funding to purchase equipment and to run for 12 months and then to provide no ongoing funding.
(3) Has the Minister been approached to help Aboriginal women in the Congress; if so, what action has the Minister taken and with what result.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Consistent with the provisions of Section 94 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, funding decisions on proposals such as the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress project, are made by the local Regional Council of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. These decisions are made in the context of overall budget allocations approved by ATSIC's Board of Commissioners. I am advised by ATSIC that the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress has not received funding because the Karlkarniny (Perth) Regional Council did not accord as high a priority to the project as it accorded to other approved proposals.

(2) Whilst no organisation has an automatic entitlement to continuing funding, I recognise that the social and economic disadvantages suffered by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples will not be improved unless project activities are targeted and supported for an appropriate duration.

Regional Councils are not the sole funding source and they need to strike a balance between the expectations held by all organisations within their regional boundary areas, and the ability to provide sufficient funding within the real constraints of scarce financial resources.

In relation to timeframes and agreed funding of sponsored activity, this will be better addressed in the regional planning processes now being developed by Regional Councils. This regional planning process will provide the necessary mechanisms for Regional Councils to make funding decisions, and to advocate the needs and aspirations of the constituents to all service providers.
(3) Yes. I have received approaches from the Aboriginal and Islander Women's Congress. These submissions have been referred to ATSIC for consideration and decision.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 16 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many officers from the Department attended the Earth Summit Conference in Brazil.
(2) What was the cost over and above normal salaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Seven officers from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories attended the Earth Summit Conference in Brazil.

(2) The final cost, over and above salaries, is not yet available as not all the accounts relating to the establishment of offices and administration, e.g. cost of telephone calls and facsimile transmissions, have been received from Brazil.
The cost of fares, travel allowance and accommodation for the seven officers was in the order of $93 520. A final figure is not known as travel acquittals have not been finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Sport the Environment and Territories, on notice, on 17 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of the campaign by the World Travel and Tourism Council to ensure that mankind's cultural and natural treasures which are listed on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) World Heritage List are placed under the protection of the Geneva Red Cross Conventions in time of conflict.
(2) Has the Australian Government, or any department, statutory authority, or Government business provided any support, in any form, for the campaign.
(3) Does the Australian Government, or any department, statutory authority, or Government business intend to provide any support, in any form, for the campaign; if not, why is it not being supported.
(4) What would be the implications, if any, of the success of the campaign for any item listed on the UNESCO World Heritage List which was threatened in a time of conflict.
(5) What would be the implications, if any, of the success of the campaign for Australian items listed on the UNESCO World Heritage List.
(6) Does the Australian Government consider such use an appropriate use of the Geneva Red Cross Conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) I have exchanged correspondence on this matter with Mr Geoffrey Lipman, President of the World Travel and Tourism Council and note his proposal.

(3) The linkages between the World Heritage Convention and other Conventions, including the Geneva Red Cross Convention, is being considered by UNESCO and State Members as part of the review of the World Heritage Convention in the twentieth anniversary year of the Convention. My Department is contributing to that review. Although I share the concerns of the World Travel and Tourism Council and welcome their initiative in this matter, I believe there are practical problems which would constrain the effectiveness of applying the Geneva Red Cross Convention to World Heritage in times of conflict.

(4) I understand that the view emerging from the review of the World Heritage Convention is that it would be difficult, if not impossible, to effectively apply the articles of any Convention to the protection of World Heritage properties during armed conflict.
(5) I do not see any practical implications.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 17 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the address by the Prime Minister to the Youth Training and Employment Forum on 2 June 1992, in which he asked for input from community groups grappling with the problem of youth unemployment:

(l) Has the Prime Minister been in contact with the largest non-government provider of employment training programs, the Sydney City Mission, with particular reference to their InteLife Project which will directly assist and train the most disadvantaged unemployed youth in a new way using the vehicle of an environment centre to provide practical employment training while demonstrating ecologically sustainable technologies and living practices to the wider community.

(2) Will the Government give generous consideration to funding support for this innovative proposal which clearly addresses the two major concerns of Australians in the 1990s, unemployment and the environment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A representative from my staff has been in contact with the Sydney City Mission with reference to their InteLife Project.

(2) The Government recognises the important role played by organisations such as the Sydney City Mission in helping the disadvantaged and in providing training for the unemployed; for example in 1991 the Government provided $2.3m to SkillShare projects sponsored by the Sydney City Mission and in 1992 will contribute $3.2m.
The Prime Minister has announced a National Employment and Training Plan for Young Australians following the national meeting on youth training and employment held on Wednesday, July 22.
The key features of the package are:

ANSWER.PARA: An offer to all long-term unemployed young people of a six month vocational training course, with a JOBSTART card on completion, giving employers a wage subsidy to employ a young person.
A milestone change with the creation of a new Career Start Traineeship, set up under a new single federal award—to target early school leavers, amongst the most disadvantaged of job seekers;
An expansion of SkillShare and JOBTRAIN with a link to a wage subsidy for a job beyond training;
A new Landcare and Environment Action Program offering young people employment experience in environmental and conservation projects;
Increased subsidies for additional current traineeships and extra support for apprentices;
A further 12,000 pre-vocational for TAFE places in 1993;
$43.6 million over three years to underpin the development of the new entry level training arrangements for the Australian Vocational Certificate recommended in the Carmichael Report; and
$56.3 million over three years to fund places in Carmichael pilot projects and the new Career Start Traineeships.

PARA.TAB: The Sydney City Mission InteLife Project could apply for funding under eligible programs and would be considered along with other proposals on a merit basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports in the media earlier in June 1992 alleging that the Federal Government has `secretly' sanctioned tests on Vietnam veterans to assess the neurological impact of exposure to chemicals during service—

(1) Are these reports accurate; if so: (a) what is the exact nature of the tests; (b) where are they taking place; (c) who is conducting the tests; (d) how many veterans are being tested; (e) how long will it be before results of the tests are available.
(2) When was a decision taken that these tests should be conducted and on what basis was that decision made.
(3) Why did the Government not announce details publicly when it was decided that such tests should be undertaken, given the great interest they would hold for the veteran community.
(4) Will the Government be publicly disclosing the results of these tests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Repatriation Commission has initiated a pilot investigation of Vietnam veterans to indicate whether there is any substance in a medical hypothesis proposing that intercerebral Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). There is no secrecy about the project or its outcome. The Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia is well aware of the project and reference has been made to it in their publication.
(a) The study involves the collection of cerebro-spinal fluid and blood for measurement of Vitamin B12 status.
(b) The tests will be co-ordinated by Repatriation General Hospital (RGH) Heidelberg.
(c) The tests will be supervised by Dr Des Parkin, Director, Haematology, RGH Heidelberg.
(d) Up to 40 veterans are to be tested. The experimental group will consist of 20 Vietnam veterans. Results will be compared to a control group of 20 veteran patients.
(e) The study should be completed in 2-3 years time.

(2) The Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia provided some information of case studies which suggests the possibility of an association between intercerebral Vitamin B12 deficiency and PTSD. A Victorian doctor has been involved in these cases and has claimed success of treatment based on an assumption of such an association. He has not been able to point to an acceptable degree of scientific research to support the association nor to evidence of the efficacy of the treatment. The Commission established that there was little in the medical literature supporting the hypothesis nor did there appear to be any research being conducted to establish the validity of the hypothesis. After advice firstly that research into this hypothesis was now practicable in terms of measurement of the status of B12 levels, secondly that a research protocol could be prepared to conduct the research to scientifically acceptable standards, and finally that, subject to the protocol being approved by the RGH Ethics Committee, the research could be conducted at RGH Heidelberg, the Commission approved the research as part of its ongoing research program. The Ethics Committee approved the protocol on 16 April 1992.

(3) The Repatriation Commission made no public announcement of the research, but discussed it widely within medical circles and ex-service organisations. It was considered a public announcement would serve little purpose, particularly as all directly concerned were aware of the project.
(4) Results of the research will be made public and it may attract coverage in scientific and medical journals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 1 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to an undertaking given in the Senate by the former Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Hansard, 7 November 1991, p.2662) that he would report on the progress of discussions between the Minister and forest industries, regarding the question of unsecured creditors of the Ravenshoe Mill—
(1) What was the outcome of those discussions.
(2) When and where were the discussions held, and who was in attendance.

(3) Following the discussions, has the Government provided, or does it plan to provide, any form of compensation for the Ravenshoe businesses who extended credit to the former mill owners on the basis that the financial management of the mill was being properly supervised by the Commonwealth; if not, why not.
(4) What assistance packages were provided to union member employees who were retrenched after the mill collapsed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1 & 2) I have not held discussions with representatives of the forest industries on this matter.
(3) No. The Government remains of the view that the debts in question occurred as a result of the commercial failure of the mill and should not be regarded as the responsibility of the Commonwealth.

(4) In November 1991 the Government decided to provide assistance to former employees who had been employed at the mill at the time of World Heritage nomination in December 1987 and who were retrenched during the period January to April 1991, when the mill closed. Workers were able to qualify under one of two categories:
(i) $2,500 dislocation allowance for a person employed at the time of World Heritage nomination and retrenched by the receivers, except for those aged 55 years and over at the date of retrenchment;

(ii) an early retirement assistance payment based on years of service in the timber industry up to a maximum of $30,000 each to those aged 55 years and over at the time of retrenchment and who were employed at the time of World Heritage nomination.
No differentiation was made in assessing eligibility for assistance between employees on the basis of union membership.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 13 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a number of statements issued by Mr Tony Miller, Consul (Public Affairs) of the Australian Consulate in New York about the status of koalas in Australia:

(1) What legislation is Mr Miller referring to in his statement that `the Australian Government introduced legislation many years ago that was designed to protect our native wildlife' and by what constitutional means does the Federal Government have control over States' wildlife responsibilities.
(2) What areas of major koala habitat is Mr Miller referring to in his statement that `areas of major koala habitat are protected by legislation'.

(3)(a) Would the Minister provide the management plans referred to in Mr Miller's statement that `the Australian, State and Territory Governments have taken action to ensure such areas are not destroyed and extensive management plans are in place'; (b) what steps have the Australian, State and Territory Governments taken to ensure that these claimed areas of major koala habitat protected by legislation are not destroyed.

(4) What work by Australian, State and Territory Governments is Mr Miller referring to in his statement that a `...huge amount of work which has been done to study the koala and its medical problems'.
(5) Which areas have stable koala populations in eastern Australia.
(6) Which areas have locally abundant koala populations in eastern Australia.
(7) Would the Minister provide specific details of successful breeding programs of koalas in captivity in US zoos including details of mortality rates.

(8)(a) What are the names of US zoos where koalas have been born; (b) of koalas born in US zoos, what are the specifics of the age, sex and mortality rates; and (c) how do juvenile males find new territory in a captive situation.
(9) Would the Minister provide explicit details of tree planting or rehabilitation programs specifically for koalas.
(10) Would the Minister advise what Government agency is providing information to the Australian consulate in New York and the Embassy in Washington on koalas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is unclear from the quotation attributed to Mr Miller whether the reference was to State or Commonwealth legislation. As the honourable senator will be aware, primary responsibility for wildlife conservation and management rests with State and Territory Governments. Commonwealth legislation relevant to wildlife conservation includes the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 and the Whale Protection Act 1980. The Federal Government has specific responsibilities for import and export controls on wildlife and for ensuring Australia observes its obligations under international treaties.
(2) Koala habitat is broadly distributed throughout Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. Nature conservation reserves in these States protect substantial areas of koala habitat.

(3)(a) The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service within my portfolio has provided funding to assist with the gathering of data and the development of koala management plans in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia through the Koala Conservation Program and the States Cooperative Assistance Program. Draft management plans have been completed by Queensland and Victoria, and are currently being developed by New South Wales and South Australia. Copies of the draft plans for Queensland and Victoria have been forwarded to the honourable senator and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(3)(b) The existing national parks and nature reserves in eastern Australia effectively protect substantial areas of koala habitat and are managed by the State and Territory conservation agencies. Ultimately the long-term conservation of the koala will depend on the protection offered by these reserves in combination with conservation measures outside reserves. Programs funded by the Commonwealth Government such as Save the Bush, One Billion Trees and the States Cooperative Assistance Program are important to maintaining and improving habitat outside reserves.

(4) The statement from Mr Miller's letter that 'A huge amount of work has been done to study the koala and its medical problems' is a generic reference to research on the biology of koalas since their initial discovery rather than work conducted solely by governments. Through the Koala Conservation Program, launched in 1985, over $800,000 from Commonwealth funding, public contributions and a donation from American Express International, has been provided to administer and conduct high priority research projects through the Research and Surveys, Save the Bush, and States Cooperative Assistance Programs. The research projects include investigations on Chlamydiosis (a bacterial borne disease which is widely distributed in koala populations), diet, habitat utilisation and identification of important remnant habitat areas.

(5) and (6) The National Koala Survey, a component of the Koala Conservation Program, aimed to identify the broad distribution of koalas in Australia to assess their current status and changes in historical distribution. The survey did not aim to assess population size in local areas or nation-wide. The surveys in New South Wales and Queensland indicated that the broad historical distribution of the koala was stable, despite some local declines, and that the greatest concentrations of koalas occurred in the northeast New South Wales-southeast Queensland region. In the southern states of South Australia and Victoria the current distribution on the mainland is largely the result of translocation of animals from locally overstocked populations on Kangaroo Island and French Island. These translocation efforts have been so successful that koalas are now re-established throughout much of the remaining suitable habitat in their former range.

(7) Koalas have been exported to 3 US zoos; San Diego, San Francisco and Los Angeles. Each has a successful breeding program. Specific details of mortality rates are currently being sought from these zoos. The information will be provided to the honourable senator as soon as it is available.
(8)(a) It is known that koalas have been born at San Diego, San Francisco and Los Angeles zoos. It is not known whether they have been born at other zoos in the USA.
(b) The information requested is currently being sought from US zoos. It will be provided to the honourable senator when it becomes available.
(c) In managing captive animals, including koalas, zoos rotate their stock and design their facilities to minimise sexual aggression.

(9) Details of such programs throughout eastern and southern Australia are not held by my portfolio. However koalas benefit from projects which seek to improve wildlife habitat generally. Such projects may be funded through Federal Government programs such as Save the Bush and One Billion Trees. Much voluntary work is also undertaken locally to improve koala habitat.

(10) I have been advised that the response supplied by Mr Miller was based on information provided by a variety of sources. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service provided the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with an information brochure which covered the points of concern.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 13 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) has recently allowed a commercial tourism venture, Desert Discovery, to visit Dorre Island, a prohibited A Class Reserve in Shark Bay.
(2) Does the Minister believe a tourist venture is appropriate on Dorre Island.
(3) Has CALM given permission for a one-off tour or a number of tours; if the latter, how many and over what time period.
(4) How long is the tour permitted to stay on the island.
(5) How many people will visit the island during any one tour.
(6) Where will the tour members stay on the island.
(7) What measures will be taken to ensure that the tour does not disturb threatened species or the integrity of the island's ecosystem and natural values.
(8) Will the impact of the visit be monitored; if so, by whom; if not, why not.
(9) (a) what scientific research will be carried out by tour members; (b) who has decided the research agenda; (c) what will be done with the research results.
(10) How much money will Desert Discovery contribute to CALM.
(11) Has CALM allocated the proposed financial contribution from Desert Discovery to a specific use; if so, what use; if not, why not.
(12) Is the Minister prepared to talk with environment groups in Western Australia about this matter; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The primary responsibility for the management of the Shark Bay World Heritage property lies with the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM). I have been advised on the matters raised by the honourable senator by CALM and the Office of the Western Australian Minister for the Environment.

(1) I have been advised that an ecotourism organisation has been given permission to undertake scientific work on Dorre island. The authorisation was issued by the Executive Director of the Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM).

(2) This is a matter primarily for the Western Australian Government to judge. I have been advised that the ecotour will assist in a scientific research program. The proposal is similar in intent to the internationally accepted Earthwatch Institute programs.
(3) The authorisation is for one tour of Dorre Island based on a research program.
(4) The tour involves visits to the Island over three days.
(5) The number of visitors will be limited to fifteen.
(6) The visitors will not stay overnight on the Island.

(7) Conditions for the authorisation include the prohibition of camping or fires on the Island. The tour will be accompanied by scientists from CALM. The proposed tour has been referred to Western Australia's Environmental Protection Authority which has decided not to require an assessment of the project.
The proposal has the approval of the National Parks and Nature Conservation Authority, the vesting body for the Bernier and Dorre Islands Nature Reserve.
(8) Scientists from CALM will monitor the visit.
(9) (a) The ecotour visitors will participate in trapping and tracking western barred bandicoots, some of which will have radio collars attached.

(b) (c) The research to be carried out on the Island by the visitors is part of a research program on the western barred bandicoot which commenced in 1986. The results of the research into the habitat preference of the Western barred bandicoot will be retained by CALM. The information will be used in the selection and management of suitable areas for re-introduction of this threatened species to parts of its former range.
(10) A financial contribution will be made by the ecotour organisation.
(11) The contribution, which was not specified, will go towards meeting CALM's costs for its three week research program.
(12) I am prepared to talk with West Australian environmental groups about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories upon notice, on 14 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What commitments and objectives has the Australian Government made to reducing carbon dioxide levels.
(2) What progress has been achieved to date.
(3) What monitoring process has been established to monitor the outcomes of this objective and what reporting processes will be put in place.
(4) What consideration has been given to the impact of population growth in meeting the set objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Reduction of carbon dioxide levels has been addressed by the Government in its decision in October 1990 to adopt an interim planning target of stabilising emissions of greenhouse gases (including carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide etc), based on 1988 levels, by the year 2000, and reducing these emissions by 20% by 2005. As part of that decision, it was also determined that Australia would not proceed with the adoption of response measures which have net adverse economic impacts nationally, or on Australia's trade competitiveness, in the absence of similar action by major greenhouse gas producing countries.

(2) The Government has taken steps to reduce carbon dioxide levels in the decision, endorsed by the States and Territories, to develop a National Greenhouse Response Strategy (NGRS). The Strategy will be based on the interim planning target and a major component will be positive measures for limiting emissions of all greenhouse gases. Joint Commonwealth, State and Territory activity this year has resulted in production of the document The Draft National Greenhouse Response Strategy—A discussion paper. This was released and widely distributed for public comment on 30 June 1992. It is proposed that the first phase of the NGRS will be completed by late 1992.

A report titled "Programs Implemented and Policies Adopted Since 1988 that Contribute to Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Australia", prepared by the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC), summarises measures that are already under way to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions.

(3) The NGRS will identify measures for auditing and reporting on greenhouse gas emissions. Specifically, part of the Strategy will involve the development and implementation of a national greenhouse gas emissions inventory.

(4) The Industry Commission study into the Costs and Benefits of Reducing Greenhouse Gas Emissions (1991), pointed out that, if there are rises in factors such as income, consumption levels, and population growth over time, greenhouse gas emissions per capita would need to be reduced further than if these conditions did not hold, in order that the emissions level remains constant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 June (Hansard, page 4603) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me as Minister representing the Prime Minister a question without notice about small business representation at the National Meeting on Youth Training and Employment chaired by the Prime Minister on 22 July 1992 in Canberra. I undertook to obtain an answer for Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The National Meeting on Youth Training and Employment was attended by about 50 representa-

ANSWER.PARA: tives of business, trade unions, governments, community groups and young Australians, who discussed a range of proposals to increase work and training opportunities for Australia's youth.

PARA.TAB: As a representative of the small business sector, Mr Paul Greenwood, Chairman of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia (COSBOA) attended the National Meeting and played an active part in discussions. COSBOA also made a written submission to the National Meeting outlining a number of proposals on training and employment measures for consideration.
Among the other business delegates were representatives of the farming, building and construction and retail sectors. All have significant numbers of small business operators.
